PETITION.TITLE: X-rated and Violent Video Material
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate assembled in Parliament:
The petition of citizens of Australia points out:

that all State Governments, States Attorneys-General, most women's groups and the majority of men in Australia, including significant numbers of Members of Parliament, are totally opposed to the importation and distribution of `X' and excessively violent `R'-rated video pornography in Australia.
that most `X-rated' material available in Australia is imported.
that the Federal Government, by its Customs power under the Constitution, and not the A.C.T. Government, is solely responsible for controlling the importation of this pornographic material.
that by continuing to allow the importation of such pornographic material, the Federal Government is neglecting its responsibility to the women, children and families of Australia.
Your petitioners, therefore, request the Senate to:
1. Ban `X'-rated pornographic material at the point of entry into Australia.
2. Exclude from the `R'-rating all gratuitously violent material.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare: Abortions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President of the Senate and the Senators in Parliament assembled:
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That every abortion kills an unborn human baby.
That the right to life of all humans is the most fundamental and essential of all human rights.
That the Government's first duty is to protect this right to life.
That the most defenceless and threatened lives are those of unborn babies for whom the Government is duty bound to take extra steps to protect.
That in 1987/88 taxpayers funds through Medi- care provided Medical Benefits for 61,879 abortions totalling $6.4 million.
That in the same year Commonwealth grants to the States indirectly financed the deliberate killing of thousands of other unborn babies in State Public Hospitals.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Parliament will carry out its duty to protect the right to life of Australian babies by ceasing to fund abortions through Medicare, restricting grants to the States and by all other means at its disposal.
And your petitioners as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare: Abortions
PETITION.PARA: The Honourable President and members of the Senate assembled in Parliament. This petition of the below citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the Senate that we support the continued cover for all abortions on the Medicare schedule. We oppose any attempt to restrict access to the rebate under Medicare.

Medicare cannot pretend to be a Universal health care system without providing a rebate for a termination of pregnancy. Those who will be hardest hit by proposals to restrict access to items 6469, 274 and 275 on the Medicare schedule are poorer and disadvantaged women who will not be able to meet the cost of a non-subsidised abortion.
Your petitioners humbly pray and request that the Senate will vote against any attempt to restrict access to abortion or any abortion-related items on the Medicare schedule.

That the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Act, 1988 includes legislation Part III-Changes to Non-Government Schools and New Non-Government Schools, designed to inhibit the establishment, growth and development of these schools in Australia by the imposition of restrictive provisions in the areas of funding, enrolments and approval criteria.

PETITION.TITLE: Animal Patents
PETITION.PARA: To the President and members of the Australian Senate

The undersigned citizens of Australia, and custodians of the Earth, oppose the patenting of animals, and the processes for altering them. Animal patents would reduce biodiversity, compromise animal welfare, concentrate ownership of breeding stock, and allow companies to appropriate the fruit of centuries of selective breeding. We note with concern that many applications for animal patents have been lodged with the Australian Patents Office and without your intervention they may soon be approved.
Please take all possible steps immediately to ensure that:
1. The Patents Office rejects all existing applications for animal patents and declines to accept any more;
2. The Senate amends the Patents Bill 1989 to prohibit the patenting of animals.
We pray that all members of the Australian Senate will act on this petition.

PETITION.TITLE: Company Tax Collection System
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

The Government's Budget decision to change the company tax collection system will be a crippling blow to many small businesses, already suffering as a direct result of the Hawke Labor Government's high interest rate policy.
The earlier remittance of company tax payments to the Government will substantially reduce the cash-flow position of thousands of small businesses.

Many small businesses will be driven under as a result of the Government's decision-unable to find funds for both tax commitments and new stock, only able to borrow at record high interest rates and unable to claim any tax relief on such borrowings to meet their tax commitment.
The Government's proposed changes to the company tax collection system has only been introduced as a greedy grab for more tax revenue.

The small business community would prefer the Government to completely abandon the proposal rather than make only minor alterations to the original Budget decision, which are not likely to alleviate the situation to any significant extent.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Privacy Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate assembled.

The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws attention to the Senate of their concern regarding proposed changes to the laws governing credit reporting, as suggested in the Bill ``The Privacy Amendment Bill 1989''.
The proposed reforms will:
Restrict the legitimate use of credit checking by businesses who sell/supply goods and or services to their customers on credit terms.

The proposals/reforms will prevent businesses from determining the solvency of their customers and will increase the financial risk of credit providers, leading to an increase in company liquidations and individual bankruptcies.

Additional costs to business from bad debts due to the lack of adequate credit checking information will result in increased prices/charges and will result in credit providers refusing credit facilities.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the Senate will call on the Government to refer these proposals restricting credit checking to a Senate select committee for further consideration before proceeding with the matter.

DEBATE.TITLE: PRIMARY INDUSTRIES AND ENERGY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1989PRIMARY INDUSTRIES AND ENERGY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 3) 1989PRIMARY INDUSTRIES AND ENERGY RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT BILL 1989

PROCTEXT.PARA: PRIMARY INDUSTRIES AND ENERGY RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT BILL 1989

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —The Committee is considering the Primary Industries and Energy Research and Development Bill 1989. I believe that Senator Lewis, by leave, has moved Opposition amendments (1), (2) and (3). The question is that the three amendments moved by Senator Lewis be agreed to.

INTERJECT.PARA: Senator Tate-Mr Chairman, I am taking instructions. I do not know whether the Government wishes to oppose these amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —Last night Senator Cook indicated on behalf of the Government that the Government opposed my amendments. I observed that the Australian Democrats are also opposing my amendments, so I accept that it is inevitable that these amendments will be lost. By saying this I am having recorded in Hansard that the Democrats are supporting the Government on this matter.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Page 4, subclause 4 (1), definition of ``primary industry'', paragraph (b), lines 6 to 9, leave out the paragraph, insert the following paragraph:
``(b) the extraction from the environment of:
(i) minerals; or
(ii) substances from which energy is made available; or
(iii) energy; or.''.
(2) Page 4, subclause 4 (1), definition of ``primary industry'', paragraph (c), lines 10 and 11, leave out the paragraph, insert the following paragraph:
``(c) the conservation and the sustainable use and management of a natural resource.''.

The Committee will note that the amendments which were circulated in my name last night have been split into two because I believe that the Government or the Opposition might find one or other of them acceptable. The wording is exactly the same as the form in which they were presented last night except that they are now presented as two amendments. The amendments, which are to clause 4 of the Primary Industries and Energy Research and Development Bill 1989, deal with the definition of `primary industry'. I remind the Committee of the wording in the Bill.
`primary industry' means any field of endeavour whose objective is:
(a) the production of agricultural or other primary produce; or-
and we have no problem with that-
(b) the extraction from the environment, or the production, of:
(i) minerals; or
(ii) substances from which energy may be produced; or
(iii) energy; or
(c) the conservation of, or the sustainable use and management of, a natural resource;

I want to stress very strongly two points. Firstly, just as with sexist language we have, over recent decades, dealt with a situation in which the language has not only reflected certain attitudes in the community, but also to some extent has reinforced them, so in this definition we have the use of words which misunderstands the way in which society is thinking. Secondly, the words are physically incorrect. I point out again that it is unfortunate that we do not have more people with a science background in this place and in the House of Representatives and that we do not have among parliamentary draftspersons people who also have some knowledge of such basic elements of science as the first law of thermodynamics-that energy can neither be created nor destroyed.
Let us take the first objection which is to part (b) of that definition. Part (b) states:
the extraction from the environment, or the production, of:
(i) minerals;

The fact of the matter is that we cannot produce minerals. There is one possible exception and that would be Synroc, which some people have called an artificial mineral, but that is really stretching the imagination. The objection here is to the idea that we produce anything from nature. We extract it, exploit it and process it, but we do not produce it. The word `production' there is physically quite incorrect; it is not in conformity with what we actually do.

I understand that the Government's intention is to cover the extraction from the environment of minerals and various other substances, and therefore to take out the words `or the production' is quite appropriate. The paragraph would then refer to `the extraction from the environment of minerals' and that is covered. I stress again that we do not produce minerals and therefore the word `production' is quite inappropriate in that context. Moreover, if we go onto (ii) of paragraph (b), in its full context it refers to the extraction from the environment of `substances from which energy may be produced'. The physical truth of the matter is that we do not produce energy. Energy can neither be created nor destroyed. That is one of the basic laws of physics. We take one form of energy and transform it into another form. For example, we burn coal and it is chemical energy. We then turn it into heat energy and that heat energy is turned into mechanical energy and that mechanical energy is turned into electri- city. That is a series of processes of transformation of energy. We do not produce energy. It is physically impossible for human beings to produce energy. So again, (ii) is quite inappropriate. The words simply do not conform with the basic laws of nature. Surely human laws should as one of their basic requirements conform with the laws of nature.

TALK.START.PARA: —It would be nice if they did.

—It would be nice if they did. The second objection is to paragraph (c) and is of a different kind. This indicates the way in which the Government appears to be picking up on words such as sustainability but not really understanding what the conservation movement is on about. Paragraph (c), reading it in context, states:

SPEECH.PARA: (c) the conservation of, or the sustainable use and management of, a natural resource.

Surely, conservation does mean the sustainable use and management of a natural resource. They are not alternatives. The point I would like to stress in relation to the second amendment to this definition is that it should read `the conservation and the sustainable use', and not `the conservation of, or the sustainable use.' Those things are not inconsistent: they must be consistent. If the Government is serious about sustainability and is beginning to understand what these terms mean, it should support the alteration of those words to read `the conservation and the sustainable use and management of a natural resource'. I do not think that in any sense changes the thrust of what the Government is attempting to legislate for in relation to its coverage of primary industry. I therefore commend both of those amendments to the Committee. If there is objection to one or the other I would seek to split the two and vote on them separately, but I hope they will both be acceptable to the Committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition has no objection to the Australian Democrats' amendments. I would like to comment on something Senator Coulter said in relation to paragraph (c). As I understand him, he is saying that, as to the words `the conservation of, or the sustainable use and management of, a natural resource', the words `conservation' and `sustainable use' are synonymous. Senator Coulter nods to confirm that. That goes along with something I said previously in a debate in this chamber in which Senator Cook and I participated. All of this talk about sustainable use is a lot of nonsense. We are talking about the conservation of the environment, and Senator Coulter has just confirmed that it is a lot of nonsense because they are in fact synonymous. When the Liberal and National parties talk about the conservation of our environment they are saying exactly the same thing as the Democrats, who are talking about the sustainable use of our environment. I thank Senator Coulter for confirming what I believe to be the case.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have had a chance this morning to look at the newly circulated amendments from Senator Coulter and listen to his supporting argument for them. They entice me to make a long, erudite and incisive speech which would dwell on pedantry to make clear the fine differences of meaning between the various shades of emphasis that come into this debate. I will decline to do so because, while we would have a morning-long intellectual gymnastic exercise which would be rewarding to those of us who engaged in it, it would not advance the progress of this Bill very far. Suffice it for me to say that, from a government point of view, that long discourse would come out, at the bottom line, to agreeing with Senator Coulter's amendments. Perhaps I should weaken at one point and be enticed marginally into the argument about sustainable use, since it was the Hawke Labor Government in the July environment statement, the first environment statement ever put down by a government in Australia, that brought into political popular usage the word `sustainability'; but I will not. In short, we support the amendments.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is my instinct to oppose this amendment to the full extent. I will make a few remarks and then invite Senator Powell to respond once more so that I can be clear as to the precise position of the Australian Democrats before I finally indicate to the Committee the Government's position. What is intended is that there be a research and development corporation established for producer organisations, not for processing organisations. It is true that many of the cooperatives that are referred to are owned by producers but have a charter to be processing organisations. The Government could certainly live on the cusp of a definition which enabled the smaller-quite clearly, almost communal-cooperative type of organisations to share in a research and development corporation of this sort.

SPEECH.PARA: To illustrate my point, let me refer to two major cooperatives which dominate the field of dairying-Bonlac Foods Ltd and Murray Goulburn Co-op Pty Ltd. According to the June 1989 figures, Bonlac's sales stood at $574m for that year; Murray Goulburn to June 1989 had total sales of $481m. TALK.START.PARA: —The Transport and Communications Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) is an omnibus Bill which amends 15 pieces of transport and communications legislation. My colleague Senator Alston will be dealing with the communications aspects of the legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: The reform of Australia's transport system is urgent and long overdue. Australia has a global isolation, and its resource centres and population locations are dispersed. The 1982 report of the Crawford Committee on Revitalisation of Australian Shipping indicated that only 3 per cent of Australia's international trade was being carried by Australian ships. As Australia is a major trading nation, that was an appalling story.

Since then we have established a link between certain taxation incentives-firstly, with investment allowances and more latterly with depreciation allowances-and agreed crewing levels. There has been some progress in that area. But Australia has some major problems, because Australian coastal shipping is extraordinarily expensive when compared with the costs of international shipping. As I come from Tasmania, I am particularly aware of that and of the impact it has on our local economy. For example a little time ago the Ford Motor Co. of Australia found that freight charges for sending motor vehicles from Melbourne to Tasmania were roughly comparable-in fact, only 5 per cent cheaper-with charges from Melbourne to San Francisco. That gives some indication of the problems that we face in Australia with the high cost of shipping. Clearly the cost of coastal shipping is unsustainable because of its impact on other industries.

However, we must acknowledge that there has been some progress in the area. But from the Liberal-National Party coalition point of view, progress in micro-economic reform has been far too slow. Manning levels have fallen-I think from 35 crew to about 30; about 14 per cent. Fuel efficiencies have increased, from 1.26 to 0.7 tonnes per thousand dead weight tonnes. But over 50 per cent of shipping costs-for example, in the Bass Strait general cargo trade-are incurred in port, stevedoring and port authority charges. This is a major problem. For bulk and tanker operations, these costs account for up to 30 per cent of total shipping costs. So the cost of general cargo stevedoring, speed of ship turnaround and reliability of the waterfront are of prime concern not only to shipowners but also to the coalition and the people of Australia.

The Navigation Act and the relevant regulations have no power over the conduct of intrastate trade. Matters that impede competitiveness include our lagging behind in international trends in manning costs. We are making improvements, but certainly not far or fast enough. There must be access to capital and fuel at the same cost levels as apply to foreign competitors because, of the costs, capital represents something like, for 100,000 dead weight tonnage, 33 per cent; crew, 22 per cent; fuel, 16 per cent; port charges, 14 per cent; and other costs, about 15 per cent. Ship-based costs compare unfavourably with those for international vessels. While the investment in new ships and changes in management practices have produced savings of 20 per cent or more, as I mentioned, large cost disadvantages remain. Those areas need to come within the compass of what we term micro-economic reform.

Certain people have difficulties with the concept of governments actually subsidising reform from which industry participants themselves tend to benefit. Before us today we have legislation to amend the Ships (Capital Grants) Act 1987. When in government, the Opposition will recognise the need for more urgent action than we have here before us today to reform the Australian transport and communications structure. It is not unnatural that people around Australia have some concerns about proposals to extend the eligibility to grants under the Ships (Capital Grants) Act because they have a legitimate view that Australian taxpayers should not be called upon to subsidise the shipowners who benefit from these proposals. The Opposition was considering an amendment in this area but, given the urgency to get this legislation onto the statute books and through the Senate, we will not delay proceedings at this stage. It is in Australia's interests to get this legislation through speedily before Christmas.

I will deal first with the Acts to be amended under the auspices of the transport sections of this Bill. Clauses 3 to 5 of part 2 of the Bill seek to amend the Air Navigation Act 1920 by proposing a new definition of aviation security to both the principal Act and the regulations. Following the enactment to the Civil Aviation Act in 1988, the regulatory power of the Air Navigation Act to extend to aviation security unfortunately became unclear. The Civil Aviation Authority is supposedly responsible for aviation safety but this did not extend to aviation security. Previously, aviation safety was considered to extend to security. The Opposition supports this amendment to clear up this anomaly.

I now turn to the amendment to the Australian Airlines (Conversion into Public Company) Act 1988. The proposed changes to this Act are contained in part 4 of the Bill and cover what appears to be a fairly routine drafting error. Amendments to the Interstate Road Transport Act 1985 are contained in part 9, clauses 22 to 26. There are three main changes. Firstly, the amendment will allow the State and Territory regulatory authorities to link the prescribed fees that are payable to the consumer price index so that there do not have to be adjustments from time to time. Secondly, the Government is tightening the prosecution provision of the Act. Thirdly, these amendments will allow spot fines for mass limit or over loading offences as an alternative to prosecution. The maximum penalty will be $200 for individuals and $3,000 for corporations. The purpose of this amendment is to reduce the burden on the court system. Again, the Opposition supports these amendments.

Amendments to the Motor Vehicle Standards Act 1989 are contained in part 10, clauses 27 to 37. This very recent Act has been amended to provide a proper link between it and the Customs Act in regard to Customs clearance of imported vehicles, which must meet the standards of the principal Act. The amendments also empower the Minister to make determinations of practices to be followed by manufacturers or importers of vehicles in regard to testing and record keeping. The amendments also cover the power of the Minister to suspend or cancel an authority to affix compliance plates where these practices are not followed and to bring emissions of particulate matter within the pollution control measures under the Act, which currently apply only to emission of gases.

While these amendments are not objectionable, it is difficult to understand why they were not included when the principal Act was passed earlier this year. Again, I think we have a case of overloaded legislation and insufficient attention to detail. As we have been told that the Act was the result of years of consultation, the Opposition, not unnaturally, asks why the basic points about cancellation of authority to affix compliance plates and the involvement of the Australian Customs Act were not considered. On the face of it, it would seem that the matter has not been thought through. As I said earlier, it simply represents a sloppy approach.

The Navigation Act 1912 is amended by clauses 38 to 47 contained in part 11 of the Bill. In summary, the clauses seek to allow a trading ship to be brought under Federal jurisdiction, amend some provisions in respect of the Marine Council, rationalise the statutory committee system and revise the agreement of jurisdiction in the case of collision regulations. This omnibus package also contains changes to the Navigation Amendment Act 1980, which is amended by clauses 48 and 49, which simply repeal unproclaimed provisions.

The Protection of the Sea (Prevention of Pollution from Ships) Act 1983 is amended by clauses 52 and 53 in part 14. Again this corrects a drafting deficiency and enables Australia's ratification of annexe V of the Convention for the Prevention of Pollution from Ships-the MARPOL Convention-which was mentioned yesterday briefly during the debate on the hazardous waste and industrial chemicals package.

Finally the Bill amends the Ships (Capital Grants) Act 1987. Some members of the community are concerned about using taxpayers' funds for a sort of subsidy in this matter. Again the urgency for change is great. Something has to be done. Some people believe that this is an appropriate way of spending taxpayers' funds to improve efficiency and lift Australia's productivity; other people believe this is the wrong use of taxpayers' funds. Again, the purpose of the change is to extend the availability of grants under the Act for new ships to 30 June 1997, and in respect of modifications to existing ships completed before 30 June 1992. The current scheme, which commenced on 1 June 1987, was to end on 30 June 1992 for new ships and 1990 for modifications. Also under this Bill a loophole is also closed against claims of excessive grant payments and a drafting error is corrected to make it easier for a special category of applicants-namely, for ships crewed below the standard crew.

In April this year the report of the shipping reform task force was presented. Its recommendations included an extension of assistance provided under the Ships (Capital Grants) Act 1987 for at least five years. The Opposition welcomes any moves to decrease manning levels, which are very high by world standards. In Australia it is well known that we require approximately 2.5 crews per ship compared with about 1.6 in most other parts of the world. But we do have some reservations, as I said earlier, about the idea of taxpayers footing the Bill for a grant aimed at putting these industries on a commercial basis from which, ultimately, the shipowners will benefit. Of course, that concept is not new in Australia. The cost to the taxpayer in this area is $52m over and above what is already committed to this project.

There is no doubt that reform of the waterfront and coastal shipping must be a priority if this country is to return to normal financial health. It has been estimated, for example, that if we can improve the efficiency of the waterfront by 20 per cent, Australia's gross domestic product could be boosted by over $1,000m each year. In regard to coastal shipping, reforms in that area could save something in the order of $550m per annum. However, whether the taxpayer should foot the bill for measures aimed at productivity increases is a matter for some concern. The Opposition also has some reservations about this link between the unions and government and the effect that this is having on the ability to institute reform of the magnitude and with the speed necessary.
In closing, I would like to remind the Senate of what the Industries Assistance Commission said in its annual report. It stated:
. . . an efficient transport sector is essential because of our global isolation, the location of our natural resources and the dispersion of major population centres.
It will be much harder to improve our trading performance if we maintain a transport system which unnecessarily inflate costs or delay the delivery of goods and services.

Naturally, the Opposition supports that. We support the thrust of the Bill despite some reservations, but we are concerned at the lack of speed and effectiveness of this program of micro-economic reform.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we are debating the Transport and Communications Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1989. This is an omnibus Bill with a wide coverage of amendments to various Acts pertaining to transport and communications. I would like to address briefly a few of those Acts; namely, the Ships (Capital Grants) Act 1987, the Interstate Transport Act 1985, the Broadcasting Act 1942 and the Telecommunications Act 1989. The amendment to the Ships (Capital Grants) Act is probably the most important one. This is to put into effect the part of the shipping industry reform announced by the Government earlier this year. The amendment extends the period of available benefits to 30 June 1997 for new ships and to 30 June 1992 for older ships. The purpose of this exercise is to help shipowners to the tune of 7 per cent to provide for older ships to take advantage of the opportunity to get crew levels down to comparable figures with vessels of other Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) countries. Australian shipping has undergone some major structural changes in recent years. That has certainly not been before time.

SPEECH.PARA: Anyone who has any remote knowledge of the Australian shipping industry knows full well of the practices and overmanning that has been inherent. It takes 2.5 crews to operate an Australian ship, whereas in other countries similar to Australia it is down to 1.6 crews. This has been going on for such a long time that this move to cut manning is well overdue. We are still lagging behind the rest of the world because it is reducing its manning levels faster than we are. It is able to provide the shipping services for exports at a lower cost. In many cases these exports are competing with our own exports. Australian exports have been put to a great disadvantage for years and years. This has also been due to problems with the waterfront. An Industries Assistance Commission report of last year pointed out that savings of $550m per year could be achieved if coastal shipping could be brought into line with other OECD countries. Australia needs these reforms of coastal shipping and the waterfront if it is to achieve anything towards cutting its overseas debt.

Cabotage must be removed to let Australian shipping compete with overseas shipping so that we can find out what rational freights are. To show my point of what some members of this Government think of removing cabotage I will quote from the House of Representatives Hansard. I have said before in this chamber that it could be the `fairytale publication' of this Parliament. I will quote Mr O'Neil, the honourable member for Grey, who spoke in the debate in that House. I do not have the date. Mr O'Neil said:

As for opening up cabotage on coastal shipping, I realise that vested interests want to repeal part VI of the Navigation Act 1912, which would mean the deregulation of Australian coastal shipping. I firmly believe this to be scandalous. I am delighted to see that honourable members on this side of the House, including the Minister, are very strongly opposed to this. With the tremendous changes that have taken place in the Australian coastal trade and in the manning of ships and so forth, it is quite appalling that we should further disadvantage our people.

Who are those vested interests that want cabotage lifted in Australia? I will tell you who they are, Mr Acting Deputy President. They are the producers of wealth and exports in Australia. They are the ones that want cabotage lifted to throw Australian coastal shipping open to competition with other countries so that we can experience how coastal shipping and freight rates should be. It was from the next quote from Mr O'Neil that I concluded that he did not know what he was talking about. He said:
It is ironic that we will not accept shearers from overseas to work in our shearing sheds and we do not want other people coming in and controlling our industries.

I do not know where Mr O'Neil, the honourable member for Grey, has been since he has been in Parliament. I am in a position to know what the shearing industry and the wool industry of Australia are doing. I can tell honourable senators that the shortage of shearers has been fixed in the last 10 years by bringing in the Kiwis. Here we have a fellow saying that we will not accept them. Not knowing much about Mr O'Neil I thought I would get out the Parliamentary Handbook to see what sort of electorate he represents. His electorate was described as rural and industrial; its location as a large electorate covering most of rural South Australia. The industries in that electorate are power generation, railway workshops, lead, silver and zinc, smelting, steelworks, shipbuilding, as well as extensive grain, wool, fishing and service industries and opal mining. This gentleman does not know that we have Kiwi shearers in Australia. He does not know the importance of coastal shipping and of rationalising shipping in Australia so that we can compete in the world markets. So much for Mr O'Neil. On the same day he continued.
It is a national disgrace that less than 5 per cent of our trade is carried in our ships.
He is a slow learner. He is wondering why only 5 per cent is carried and then he carries on with all those stories of why we should not remove cabotage.

However welcome this reform is, I do not see why the Australian taxpayer has to foot the bill while ships are being adjusted to take the lesser crews. From my understanding the taxpayer will be paying out $52m over the next three years, over and above what has already been committed to this program. Over that period that $52m should provide benefits to the shipping industry of some $80m. From that point forward the Australian shipping industry should benefit to the tune of $50m annually, hopefully spreading to all Australians. If the shipping industry is to benefit that much, why should the taxpayer have to pay out?

This is similar to the Kodak (Australasia) Pty Ltd deal, the airlines deal and the tourist industry deal, but rather different from the farm manufacturers deal that we had, especially as it related to the John Shearer Ltd manufacturing industry of South Australia which manufactures tillage and harvesting machines. If, after having spent the money to restructure coastal shipping, the results are that good, the shipping lines could foot the bill themselves. That would at least show that the companies plan to stay on in the future, not just for the life of the subsidy. This is what I am afraid will happen with Kodak. The waterfront is a typical example of where the Government has to fork out money to buy out restrictive practices and fund early retirement because of various fiascos. The wheat industry, which we have recently deregulated, has received no such treatment. I am sure that there are other industries, such as the road industry, that would like to receive the same sort of treatment.

The main purpose of the part of the Bill dealing with the Interstate Road Transport Act is to link the prescribed fees applicable and payable to the States and Territories to the consumer price index (CPI). This is a commendable measure. It means that fees are able to be increased without having to be justified each time. It is a pity that the Government does not index the money that is returned to roads, through the fuel levy, to the CPI. Fuel is indexed to the CPI but the return to roads is certainly not treated in the same fashion. Only the collections are indexed; not the spending on roads.

The second purpose of this part of the legislation is to strengthen provisions on prosecuting directors, agents and employees in breach of the Interstate Road Transport Act. The provisions apply mainly to make managing directors, directors and agents responsible for the actions of their employees. This has not been very well explained, and during the committee stage I will be seeking information. The last purpose of this part of the Bill is to allow for on the spot fines for overloading offences. Once again, I am well aware of this problem. This move, in the name of cutting down on the log of work in the courts, is a reasonable enough measure. In the future, revenue raising will get a boost because of the advances in technology. Trucks will be able to be weighed and have speeds recorded electronically while on the move. If laws are being broken, people will be fined and there will be an increase in revenue.

I will say a few words about the viability and safety of the interstate transport industry. Heavy vehicles have certainly been in the news lately. Many have been involved in traffic accidents with a resultant loss of life. We heard about some more this morning. There are a few reasons for this upsurge in accidents. The main reasons could be speed, the state of the roads and the volume of traffic on the roads. One must look beyond these three points to ascertain why these problems exist. I will take them in order. First, speed could be attributed to a plethora of reasons but the main ones could be summed up by referring to rising costs, extra competition and cowboy drivers. We need to cut down on the number of cowboy drivers. There is a need for graduated driving licences. To cover ever increasing costs under this Government heavy vehicles have to do more trips each week. Interest rates are the greatest single factor, closely followed by increased damage to vehicles and tyres and increased fuel usage because of this Government's neglect of our roads. One adds to the other. Secondly, Australian roads are in their worst condition ever because of the 40 per cent cut in real terms in road funding over the last four years, less than the life of this Government.

My third point is the increased volume of traffic. Traffic is increasing because of a few factors. Heavy vehicles have to increase their number of trips to stay viable. There has been an increase in traffic due to the airline dispute. It finished one month ago, but we still have record numbers of bus and heavy vehicle trips. Along with the Australian one car, one person mentality, we have a worse traffic volume scenario because of the failure of the other transport modes; that is, coastal shipping and rail transport. It is scandalous that road transport should be able to compete with shipping and rail on the long haul routes for bulk loads.

I have already discussed coastal shipping. I cannot see that there will be much improvement in the short term. But there is one hope on the horizon-and that is rail. If the recommendations of the subcommittee of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure are carried out, there is hope for the future. My understanding is that the subcommittee emanated from the House of Representatives Standing Committee to examine the national rail system. At present, we need more money on roads and we need to assert control over the drivers of heavy trucks and buses. Generally, bus drivers get off light in the debate on road accidents. But they speed and they break road rules, as do drivers of the heavy vehicles. That is why I do not mind giving them a mention. Whatever is needed on these vehicles, such as speed limiters and tachographs, should be installed. However, that is a debate for another day.

Finally, I move to the Telecommunications Act. Under this Bill, the service available to constituents having trouble receiving radio or television broadcasts is to be charged for. With today's more electronically minded young people, these problems can generally be sorted out in the home. If they cannot be sorted out at home, tradesmen are available. Interference in home reception usually comes from power generators, supply lines and transformers. In respect of clause 19 the explanatory memorandum states:

21. This clause amends section 125d of the Principal Act by inserting a new subsection (4) to allow the Minister to make charges for the investigation of interference to the reception of radio and television programs.
22. Often broadcasting reception difficulties are not caused by interfering signals, but rather are attributable to factors which are quite beyond the Department's ability to correct.

I fully understand that. However, it continues to say that common examples involve emission from electrical reticulation systems. How does the Minister for Resources (Senator Cook) justify asking the householder to rectify such problems? I believe that the householder, in general, will always try to sort out his or her problem with receivers, whether they be radio receivers, television receivers or two-way radio receivers, if one happens to have one in the home or in the business.
