TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to confine my remarks to the communications provisions in the Transport and Communications Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1989, which is an omnibus Bill. I would like to start with the matter which Senator Panizza has just finished dealing with. The principal amendment to the Broadcasting Act will allow the Minister to make charges for the investigation of complaints of interference to the reception of radio and television services. The proposed change is said to be necessary because of the increasing use of the Department's free investigation services, often in cases where the problem lies with the domestic receiving installation and, therefore, should be treated as a problem for the consumer rather than a problem for the Government.

SPEECH.PARA: We have been provided with some statistics which suggest that some 16,000 complaints of reception and interference difficulties are investigated annually by some 40 staff members of the Department. Over 75 per cent of those cases ultimately turn out to involve problems caused by deficiencies in receivers, inadequate or faulty antenna installations, local faults in power line systems, or people trying to receive stations not intended for their areas. In other words, these are not strict interference problems; they are not difficulties caused by the installations for which the Government ought to be responsible.

We take the view that it is reasonable for a charge to be imposed in circumstances where consumers are essentially freeloading off the Government, where they could quite simply, and presumably much more cheaply than with all the unnecessary costs that are often built into government charges, make their own arrangements. But there are still some areas in which I think we have genuine concerns and on which we would require some further information.

It is proposed that a $60 call-out fee should be applied, but it is not at all clear from the explanatory memorandum whether that money will be refunded in the event that it is found to be a problem relating to the equipment rather than a problem that could have been rectified by the individual consumer. It would certainly be our view that, if it ultimately transpires that the consumer was justified in calling on the Government to investigate the matter, that amount should be refunded.

Senator Panizza raised what I think is a much more difficult area. We can always see these things in black and white and say, `If it is the individual's fault, the individual pays; if it is the Government's fault, in terms of interference, the Government pays', but there will inevitably be a large number of grey areas. Senator Panizza quite rightly raised his experience of microwave links which some months later turn out to be the problem. Presumably in that situation the Government should bear the cost. But I can envisage situations where it is a scoreless draw, where no-one really knows who is at fault and, in those circumstances, I would take the view that the consumer should get the benefit of the doubt. So it is only where it can be clearly demonstrated that it is a problem that can be rectified by technicians employed by the consumer that any charges should be borne by the individual.

It is also not clear to me whether that $60 call-out fee is merely a start and whether other charges might be levied down the line. If there are to be those charges we should know about them up-front. It is also not clear when the system is to start. I think one can safely hazard a guess that the Government's intention is that it should not be introduced prior to the election, because the note I have states that it is planned in early 1990 to introduce the proposed $60 call-out charge for the investigation of individual reception.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why do you think that wouldn't be before the election?
—I would like an indication as to why it is proposed simply to start that in early 1990. If there is no magic about dates can we be told when it is proposed to introduce it?
—I've no idea when the election might be.

—That is what I am saying. If it is just to be left up in the air, and flexible, the inevitable suspicion will be that no announcement will be made prior to the election. If it is not driven by the election timetable, could the Minister for Resources (Senator Cook) please tell us when the Government proposes to introduce it?
—On 1 March.
—I am indebted to the Minister's advisers for that information, so we can readjust our election timetable accordingly.
—I am not the person who makes the decision about the election, I can tell you that.
—Can the Minister assure us that that fee timetable will not be affected by any election announcement?
—I am advised 1 March. We might spend more time discussing it in the committee stage.
—Can you assure us that you will not double it when you get in?

— We have no intention of doing that. We are interested to see how it works. We note that the actual charge is $175-or so it is said-but I again take the view that that probably has substantial featherbedding built into it and the real cost is probably significantly less. So we do not see any need to have full cost recovery at this stage.

SPEECH.PARA: The matter I draw attention to is a classic example of the way these issues are generally handled at ministerial level, as opposed to departmental level, where I think a genuine effort has been made to come to grips with the difficulties. The booklet that has been put together, no doubt, has involved a lot of time and research and I think is ultimately a very useful guide to users. But what concerns me is the pre-election pollyanna material put out by the Minister for Telecommunications and Aviation Support (Mrs Kelly). It rabbits on about Government moves to improve television and radio knowledge; it tells us about all these wonderful things that the Government will be doing to help us, how copies of the booklets are going out to 2,500 technicians and antenna installers around Australia; and it makes it clear that, in the best of all possible worlds, this is meant to assist consumers and help people to determine whether they can handle the problem themselves or whether they need the assistance of a technician. What it does do quite clearly and deliberately is avoid any mention of the cost. It is very selective and disinformative in that sense.

Clearly, knowledge of the charge is meant to bring about a revolution in consumers' attitudes, so that their first port of call is not the Government but rather the local technician to get their own advice, which will be much more cost efficient. But no, none of that is included in this press release. There is no mention made of charges, just the usual soft sell-another example of the obsession with public relations, an utterly superficial approach to serious technical issues. In combination with `do-nothing Ralph', the assistance of the Minister for self-promotional media opportunities makes it clear why broadcasting regulation is in a state of crisis and why this sort of press release will do nothing to address the real issues.

The amendments to the Telecommunications Act are to enable the Overseas Telecommunications Commission (OTC) to continue to provide reserve services by satellite-based facilities within the external territories and by satellite facilities or otherwise, between the external territories and other places within Australia. This is said to be a drafting error and we do not object to drafting errors being corrected; we are all fallible. What is of interest in this context is an article that appeared in yesterday's Age by Jay Spencer, in the section `Computer Age', which says:
. . . Telecom's fiercest competitor has been OTC, not a private company, despite Mr Ward's-
the Managing Director of Telecom-
eagerness to merge OTC with Telecom.

I do not know whether the journalist got it right, but if he did that is a matter for very serious concern. I would hope that the Government will be vigilant and ensure that no such merger proposal is encouraged in any way.

Telecom has been dead keen for many years to get its hands on Aussat Pty Ltd. It is news to me that it is now in the business of trying to take over OTC. Either of those steps would be entirely retrograde in the interests of genuine competition. The last thing we want in this country is yet another bigger and better monopolist. This is clearly, to date, the Government's favoured and favourite monopolist. Its policy is driven entirely by the pressures that derive from the Australian Telecommunications Employees Association, the Public Service unions, the anti-privateers and the left wing of Caucus, all of whom take the view that Telecom can do no wrong and that indeed it needs all the protection it ought reasonably to have. What we now have in this country is probably the most cosseted and protected telecommunications environment in the Western world. I am not sure whether Senator Cook is up with developments overseas, but the fact of the matter is that even conservative Europe is moving very much away from the sort of regulated and protective environment that has been in place for many years. We are alone; we are going backwards.

TALK.START.PARA: —I just had a thought that it could be accurately said that Telecom unions thought Telecom could do no wrong. I think there is empirical evidence to suggest quite the contrary.

—They certainly have vigorous disagreements with Telecom, in terms of wages and conditions, but they are as one in supporting the effort, sometimes against the inclinations of Telecom, to maintain and expand the monopoly. Classic examples of that are the first phone monopoly and the cellular mobile telephone services which Telecom was prepared to surrender to the task force in 1987-88. Senator Evans was prepared to concede this but the Caucus Telecom liaison committee-the monopoly protection society-weighed in very heavily, with two out of three members, Roger Price and John Saunderson being former Telecom employees. The inevitable outcome was that not only did Telecom retain what are now called reserve services but they have actually been expanded. We are very much concerned about the results of all of that.
—At least they had real jobs once.

—We are not ideologically obsessed, as perhaps Senator Powell might believe. We are interested in consumer value for money and we believe that there are tremendous opportunities not only to reduce prices about also to increase quality of service. That will come about from further and better competition in these areas and not by any possible mergers between what are currently two very big and powerful monopolies. I do not want to say anything more than that.

SPEECH.PARA: In terms of the costing, as Senator Panizza pointed out, it is said that there will be estimated net savings in the financial year of approximately $350,000. It might be helpful to know how that figure is arrived at because 75 per cent of $16,000 multiplied by $60 comes out at about $720,000. There may well be other offsets that are not readily apparent and I would certainly be interested if the Minister could provide a better than ballpark figure in that regard.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —In addressing the Transport and Communications Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) I will be brief. Most of my remarks will relate to the communications sections of this legislation. I note that part of the Bill is to amend the Motor Vehicle Standards Act 1989. I have had a great deal to do with that Act, having called for that legislation to address the problem of the import of substandard vehicles. That legislation did come forward very quickly from the Minister for Land Transport and Shipping (Mr Robert Brown). The Australian Democrats supported the legislation and now we have some tidying up amendments to it. One of the amendments in this Bill concerns ministerial discretion. Since the passage of the Motor Vehicle Standards Act I have had some representations from people in specialist areas of importing vehicles. While I was not deeply moved by their representations, one does understand that some people have particular interests, although in the case of some of the representations I thought they were more than just hobby and personal interests and were developing into considerable commercial interests, which I felt quite appropriately ought to come under this kind of legislation. I can see that from time to time there would be a need for some further discretion and I am pleased that the Government has come forward with this particular amendment, and indeed with a tidying up in general of that whole exercise.

SPEECH.PARA: In addressing some of the communications issues raised by way of this amending Bill, which is of course an omnibus Bill, including amendments to a number of Acts, I do not want to take up much of the time of the Senate at this stage of proceedings. However, I want to make a couple of general points on behalf of the Australian Democrats.

One of the disappointments of this parliamentary session-indeed, one of the disappointments for us since the election in 1987-has been the lack of substantive action in the area of communications and in particular in broadcasting legislation. Under the previous Minister, Senator Gareth Evans, there was movement and there was promise of more action. However, under that same Minister we saw moves in broadcasting, with which the Democrats strongly disagreed and still do, that led to increased concentration of ownership, particularly in the area of television services while at the same time, I acknowledge, stronger cross-media rules and in the area of radio broadcasting some limitations, which were supported and encouraged by us.

The question of oligopoly ownership in television remains a problem. We now have considerably more problems in that area, generated in the first instance by the carrot that was dangled before the noses of the entrepreneurs in this country with the establishment of networking, which is basically what the range of legislation at that time amounted to, leading to the considerable financial problems that we have in that sector. That shows up starkly the lack of action in that area by this Government. We will be dealing later in this session with some further amending legislation of a very minor kind with regard to the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal. I take the opportunity to express our disappointment that there has not been the action, particularly in the area of broadcasting, that we would like to have seen. It is of particular concern because we now come towards another election, and, if there is a change of government, we would be very concerned that some of the trends which we would prefer not to see will be escalated. For instance, the question of the very survival of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal comes before us in that context.

I just put those remarks on the record. In doing so, I also say, with more direct relationship to this Bill, that we still await the total review of the three telecommunications carriers-Telecom Australia, the Overseas Telecommunications Commission of Australia (OTC) and Aussat Pty Ltd-which was signalled in May 1988 and which clearly is quite urgent. The annual report of Aussat was recently before this chamber. It is of major concern to the Democrats that Aussat has enormous problems. We do not believe that those problems are being met properly. Perhaps we would have achieved more had the review been completed by now.

The Democrats say that the whole story of Aussat is a sorry one. In the early 1980s it was clear to those who wanted to see that Aussat was not going to be a success-at that time it was just an exercise to satisfy the interest of Kerry Packer, in particular, who had views about how we should get into networking. The Government at that time ought to have cut its losses which in 1983 amounted to about $80m. Now we see annual debt problems of hundreds of millions of dollars in Aussat. We are facing a new generation of satellite. We say to this Government now that it should look again at this issue. We have the technological tail driving the broadcasting dog, as Kenneth Davidson said recently in a newspaper article on this issue. It has been the tradition that that is exactly what has happened. When we toss in the odd entrepreneurial spirit who is looking down the track at the interests of a commercial entity, not at the interests of satisfying the needs of the Australian community, let alone concerns about the public purse, we get what really amounts to an unholy mess, a very expensive one at that.

As we have often said and continue to say, the way out of this mess would be, first, not to go ahead with the second generation and to amalgamate Aussat and OTC. We are opposed to the speeding up of the introduction of pay television, using Aussat in the first instance as a kind of crutch for OTC, which it would be in the short term because of the question of economic viability. If and when we have pay television, the optical fibre network which should be in place by the end of this coming decade would be a much more appropriate way to go. In any case, pay television has not been fully investigated. I believe that it is a system which does not have wide support. I am dismayed at the approach being taken by John Saunderson, the Chairman of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure. He seems to be putting forward the introduction of pay television and using various excuses, in particular the provision of public television and diversity in television programming to support that approach. It seems to me that the consumers in Australia have a right to diverse and public community television without having to pay extra for it while the networks gobble up the major and free frequencies. I do not see that that is a valid argument for a quick introduction of pay television.

We do not support any escalation of the push towards pay television. We would much prefer to enshrine a broadly based television system in the mainstream which would be widely owned by a diverse group and which would provide much more diverse programming through ownership provisions and also through strengthening of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal and other measures. Those are the major points that I want to make in this debate. As I say, we welcome many of the tidying up elements of this legislation but we have some fundamental concerns about the basic principles behind government policy and the general inaction in this area over the period that this Government has been in office.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-A number of speakers in this debate have indicated that they will support the Transport and Communications Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1989 and that amendments to the Bills will not be forthcoming. However, all of the speakers expressed reservations or opinions about the conduct of the Government or of the specific government business enterprises covered by this legislation. In the first instance I acknowledge the contribution of Senator John Watson who indicated that although it was his intention to proceed with an amendment he would now not do so. He took the advantage of the speech he made in the second reading debate stage to set out all of his concerns that that amendment would have addressed.

SPEECH.PARA: On behalf of the Government I acknowledge the actions of Senator Watson and take on board his views as expressed in his speech. I will certainly be commending those views to the Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Willis). I thank Senator Watson for not proceeding with the amendment. I do not in any way doubt that his concerns and those of the Opposition are real, and the Government acknowledges that. Many of the other speeches made in the second reading debate stage dealt with matters not specifically addressed in this legislation but were made on the basis that this legislation covers the whole of the `waterfront'-if I might coin a phase-of communications and transport. Therefore, in that very wide purview it is possible to make speeches relating to alive and real political issues or concerns under that broad umbrella and do so without specifically addressing any particular amendments we are seeking to bring forward. I acknowledge that and I do not wish to pursue to a logical conclusion each of the arguments that have been put because that would mean an extraordinarily long reply. We will meet the Opposition and the Australian Democrats as appropriate in forums and in this chamber and debate many of those arguments when the occasion arises in the future.

However, it is incumbent on me to reply to some points that have been made in the debate. It is appropriate that the Government put its views on the record since these matters have been ventilated. The first of those points is the issue of micro-economic reform. Once again, I acknowledge that the main proponent of the debate on micro-economic reform in the second reading debate stage was Senator Watson. It is a field in which I know him to have a considerable personal interest. While often many of the things he puts to the Government are not to our taste, one has to acknowledge that in this area he is an authority, albeit not in a way which we agree with. I acknowledge that, but in Australian economic life one of the most important and significant economic debates is about the degree, the pace and the extent to which micro-economic reform can occur.

There is little difference between the major parties-the coalition and the Government-as to the objective. We all agree that it is important that we obtain efficient, lean, competitive infrastructure for industry development in Australia. The areas in which government attention is needed if Australian industry is to become more competitive include transport, communications and a plethora of other areas. I do not think there is very much difference between us over the objective. There is a considerable difference between us-a difference which distinguishes the philosophies of the major parties-over the means by which we should achieve the desired outcome. It is in the field of that difference that there is real contention between the Government and the Opposition, perhaps appropriately, because it is then for the Australian community to choose which of the methods to reach the goals is the most desirable.

I would argue strongly that the method of resolving contention, conflict and division in the community which the Government has employed, of bringing together all the social partners-be they unions, industry or interested groups-to work with it through a consultative process with the objective of achieving significant and real change, is by far the preferable one. I identify that as being the Government's desire and, indeed, practice across a range of areas in this community-the most shining example being the prices and wages accord. In this way, the Government has been able to work with the community to achieve significant change of durable benefit for Australia. I juxtapose our approach with what I identify as being the Opposition's approach of ignoring-by pretending they do not exist-some of the very thorny difficulties of making changes, which involved structural alterations that put people out of work or change the way in which they do things without taking account of the individual needs and the ordinary dignity of Australian workers.

I do not want to continue with that point unnecessarily, but I think this is really what this debate is about. We can argue about the pace and the extent of the reform that is possible. I point to this Government's record of achieving significant reforms of the financial market and foreign investment guidelines, introducing major tariff reductions, establishing a free market for crude oil in Australia and achieving significant reforms-which I count as micro-economic reforms-in education and training in this country. These reforms have all been undertaken-not without heat and argument-and we have been able to move very constructively down a path of real change which, it appears to me, will be enduring.

I turn to shipping and the waterfront which were referred to in particular by the Opposition. Under the micro-economic reform that we are proposing, the Australian shipping industry has a bright outlook. It is one of the most traditional of Australian industries and is in the process of reconstructing itself. It can be argued that this reform has led workplace restructuring in Australia. More credit-rather than criticism and dispute-needs to be given to the Australian shipping industry for what it has achieved. Those real gains should be acknowledged rather than simply dismissed as if they were always there for the taking.

In 1984 the average crew on a major Australian trading ship was 33. Today it is 27. Next month it will be 25. More importantly, by mid-1992 it will be 21 and, at that level, Australian shipping will match the average crewing levels on Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) ships. Senator Panizza asked why we cannot get to the OECD level. We will, in 1992. By the same benchmark date the most efficient and modern of Australia's ships will have crews of 17 or 18. By 1993 the training regimes will be in place allowing crewing of 14 to 16.

It may be argued that that is not quick enough. But this is an established industry-a strong industry, an industry that has been wrought in the tradition of Australia over many decades-and adjustments are painful and upset practice. We do not shirk from that, but we say that that change is to be obtained sensitively-and, when it is obtained, it will be real and enduring because of that-rather than by forcing, pushing and compelling which, in the event of disputes, will mean that the foundations upon which it is erected are suspect. As a consequence of this, ship owners in Australia have embarked on a major re-equipment program. At the last count, this result in 26 new, modern fuel efficient ships being introduced into the fleet by 1992.
Sitting suspended from 12.45 to 2 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Is it the case that the only eastern European head of state to visit Australia during the Hawke Government's term of office has been President Ceausescu of Romania? Was Ceausescu not accorded the honour by the Government of being the first head of state to visit Australia during our bicentennial year? Is it not also the case that the Ceausescu visit took place shortly after similar government-supported violence in Brasov, Transylvania, somewhat similar to the violence that we have become aware of in the last couple of days? Will the Minister explain what sort of message he believes the Government is communicating to such tyrannical regimes by its hosting of such visits?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not entirely familiar with the history behind the President of Romania visiting Australia. My recollection-and it is only a recollection; I have not checked it-is that the indication of an invitation to the President came at about the time of the Los Angeles Olympics, or before then, when the Romanians were the flavour of the month because they broke the eastern boycott. I think that might go back to the Fraser Government's time in office. Senator Hill asked me whether the Australian Government will respond. At this point, I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a press release issued by Minister Duffy.

ANSWER.PARA: The Australian Government today expressed its shock and outrage at the violent suppression of protest in the Transylvanian town of Timisoara on 16 December.

The Minister for Trade Negotiations and Acting Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, Michael Duffy, said Australia stood ready to join with other countries in making a joint approach to the Romanian authorities.
``Australia's protest has been formally conveyed to the Romanian Government,'' he said.
``We are also discussing the problem in other capitals in both the East and the West, to determine whether there is the international will to make a concerted protest to the Romanian Government.''

Mr Duffy said the incident in Timisoara demonstrated the lengths the Romanian authorities will go to in their attempts to maintain their totalitarian control over the country. According to eye witness reports, Romanian troops fired on unarmed demonstrators.
``We do not have an accurate picture of the situation but we understand that deaths and casualties number in the hundreds and perhaps in the thousands,'' Mr Duffy said.

Australia has been a consistent critic of the human rights record of the Ceausescu regime. At the last session of the United Nations Commission on Human Rights, Australia co-sponsored the Resolution which expressed concern at human rights abuses in Romania and appointed a Special Rapporteur to investigate the situation in Romania and in particular the campaign of forced assimilation of Romania's ethnic minorities.

The Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, Senator Gareth Evans, currently visiting East Europe, made Australia's views clear in contrasting the reforms taking place elsewhere in East Europe with the bloody suppression of protest in Romania.

I will go on to give some background information. Popular discontent has begun to boil over in Romania, one of the last bastions of hard line communism. On the weekend of 16 and 17 December, crowds of mostly ethnic Hungarian youths gathered in the Transylvanian town of Timisoara to prevent the deportation of a local priest known for his criticism of the Ceausescu regime. The crowd soon turned into a huge demonstration of between 5,000 to 10,000 people shouting anti-government slogans and denouncing President Ceausescu's repressive Stalinist regime. This is the first demonstration since the Brasov demonstrations in November 1987.

The demonstration turned violent when police brought in armoured personnel carriers and used water-cannons to disperse the crowd. Reports state that shots were heard and the military were seen to be carrying fixed bayonets. Shop windows were broken and fire bombs were thrown during the running battle with security forces through the town. The unconfirmed death toll could go as high as 400. Many injuries and arrests have been reported, although many demonstrators would not have had their injuries tended in public hospitals, fearing further intimidation. The town is now sealed off and security forces are in control of Timisoara. It appears that many other parts of the country are under martial law as well. Romania has also closed its borders with Yugoslavia, Hungary and Bulgaria.

While other countries of eastern Europe are shedding their totalitarian systems, Romania appears to be intensifying its repression of the population in the vain hope that it will stifle dissent. In the past, even Romanians resident in Australia have, out of concern for their relatives back home, been careful not to publicly denounce the President of Romania. The Romanian people, cowered by their fear for so long, cannot be repressed indefinitely. Importantly, eastern European countries such as Poland, the German Democratic Republic and Hungary are at the fore by joining the West in their condemnation of the brutal force used against Romanian people.

Senator Evans, in Berlin yesterday, stated that any government which can cling to office only by shooting and beating its own people has lost all claim to moral authority. He added that Australia has been a long-standing critic of Romania's human rights abuses. Senator Evans also instructed the Australian Embassy in Belgrade to find out exactly what happened in Timisoara and to register with the Romanian authorities Australia's expectation that the Romanian Government avoid violence and honour its international human rights commitments. I am not sure whether Senator Hill has a copy of the press release issued today.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I appreciate the Minister's answer but I do invite him to answer the original question, which was really that, in the circumstances where the Government was aware that Ceausescu was carrying out such abhorrent practices as occurred in Brasov shortly before he visited Australia, does the Government not agree that hosting such visits in Australia, in those circumstances, only gives implied comfort to the abhorrent practices of those such as Ceausescu?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, determining these matters with hindsight or with foresight is a difficult question. I know that both I and many others did not attend any of those functions because of our views on the President of Romania. I did not put `regret' on my invitation; I put `reject'. However, as I understand it-and as I have said, I have not been fully briefed on this-the invitation to that particular person goes back over many years to when the Opposition could not have seen with foresight that in the period of the Los Angeles Olympics, or preceding that, Romania would take the course of events which it has currently taken. At that stage, there was the general view-maybe a view which was not correct-that it was one of the lesser repressive regimes in eastern Europe at that stage. Clearly, with hindsight, the Opposition may well argue that it was not the case. But many others at the time of the Los Angeles Olympics argued that the Romanians had shown some courage in standing up to the Soviet Union. Whether that was a correct analysis, I am not sure. If I can find out the exact details of when the invitation was issued, and how many prior invitations may have been issued, I will give the honourable senator the information.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ABORIGINAL AND TORRES STRAIT ISLANDER COMMISSION

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs advise the Senate of the latest developments in the establishment of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Collins for his question and I am sure that honourable senators would be wanting to know, as we move into the 1990s, how the new structures are being put in place, on the one hand, in order to attempt to strike a balance between the very real and legitimate aspirations of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people to create their own future and shape their own destiny within our Australian society and, on the other hand so, that this Parliament might accept its responsibility to the general Australian community for the expenditure of the moneys that are involved in ensuring this creation of their own future by the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. Indeed, the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission is an expression of that balance, which I believe this Government got right after many years of very arduous and long drawn out debate.

ANSWER.PARA: We are now in a position where the Australian people have enabled themselves to put in place a structure which will help remedy some of the injustices which currently plague the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples as being amongst the most disadvantaged in Australian society.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Stone apparently does not agree that they are amongst the most disadvantaged in Australian society. I was speaking of current injustices, Senator; I was not speaking of any inherited guilt idea, such as was spoken of during the debate. I am talking about current injustices.
—I rise on a point of order, Mr President. I do so in part because the Minister, I think, has misunderstood the interjections that he has been getting.
—What a point of order!

—It is very relevant because the Minister is simply not addressing himself to the question that Senator Collins has asked him. We might all be interested to know what progress has been made with respect to the establishment of the Commission, the legislation for which we laboured over long and hard in this chamber. I simply ask the Minister not to give us arguments about why something needs to be done with which we all agree, but rather to tell us what Senator Collins has asked; that is, what has been done with respect to the establishment of the Commission. That is my point of order-relevance.
—I remind the Minister to take notice of the relevance of the question he was asked by Senator Collins.

—Yes, Mr President. I was simply trying to put into perspective the current injustices which we believe will be remedied by the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission. It is coming into place, Senator Stone will be delighted to know, on 5 March 1990. I believe that it will mark a new era in the administration of Aboriginal Affairs in this country. The Commission will be headed by Lois O'Donoghue and the new Chief Executive Officer will be Mr Bill Gray. I am quite sure that all senators around the chamber are well aware of the personalities of those two persons. Lois O'Donoghue is currently the chairperson of the Aboriginal Development Commission. She has a long involvement with Aboriginal people over many years. Her experience in Aboriginal affairs administration and her vast knowledge of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities across the country make her well qualified to oversee the major changes that will occur under ATSIC.

ANSWER.PARA: Mr Bill Gray is currently Secretary to the Department of Aboriginal Affairs and has served in that portfolio under both Labor and Liberal Ministers. He has occupied the position as Secretary during a very difficult period and the administrative and managerial skills he has displayed during that time are valuable qualifications for his new position as Chief Executive Officer. —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Has the Government initiated a review of Australia's relations with Chile as a result of the recent return to elected government in that country? In particular, has the Government examined those elements of the relationship which existed in 1973 but which have, quite properly, been in abeyance since that time-for example, academic exchanges and visits by training vessels, et cetera?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —Before going to the specific point of Senator McMullan's question, I should reiterate that the Australian Government warmly congratulates Mr Aylwin on his historic victory in the Chilean presidential elections held on 14 December. Voter participation of over 90 per cent and Mr Aylwin's marginal victory of 55 per cent, to the next candidate's 29 per cent, bear witness to the hunger for democracy after 16 years of authoritarian military rule in Chile. That rule has long been opposed by many in Australia and the Hawke Government has been active in the United Nations, as well as through its official representatives in Chile, in supporting the full restoration of democratic and human rights in Chile. The restoration of democracy in Chile is not yet absolute as General Pinochet has entrenched himself as Army commander for another eight years. While the centre left coalition appears to have won 72 of the 120 seats in the Chamber of Deputies-that is the lower House-and about 22 of the 38 elected senators, it will be deprived of a majority in the Senate by the fact that nine senators are to be appointed by the outgoing Pinochet regime rather than elected. In this context the Australian Government renews its call for all Chileans to continue to work actively and in a spirit of compromise to enable a complete return to democracy at the earliest possible date.

ANSWER.PARA: Australia looks forward very much to working with the government to be led by President-Elect Aylwin in strengthening the healthy bilateral relations between the two countries and in cooperation on matters of mutual interest, including the Cairns Group and Antarctica. The Government will be examining other ways in which bilateral relations can be broadened and strengthened in line with the progressive restoration of democracy in Chile. Elements such as those mentioned by Senator McMullan will certainly be looked at sympathetically in the context and in the light of resources available. The Government will be giving attention to this matter in the period leading up to the formal inauguration of the Aylwin Government on 11 March next year and, thereafter, in our discussions with the new Chilean authorities.

—Can the Minister for Justice tell the Senate what changes there will be in the sentencing of Federal offenders in Queensland now that that State has finally elected an enlightened Labor Government?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is an important matter. It gives me great pleasure to speak of this, and I do so in the context of congratulating the Labor Government in Queensland on its magnificent victory. Last Sunday I met with the new Queensland Attorney-General, Mr Deane Wells-he will be well known to members of this chamber having been a former member of the House of Representatives-to discuss a matter of the utmost importance to ensuring a fair national sentencing scheme for those convicted of Federal offences. The issue was the availability of community service orders to Federal offenders convicted in Queensland. As a result of our discussions I can report that the Commonwealth and Queensland governments have agreed on a new system of sentencing options which will allow people who offend against Federal laws to be given community service orders as a penalty.

ANSWER.PARA: One of the principal benefits of the new agreement will be to ensure that, where appropriate, the families of people who commit social security offences do not suffer because of the conviction, particularly of a mother. Community service orders require offenders to devote a specified number of hours to community work. In Queensland such work includes person to person work, such as reading to the elderly, or doing gardening and repairs for pensioners, group projects, such as building school playground equipment, working for the disabled and environmental projects, such as clean-ups and reafforestation schemes.

Community service orders are a particularly effective penalty in certain circumstances, especially where the offender cannot afford a fine and imprisonment is not a suitable punishment. Importantly, this community-based option stops short of the deprivation of liberty and loss of income and family contact involved in a prison sentence. This Parliament legislated in 1982 to make community service orders an available sentencing option for Federal offenders. Until now, however, we have been unable to reach an agreement with the Queensland Government that would entitle Federal offenders to be given such a punishment when convicted in Queensland. This has meant that there were insufficient alternatives to imprisonment for Federal offenders appearing before Queensland courts charged with what were quite often minor fraud offences. This absence of community-based sentencing options for Federal offenders principally affected social security offenders, particularly women with children. Tragically, in some cases, it caused mothers to be separated from their children, making innocent children themselves the victims. Obviously the Commonwealth cannot condone deliberate and repeated defrauding of the social security system. However, equally, I have been anxious to ensure that the suffering of families is not out of proportion to the offence. Greater use of community service orders makes sense in every way.

On the latest available Queensland figures, the average annual cost of administering a community service order in that State is less than $750 compared to almost $30,000 for keeping a person in prison for a year. The successful negotiation of this agreement with the new Queensland Government follows similar agreements with other States and Territories in 1986 and with the new Tasmanian Labor Government within a couple of weeks of its coming to office in late winter this year. New South Wales is now the only State not a party to the scheme. I congratulate the Queensland Attorney-General, Mr Wells, and his Government on taking such prompt action. I also take the opportunity to send a cheerio and a Christmas greeting to Mr Wells and his wife, Jane, who had a baby on Sunday morning.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer him to the recent ruling of the Federal Court that members of local government councils are not employees for the purposes of the Income Tax Assessment Act, and the consequent acknowledgment by the Australian Government Solicitor, on behalf of the Commissioner of Taxation, that income tax ruling MT2035 would be withdrawn. The effect of the Federal Court order is that councils are not required to make pay as you earn (PAYE) contributions in respect of allowances paid to elected members and fringe benefit tax (FBT) returns are not required to be lodged in respect of those allowances paid to elected members. Has income tax ruling MT2035 been withdrawn? If so, when was the announcement made? If not, will the Government be directing the Commissioner of Taxation to withdraw the ruling? Will the Government be repaying to local government bodies all PAYE tax collected this financial year and fringe benefits tax contributions paid since the date of the ruling? Or, is the Government considering introducing legislation to avoid the Federal Court ruling? If so, will that legislation be retrospective?

—I have just seen a note from the Treasurer's office which names tax ruling 2035. I do not intend to read out the whole of the note as it is rather long. However, I will take out the most relevant points. The Federal Court, as Senator Bishop has already said, declared that local government elected members were not deemed to be employees for purposes of taxation. I understand from the Treasury minute that the taxation ruling was withdrawn in the same month as a result of that decision. The Government endorses that decision because it recognises the largely voluntary nature of the service most local government elected members provide their communities. I also understand that with the exception of a relatively small number of elected members in Queensland who are paid salaries determined by the individual councils concerned, the remaining 9,000 or so local government elected members in the rest of Australia receive only a small allowance, generally less than $2,000, in lieu of their civic duties.

—I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. The salient point of the question was: What was the date of the announcement of the withdrawing of the ruling? The most significant part of the question is: Is the Government going to return PAYE deductions that have been paid as and from the beginning of this financial year and all FBT payments? Or, is the Government considering introducing legislation to overturn the Federal Court ruling and making it retrospective?
—I do not know the date on which the ruling was withdrawn. I will get that from the Treasurer-and likewise the other questions. I knew nothing about this issue at all until the question was asked.

—I address my question to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. The Minister has twice reported to the Senate on the plight of the sole surviving Norfolk Island boobook owl and attempts to re-establish owls on the island. Without implying that the Minister has in any way influenced events, can the Minister inform the Senate on the success of the dalliance between this owl and two male New Zealand boobooks imported to the island in September 1987?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —They were not quite boobooks that came from New Zealand; they were a subspecies. They are very close to boobooks. They are called mopokes-pronounced `moreporks'.
—What do they sound like? What is their call?

—`Morepork' is the sound of the call. That is why they are called `moreporks' but the word is spelt `mopokes'. I will not imitate the call lest the females come running. As the Senate would recall, there was a lone female called Miamiti who was named after Fletcher Christian's lover with whom he eloped from Tahiti and who was, apparently, prolific. Last year we put two more mopokes onto the island. I am happy to report that two chicks have now been hatched and Miamiti is smiling.
—What do they look like?

—I am not going to discuss the way they look but photographs are available in my office. The Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service put out some 23 nesting boxes around the island. Last year a feather was sighted in one of them and this caused great excitement-but all to no avail. Later an egg was found but Miamiti abandoned it. We sent two onto the island, and apparently the father is the young one. We sent a five-year-old which had successfully raised a family with a 12-year-old. He piked out of it but an 18-month-old, called Tintola, which means darling, has done the trick, evidently, and two chicks have now been born. We should not get too excited. The mortality rate of these owls is 60 per cent in their first year.
—This is very exciting.
—I knew Senator Tate was getting excited. I urge him to calm down. I will have to report further. Things on Norfolk, as least for the owls, are looking up.

—I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. I cannot allow this to go past. In November 1987 in this place the Minister said some very uncomplimentary things about New Zealanders. He wondered why importing a New Zealander would make anyone happy, let alone a boobook owl. He also implied that New Zealanders were all talk and no action. Does the Minister still hold to these views?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —I recall the statement. I suppose I must unreservedly withdraw it. Mind you, it is only some weeks since the National Parks and Wildlife Service reported that as far as these owls were concerned it had done a check on Miamiti. In one of the three measurements that are important it actually thought that Miamiti may have been a very big he. Had that been the case I would not have taken anything off what I said about New Zealanders but, given that it is wrong, I unreservedly withdraw any insult to the pride of New Zealand and I hope more of them go to Norfolk Island.

—Has the Minister for Finance seen Richard Farmer's column in today's Australian in which he canvasses options to neutralise the capacity of the Australian Democrats and other minor groups in the Senate to interfere with money Bills? Has the Government ever considered Mr Farmer's proposal that the major parties establish a code of behaviour which would prevent them from opposing in the Senate the key elements of the legislation of whichever party was in government?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen the article. The basic proposition which Richard Farmer puts up is, I believe, inarguable, that is, that the Senate makes it extremely difficult for any government to run responsible fiscal policy. There have been hundreds of occasions since this Government has been in office when the Liberal Party has opposed savings measures or obstructed tax legislation which required people to pay their fair share of tax. I hasten to add that the Liberals have been aided in their opposition by the National Party, usually the Democrats and sometimes some of the other motley so-called Independents that we have in the Senate.
—Senator Harradine.

—Senator Harradine is certainly one of those who, when his vote was not critical on a piece of tax legislation, voted for it and, when his vote was critical a year later, voted against exactly the same piece of legislation. That is the sort of thing that a government has to put up with when the Senate is constituted as it is and behaves as it does. However, Mr Farmer's suggestion that there should be a convention, to which both the major parties subscribe, that financial legislation will not be obstructed is extremely naive. The events of 1975 demonstrated that no convention is regarded as sacrosanct by an opportunistic, power hungry Liberal-National Party.

ANSWER.PARA: Some commentators have recently expressed shock and outrage at Senator Haines's announcement that the Australian Democrats, should there be a coalition government, would block savings measures and also block the watering down-the effective repeal-of the capital gains tax. The same commentators do not seem to have noticed that the Democrats have been doing that to this Government for years. Ever since we have been in office, the Democrats have been doing precisely that. So I do not see why there should be so much outrage at the Democrats saying that they will continue to do that under a coalition government-continue to do what they have been doing for years under a Labor Government.

However, one important distinction between what Senator Haines said a couple of weeks ago and what the Democrats have done over the last 6 1/2 years is that the Democrats' proposal would actually give a coalition government, should there be one, an extra $450m in revenue. Of course, that would have the opposite effect on the Budget bottom line of everything else that the Democrats have done to this Government in the last 6 1/2 years. Indeed, the $450m extra revenue would go a long way towards plugging the $830m-odd black hole in the Opposition's costings in its Economic Action Plan. The final point is that we will see again, before the end of this week, whether the Senate will allow this Government to implement its taxation revenue policies or whether it will try to continue to block the collection of $500m in this financial year.

—My question is directed to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories and it relates to World Heritage listings. Is the Minister aware of the anti-World Heritage propaganda that has been circulated widely throughout the Shark Bay community in Western Australia? Is the Minister also aware that `Man and the Biosphere', another United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation conservation program, is being promoted in the Shark Bay area? As the Minister is aware, there are a number of conservation programs possible for Shark Bay-World Heritage, `Man and the Biosphere', both World Heritage and `Man and the Biosphere', or a State government managed national park and marine park. Which of these does the Minister consider would offer the best protection and management for the Shark Bay area? If he believes that the World Heritage program offers the best protection for Shark Bay, does he therefore agree that some positive action needs to be undertaken in the Shark Bay community and with Western Australian Government departments and Ministers by the World Heritage department of the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories to rectify this anti-World Heritage propaganda?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —I recall that my visit to Shark Bay last year was the only time that I had encountered anywhere in Australia a League of Rights campaign and, indeed, a couple of actual real live breathing League of Rights people. Those people have spread some pretty extraordinary propaganda.
—Senator Boswell has woken up to them.

—Senator Boswell woke up to them a long time ago. Senator Panizza still has a way to go before he does. Unfortunately, a number of politicians in Western Australia, in particular from the Liberal Party-and this is not a National bagging day; they come from the Liberal Party-have egged on those League of Rights people with some of the more stupid propaganda. In fact, it goes to that great line about the one world government of which we are apparently a party with all the nasty socialists. I do not know what happens now that the wall is breaking down, but I have never taken that propaganda too seriously. Unfortunately, Senator Vallentine, there are a number of people in the area who continue to spread it. I know that Minister Pearce from the Western Australian Government has been talking to them on many visits that he has made to the area. From the reports I have received, I think the people of Shark Bay and its surrounding areas are much more aware of the truth of these matters than they were a year ago. Of course, that does not mean that the community accepts that the World Heritage program is the right way for us to proceed.

ANSWER.PARA: I do not favour the `Man and the Biosphere' program as the best way of ensuring the future protection of Shark Bay. I have always favoured the World Heritage program and continue to do so. I have had a number of discussions with the Western Australian Government, which I hope will eventually lead to the listing of Shark Bay. I would like to report to Senator Vallentine that I have its agreement, but I do not. Nonetheless, the talks are continuing. I think the Western Australian objection is to a concern that sovereignty over the area will be taken away from it and from the local people. I am encouraged by the management plan the Western Australian Government has put out for Shark Bay. If we were to list this area for World Heritage, that management plan would form the basis of the way in which we would proceed.

If there was to be any move towards this, though, there would need to be a long discussion about the possible boundaries of the area. I have never accepted the original boundaries suggested by conservation organisations as being all that wise because they are so broad that they take in areas of pastoral land which are so degraded as to concern me as to whether they are worthy of being put in. Fortunately, the Western Australian Government is now buying some of that land and, hopefully, that will mean that some developments which could have occurred on the edges and fringes of Shark Bay will now not happen. As far as the future of the area is concerned, I believe that in terms of both mining and tourism the management plan should provide the basis for an orderly future development which will not damage the values of Shark Bay. Whether one talks of seagrass beds, dolphins, stromatolites or whatever else, at Shark Bay World Heritage values abound.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Justice. Commander Jim Allen, who heads the Australian Federal Police general and government fraud investigations, recently was reported as saying that `Australia needed specific legislation with stiff penalties to combat procurement fraud along United States lines, where offenders faced up to 10 years gaol and companies $1m fines as well as being banned from government contracts'. In view of the importance of this matter, is the Australian Government proposing to introduce such legislation? If so, when? If not, why not?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —In relation to the new role being undertaken by the Australian Federal Police as the premier law enforcement investigative agency Australiawide, there has been a recognition that it needs to concern itself not only with drug trafficking, which perhaps gets most media attention, but also with fraud against the Commonwealth. In combating major fraud against the Commonwealth there are special personnel trained and dedicated to that task. Senator Newman has mentioned one of the key personnel in that area. Indeed, there have been extremely fruitful discussions between the Minister for Defence, Mr Kim Beazley, and myself leading to the appointment within the Department of Defence-or the secondment to it; I do not know the exact phrase-of Australian Federal Police personnel to assist in combating the type of fraud to which she has pointed. One would hope that the preventative strategies, which are absolutely essential, are in place in a way which prevents the rise of fraudulent activity so that temptation is not in place so as to lead weak or corruptible people to succumb to that temptation.

ANSWER.PARA: One may also say in relation to Commonwealth fraud that those officials of the Commonwealth who are engaged in such fraud are now on notice from this Parliament, a notice which was given very recently, that they will forfeit their superannuation entitlements. The community will refuse to pay to them those entitlements which otherwise they and their families would be able to obtain on leaving the Commonwealth Public Service. Between the Parliament and the Government, as represented particularly in the activities of the Australian Federal Police, one will see greater activity in relation to fraudulent activity of the sort mentioned.

In discussions with Peter Faris-I think Senator Hill and other members of the Joint Parliamentary Committee on the National Crime Authority would confirm this-it was clear that there is a very firm intention on the part of the National Crime Authority to dedicate more of its activities to the combating of fraud as opposed to acting as a super drug force throughout Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank Senator Tate for his interesting discursion on the subject, but that really was not what I asked. Perhaps I need to remind him. I asked him whether the Australian Government was intending to introduce the public recommendation from Commander Jim Allen about the need for specific legislation with stiff penalties, and if not, why not? In the light of the recognition which the Minister has given to the fact that Commander Allen is such an expert and is leading the fight against fraud, what is the Government planning to do about this recommendation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am always willing and happy to look at any recommendation as to more specific areas of offences that could be created in relation to fraudulent activities against the Commonwealth. But I believe that the Crimes Act sufficiently provides a mechanism by which we can seek to combat the sort of fraudulent activity to which Senator Newman is referring. I believe that there is also, I think under Sir Harry Gibbs, a review of the penalties that might attach to Commonwealth offences. That might lead to an increase in or a rationalisation of the penalties that ought to be imposed in respect of procurement fraud.

ANSWER.PARA: It was only yesterday in the Senate that the chamber refused to enable the Australian Federal Police to use listening devices in relation to fraudulent activity against the Commonwealth. If Senator Newman is really concerned about fraudulent activity against the Commonwealth, she was in a position yesterday to persuade her colleagues to enable the use of listening devices to enable the combating of that fraudulent activity. After all, investigation is the first step to securing a conviction in the courts and the imposition of the penalties Senator Newman is seeking.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Foreman for his question on this particularly important issue. It continues his interest in matters to do with the criminal justice system. Many honourable senators would have read in the Sydney Morning Herald some months ago an article about the Clemenger report-the Silent Majority Part II-which showed that there was a great deal of public disquiet and concern in Australia today about the issues relating to crime and punishment. That survey sought to discover just what Australians are worried about today. Fourth in the list of the top 40 concerns was the early release of criminals from prison. I am pleased to say, however, that this is a concern that the Government has been able to respond to.

ANSWER.PARA: With the passage of legislation through the Senate yesterday the fraud on the public, whereby judges set minimum terms which bear no relationship to the actual time spent in prison, will happen no more. Once the legislation commences operation, the State remissions that come off the non-parole period will no longer be available to eat away at the minimum sentences of Federal offenders. The early release of prisoners brought about by such remissions will not occur. Instead, a sentence will mean what it says. The judge will set a prison term and a parole period to follow that term and the prisoner will remain in prison for the period set by the judge. Obviously, only Federal offenders are affected by the new legislation-persons who have been convicted of a crime against Federal law such as drug importation or fraud against the Commonwealth. For any current Federal prisoners, I point out that the legislation is not retrospective so it will not affect their sentences. As honourable senators will know, there are no Federal prisons. The Federal Government uses State courts to try and State prisons to incarcerate those sentenced to a term of imprisonment.

The problem has been that until now a Federal prisoner has been treated in the same way as would be a State prisoner sentenced to the same term-that is, the remissions and parole systems of the relevant jurisdictions applied. This meant that it was extremely difficult to ensure consistency in the sentencing of Federal offenders as the systems differ in every jurisdiction. It also meant that in those States which grant remissions off the non-parole period, it was impossible for the public to know just how long a Federal offender would spend in prison. It meant that every week I would have to deal with numerous cases where the date of the prisoner's release bore no relationship to the minimum term set by the judge. One recent example that comes to mind is of a Federal prisoner who received a 15-year maximum sentence for conspiracy to import heroin. The prisoner was given a five-year minimum term but, with State remissions, spent only three years and one month of his sentence in prison.

Under the new legislation, any State remissions that come off the non-parole period will no longer be available to eat away at the minimum sentences of Federal offenders. There will be certainty in the sentencing of Federal offenders. Certainty does not mean longer sentences since mechanisms have been built into the legislation to ensure that judges adjust the prison part of a sentence to take account of the fact that it will no longer be reduced by remissions. The punishment of imprisonment will remain the punishment of last resort. What the certainty of the new regime means is that if an offender is consigned to that last resort, he or she will stay in it for the period set by the judge. What is announced in court will be carried into effect and everyone-the prisoner, the judge and the public-will know that what is announced in court will be carried into effect.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate-
1. condemns the slaughter by the Romanian Government of a number of its own people who were demonstrating for democracy and increased freedom;

2. calls upon the Romanian Government to adhere to the internationally accepted standards of human rights and to comply with the Helsinki Accords and other international agreements to which Romania is a party; and
3. urges the international community to join in protest to demonstrate that such gross abuses of human rights will not be tolerated by civilised societies.

The news emanating from Romania today is deeply distressing. Another regime has turned its guns on its people rather than seek to understand the reasons leading to popular disaffection. The reports coming from Romania are still scanty, but enough is known to condemn yet again the repressive regime of the Ceausescu family. The tide of social change and history will ultimately vindicate and liberate the people of Romania but, in the meantime, through this motion, we join the wider international community in expressing our revulsion at the recent events.

Romania, through its reform resistance leadership, is a state that has defied the changes occurring in Poland, Hungary, East Germany and Czechoslovakia. It is a state where people just try to survive; a state where basic human rights are abused and where dissent is crushed. It is therefore even more important for outside voices to proclaim the Romanians' cause. Contrary to the Romanian Government's official report to the United Nations Human Rights Committee, submitted in January 1988, the Romanian Government still violates other basic human rights of its citizens. The right to leave is not safeguarded in Romanian law. Thousands of Romanians wishing to leave that country are not permitted to do so. The rights of freedom of thought, conscience and religion are daily violated. The persecution and forced Romanisation of some minority groups in Romania have intensified. Free expression is not at all tolerated. Independent labour unions are prohibited. Indeed, the technique of repression is actually facilitated by the Romanian legal system-a system that deviates from the standards and requirements of international covenants. The situation is so bad that even ecology in Romania is not allowed to be commented on. A recent report dealing with environmental issues had to be smuggled to the West through an underground group.

In 1988 President Ceausescu restarted a rural resettlement program, meant to serve as a model for the eventual social engineering of the entire nation. This obscene program is to see 7,000 of the country's 13,000 villages levelled by 1995. The main victims of this resettlement policy are the Hungarian and German ethnic minorities, as well as gypsies, the Ukrainians, Serbs and Turks, whose families have lived in Transylvania and other parts of Romania for centuries.

This forced assimilation constitutes a violation of the International Covenants on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights and on Civil and Political Rights, in particular those articles which guarantee to ethnic and linguistic minorities the continuation of their own cultural life and the right to a free choice of residence. Indeed, the Government flagrantly ignores these obligations and commitments of the international accords, in particular the Helsinki final act. Indeed, one law of Romania-decree 408-states that all conversations with foreigners must be reported to the authorities within 24 hours.

Amnesty International and the United States Department of State report on human rights all too graphically list the disappearances, maltreatments and tortures endemic to life in Romania. It is a State where persons accused of acting against the socialist order can still be committed to psychiatric institutions as a method of punishment. I recently read a quote attributed to the First Secretary of the Ilfou Party Committee-the region being resettled outside Bucharest. He said that the program of resettlement is designed to `mould the new communist man' by changing his present way of thinking, behaviour, customs, practices and habits. Almost everywhere else in eastern Europe the new communist man has shown what he thinks of communism. With the passing of this motion we, as a Parliament, both send and lend our support to the long-suffering people of Romania.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Government I join with Senator Hill in supporting this motion relating to the events in Romania. As has been highlighted in the press here, a popular discontent has begun to boil over in Romania. This is the first time that that has happened since 1987, when the Brasov riots took place. I do not want to go to the details of the current dissent, about which reports are not entirely satisfactory. But it is quite clear that a very severe situation exists there. A very repressive regime of police and army activity has been put into place. All the signs of a totalitarian country are being displayed in what is now happening in Romania.

SPEECH.PARA: Today in Question Time Senator Hill asked a question of Minister Robert Ray representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade about events in Romania. In answering part of that question, Senator Ray tabled a statement issued today by Mr Duffy, the Acting Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, to which I can add not very much by way of my comments in the Senate.

The events in Romania are really, in a sense, very much highlighted by the enormous changes which have taken place in other regimes in eastern Europe in the past few years. For example, when the invitation was issued in the mid-1970s to President Ceausescu to come to Australia, the Romanian regime, compared with regimes in other parts of eastern Europe, did not seem particularly bad. In fact, it seemed reasonably and comparatively good. There have been such enormous changes in these other countries where, suppressed though it has been, there has probably been a stronger liberal dissident tradition than in Romania. The changes have been so enormous that they particularly draw attention to the monstrosity of the regime which remains in place in Romania.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is the status of Lang Hancock's iron ore contract with Romania?
—I do not know. I do know that Lang Hancock entertained Romanian delegations. I think that President Ceausescu, during his visit here, went to Western Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: The Romanian authorities were insistent upon accepting the invitation for President Ceausescu to visit Australia in 1988 for the bicentennial year, even though it had been issued many years before. It is probably fair to say that he wanted to be treated as a head of state, like the other heads of state who had been particularly invited to Australia for the event. Though I am not at liberty to say some of the things that I learned in the course of President Ceausescu's visit-not in public anyway-the rigidity and closed-minded nature of the regime was amply displayed by the President during his visit.

There are only a couple of other points that I will make. For the first time, eastern European regimes, who two years ago were protesting against events in Romania, have joined with the other countries of the traditional Western world in condemning what has recently taken place in Romania. The Romanian authorities do not have many friends either in eastern or western Europe or in the other democracies of the world. Poland, the German Democratic Republic and Hungary are at the fore in joining the West in their condemnation of the force used against the Romanian people.

As Senator Ray said at Question Time, Senator Gareth Evans has registered Australia's horror at the events and has asked the Romanian Government to avoid violence and to honour its international human rights commitments. The Romanian Consulate-General in Sydney has been informed today of Australia's views. Australia's voice is being added to the protest of other countries. The problem is also being discussed in other capitals-both East and West-to determine whether there is the international will to make a concerted protest to the Romanian Government.

Australia has been a consistent critic of the human rights record of the Ceausescu regime. At the last session of the United Nations Commission on Human Rights Australia co-sponsored the resolution which expressed concern at human rights abuses in Romania and appointed a special rapporteur to investigate the situation in Romania and, in particular, the campaign of forced assimilation of Romania's ethnic minorities, to which Senator Hill referred in his remarks. The Australian Government stands ready to play its part in any further action which is determined by the European or international community.

In conclusion, I have been present at some of the discussions which took place with President Ceausescu. I am not making any claim in respect of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) but he raised, in my presence, some of the human rights issues in Romania and of all the bicentennial visitors we had to this country, President Ceausescu was the only one with whom the Prime Minister clearly did not get on well.
