TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to associate the Australian Democrats with the remarks that have been made and indicate our support for the motion that has been moved by Senator Hill condemning the Romanian Government for its repression of its own citizens. Last night I had the honour to speak at a function for a delegation from Paris to establish in Australia a branch of the Federation for a Democratic China. Today, Senator Haines, Leader of the Australian Democrats, was the guest speaker at the launch of that Federation in Canberra. I raise that issue because I think the two events-the one we saw in the middle of this year in Tiananmen Square where the regime turned on its own people, and the one which has been reported as occurring in Romania, not only last weekend but over quite some time now, where the Romanian regime is doing the same to its people-probably reflect in some way the advances that have been made elsewhere in the world, to which Senator Button referred. We have become almost blase about the developments in eastern Europe that have occurred with such breathtaking speed. People in the German Democratic Republic are at the forefront of the condemnation of what is happening in Romania, whereas under the previous Honecker regime they would not have entertained such a thought.

SPEECH.PARA: What we have seen in 1989, probably more than in any year since the end of the Second World War, has been a rising up of the people to take control of their own lives and the establishment of democracy in so many countries. The Romanian Government's actions are even more horrific when we compare them with what has occurred in China and, doubtless, what will occur in other countries such as Albania-if we ever hear anything about what happens in that country. It reminds us that the fight for freedom and democracy goes on and the advances that have been made in some parts of the world have yet to be made in others.

One stands in awe of the courage and tenacity of people who want to be free. Where people have stood up against repressive regimes and have won we have applauded and congratulated them. Where people have stood up and lost we have mourned and suffered with them. We know that the human spirit is resilient and tenacious. In 1989 the victories that will be won will be in China, Romania, Albania and the Latin American and Asian countries that still suffer under repressive regimes. We tend to focus on dramatic events-again I suppose that that is part of human nature-but, in the end, continuing day-in and day-out repression is as damaging to the human spirit as is the bullet and the bayonet. In the spirit of the motion moved by Senator Hill we have referred not only to those courageous people in Romania who at least have made this attempt to be free and who undoubtedly will continue to move that way; we have also empathised with all other peoples in countries with repressive regimes and expressed the hope that they, too, will be free and that the next decade will see the finish of something that was started this year. We hope that the sun will shine brightly in the history of the establishment of democracies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the motion moved by Senator Hill to condemn the slaughter by the Romanian Government of its own people while demonstrating for democracy and increased freedom. News of the happenings within Romania have been very sketchy indeed. Of course, we have known for some time that Romania has been under a Stalinist-type dictatorship and that extreme suffering and gross violations of human rights have been occurring daily in that country. SPEECH.PARA: We now have the opportunity of expressing our condemnation by passing this motion in the Senate. But I think we should learn a bit of a lesson now so that we will know what attitude to adopt in respect of other heads of government who want to come here. As we all know, a luncheon was held in the old Parliament House for President Ceausescu and a number of senators and members did not go along to that luncheon. DEBATE.TITLE: REVIEW OF THE AUSTRALIAN NATIONAL PARKS AND WILDLIFE SERVICE

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I commence, Mr Acting Deputy President, by saying that I am very pleased to see that you are in the chair because it allows me to indicate formally that the answer to the question you asked Senator Richardson earlier today was: beetles. You and I both know what Haldane said about the good Lord's inordinate fondness for beetles as the demonstration of why he created so many of them.

I am pleased to speak briefly to the report of the review of the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service (ANPWS) undertaken by Mr Bruce McDonald, a former head of the Department of Sport, Recreation and Tourism. This is an interesting report which I have had the opportunity to scan only briefly since it was tabled. I draw attention to a couple of the recommendations and indicate a preliminary view on a number of those matters which I think are of importance. On page 141 the review recommends:
That the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service be merged into a wider-ranging statutory authority, to be called the Australian Nature Conservation Authority.

That is not a recommendation which I find attractive. Certainly it is one which would not be in accordance with the course of action in this area that an incoming coalition government would seek to undertake. We, in fact, want to strengthen the role of the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service but do not believe that a case is made out for the creation of another statutory authority. That is very much opposed to the general thrust of policies which we are putting forward. We do, however, support the recommendation which appears on page 142 that there should be a revision and consolidation of all Federal nature conservation legislation. At the moment there are an extraordinary number of Acts dealing with aspects of nature conservation which should be consolidated into one significant Federal statute, and we certainly do endorse that. There are two points to which I make reference, both of which endorse significant initiatives already undertaken by the coalition parties in the development of their policy. The report recommends on page 143:
that an expert commercial specialist be engaged to look at the question of charging, merchandising and publicising of the Commonwealth's nature conservation activities.

Cost recovery within the ANPWS is something which is very much put forward at the moment in the coalition parties Economic Action Plan. We are very glad to see that the consultant has understood the capacity which exists for some greater cost recovery to finance the expanded work of the Service, and I welcome that. On page 122 of the report there is a comment by the consultant about the need to improve the handling of certain Commonwealth-State relations aspects of national park administration and World Heritage areas in particular. He draws attention to the fact that Australia really lacks what he describes as `a truly national parks system', that is a system of national parks which is truly a national system, as distinct from having national parks that simply have those titles because some State or local government authority has chosen to call them national parks.

In the statement issued by the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Peacock, the Leader of the National Party of Australia, Mr Blunt, and me in July of this year we outlined our proposals for the development of what we called a system of priority national parks which is very much in line with the consultant's conclusions in his review of these matters. The consultant suggests that there ought to be a timetable for the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (DASETT) to phase out and later eliminate-or at the very least minimise-its involvement in management issues related to national parks, leaving the Commonwealth's role to the park authorities. We say that the ANPWS should confine itself to policy development and policy administration. We agree with that observation by the consultant.

This is a valuable and important report. It is very detailed. Undoubtedly, it will repay a great deal of study. I have great pleasure in commending it to the Senate for its attention and indicating the general thrust of what we do and do not support. Finally, I hope that in the replacement of Professor Ovington, who is shortly to retire as the Director of the ANPWS, the Commonwealth will select an officer who will continue the good work that he has commenced.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —In October of this year during the Estimates committee hearings I, like Senator Puplick, raised the issue of when the review of the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service (ANPWS) would be presented in the Senate. It was confirmed by Professor Ovington during the Estimates committee hearings that the report was submitted at the end of March. It has been tabled in the Senate today. This report contains great praise for the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service, an excellent organisation with dedicated staff. In the report its staff are described as being dedicated, enthusiastic, resourceful, professional and effective. It is great that this is recognised in the review.

A major recommendation is the consolidation of ANPWS into a broader Australian Nature Conservation Authority (ANCA), which would include the present Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority and some of the functions carried out by DASETT. Consolidation of various instrumentalities into a well-resourced Australian Nature Conservation Authority would appear to be a sound move which would strengthen and coordinate nature conservation activities in Australia. A major nature conservation problem in my own State of Western Australia is conservation of the marine and coastal environments. I refer specifically to Ningaloo reef which is an area of particular concern, as is the whole of the north-west coastline, and the Ashmore and Cartier reefs. As I said some time ago with regard to senators' financial capacities, if everybody in this place were to appear in one of these documents one would wonder how they could be allowed to run the country. That goes for all senators; I am not commenting on Ministers in particular. It is a pretty loose and certainly far from optimum situation to have before us a document such as this.

Honourable senators will remember that earlier this year I attempted to move, unsuccessfully, for the setting up of a committee to look into the establishment of a code of ethics dealing with these types of matters, matters that have been raised both in the Fitzgerald Commission of Inquiry into Possible Illegal Activities and Associated Police Misconduct and the New South Wales Independent Commission Against Corruption, concerning politicians' use of their power and influence to enrich either themselves or others. On the basis of this document it is evident that none of our Ministers has done anything of the kind. The problem is that, whilst our proposal for the establishment of a committee to look into a code of ethics was rejected, at the same time elsewhere the proposal for a code of ethics has been lauded. The new Commonwealth procurement policy, of which all senators have received a copy, states:

The Government is committed to maintaining high ethical standards in purchasing and to fair dealing with suppliers. It has agreed to the adoption of a code of ethics for the observation by all staff responsible for purchasing.

It is fascinating that the Government has seen the need for the purchasing reform group to have a code of ethics but that it has not seen the need to do likewise for parliamentarians. In regard to the private sector, I refer to an article in the Australian Financial Review quoting the Managing Director of the Adelaide Steamship Co. Ltd, Mr John Spalvins, who talks about the need for Australian business to adopt higher moral corporate standards to avoid what Mr Spalvins termed `cowboys'. Mr Spalvins was talking about the obvious need in business for the adherence to a recognised code of ethics. Again, business is moving towards this, and politicians seem to say, `It has got nothing to do with us'.

Probably one of the most extraordinary propositions is that which was put in this chamber on 10 May 1989 when Senator Richardson announced the establishment of a very important ethics committee. He said that a working group looking at techniques used in current Antarctic research projects involving live animals recommended as follows:
. . . there ought to be an animal care and ethics committee on a permanent basis and that a code of practice should be developed to cover our research involving Antarctic animals.

Honourable senators will be aware that this committee is called the Antarctic Animal Care and Ionising Radiation Usage Ethics Committee. I wonder how many people knew it existed. It is interesting that we have seen fit to establish the Antarctic Animal Care and Ionising Radiation Usage Ethics Committee to deal with that particular matter and, at the same time, we said that we saw absolutely no reason why we should do anything about the ethical behaviour of the people governing the country.

The Commission for the Future was established in one of those motherhood gestures involving public relations and little substance. The list of motherhood activities of this body-led by Mr Phillip Adams-is incredible, and includes such exciting things as our foreign affairs future. I do not know whether Senator Gareth Evans is excited about this, but Mr Phillip Adams's organisation has a program which, the report states:
. . . comprises a new series of projects to examine and influence the future relationships between Australia and her major North Asian trading partners.

The thought of Mr Phillip Adams playing such a role in Australia's future terrifies me. It is bad enough having Senator Gareth Evans doing it, but to have in such a role Mr Phillip Adams, who has confessed to seeking to influence our activities in this area, is totally unnerving.

The Commission has also initiated a project to map the future role and character of Australia's trade union movement-I wonder what the Department of Industrial Relations is doing. . . . the Commission's wide ranging programs extended from the future of trade unions to the future of our climate, from the ageing of our population to the impact of new communications technology, and the broad demands of future education.

It goes on with a lot of motherhood stuff about the future of the Australian economy.

SPEECH.PARA: The Commission believes economic sustainability can be reached by the year 2000, and that the environmental goal will take longer.

SPEECH.PARA: The coalition recognises the absolute need to provide rental housing in the public sector for people who cannot necessarily provide themselves with housing. We believe that the emphasis should be on placing people in their own homes and that assistance should be given in the form of rent subsidies and mortgage relief payments. The Opposition will support this Bill, but will move a second reading amendment condemning the Government for its policies that are causing undue hardship for hundreds of thousands of home owners and would-be home owners in Australia.

The Government's policies are making it very difficult for those who are now receiving housing assistance to bridge the gap to housing self-sufficiency. The emphasis of this Bill is to assist public rental housing. The Opposition would rather see people being assisted into their own homes. The coalition believes that public housing administered by a public sector does not give the best value for money because a good percentage of the money is chewed up by administration. As I said before, we recognise the need to house people who are unable to provide themselves with private housing.

There is a problem with this Bill that has been taken up by Senator Tambling on behalf of the Northern Territory Government. The Northern Territory will be dramatically affected by Commonwealth funding being distributed on a per capita basis. Some assurance has been given by the Government that the Northern Territory's share will be looked after and maintained. In 1988-89 the Northern Territory's share of the `nominated' funds was $43.8m. However, under the new per capita arrangements this amount will decrease to approximately $3m per annum. I know that Senator Collins has given some undertaking that he will see that the Northern Territory will not be adversely affected. I do not know how he will do that in respect of the legislation that is before us now, unless he has some sort of commitment from the Minister for Housing and Aged Care (Mr Staples).

The Northern Territory has the largest public housing sector in Australia-22 per cent of dwellings are public sector housing compared with 5 per cent nationally. The Northern Territory also has a much younger population which puts an additional strain on demand for new and lower cost housing. There are some problems in respect of the number of consultations between the States and Territory governments. I believe that some States have not signed the agreement which is before us today. The Northern Territory Government was not aware of what the new agreement would mean to it in dollars and cents and has continually voiced its opposition to this legislation.

The real problem facing Australia's accommodation seekers is the Government's one-tiered, irresponsible, high interest rates policies that are putting an unbelievable strain on young home buyers, people seeking both private and public rental housing, and families paying increased mortgages just to keep a roof over their heads. While the appropriation of this money is commendable, it is really not addressing the main issue; that is, that housing interest rates are currently at 17 per cent. That is unaffordable by most standards. All indicators prove beyond any reasonable doubt that the Government's housing policy is in disarray.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tatters.

—`In tatters' Senator Brownhill says, and he is quite correct. I will cite a few statistics: in October this year, 11,460 housing and dwelling approvals were granted compared with 15,312 in October last year. In September this year the number of private sector houses commenced dropped by 17.3 per cent over the number of commencements for September 1988. SPEECH.PARA: We can cite statistics in the Senate, but they do not give the true picture of the hardships facing many of Australia's young families. The pressure on families of meeting monthly commitments on the family home is resulting in many broken marriages and unhappiness. Buyers are having difficulty in meeting their payments because of high interest rates. I wish to cite some figures, which are quite frightening, from a report of the Housing Industry Association. The report lists the average first home costs in the capital cities and the incomes needed to service first home loans. The average cost of a first home in Sydney is $139,200. One would need an income of $64,100 to service a loan for such a house. That is mind-boggling. A home that one could purchase in Sydney for $139,000 would be a fairly modest home. I think it would be a worker's dwelling. This indicates that the Government's interest rate policy is crippling the home buyers of Australia. In Melbourne the average cost of a first home is $135,000, and an income of $62,200 would be needed to service a first home loan there. In Brisbane the average cost of a first home is $97,500. A more modest income of $44,900 would be needed to service a home loan there, but even that puts home ownership out of the reach of most young home buyers. Very few non-professional young people would have an income-even a joint income-of $64,100, which is required to service a first home loan in Sydney.

So we can say truthfully that this Government's high interest rate policy has put home ownership beyond the reach not only of average Australians but of wealthy Australians. The amount of $64,100 is a professional salary, the salary of a high office. It is not an income that a tradesman, an office worker or a bank officer would normally enjoy. It is more in line with the income of a doctor, a solicitor or a barrister.

TALK.START.PARA: —Or a public servant.

—High ranking public servants may be able to afford to buy a home in Sydney, but it is beyond the capacity of a working man or woman, or family. This Government has neglected its base support again. It was elected with the support of the working people. It has taken its support away from those people, its grassroot support, its heartland. It has taken away the right of those people to own a home in Australia. That is an indictment of the Government in which Senator Cook, who is in the chamber, serves.

SPEECH.PARA: The income needed to service a first home loan in Adelaide is $41,000. The average cost of a first home there is $89,200. Again, it is beyond the reach of most working men and women. Young married people know that they have to have two incomes before they can even begin to think about owning their own home. That puts a strain on people who want to have a family. People are having families later in life because they just cannot afford to get out of the work force. It is a strain on them. When they have children, the children are put into creches, into kindergartens, and into child-care centres at a very young age which, again, puts a strain on the families.

When Labor came into office seven years ago it took first home buyers 19 per cent of their average weekly earnings to service an average housing loan. In June 1985 that average had jumped to 25.6 per cent of average weekly earnings. Now that figure has skyrocketed to an unbelievable, almost unreachable, figure of 31.5 per cent of average weekly earnings. Savings bank interest rates for housing loans reached a staggering 17 per cent this year. Building society rates are slightly higher, I believe. It is beyond the capacity of many people to meet their commitments. These statistics do not show the real picture of the strain on thousands of young Australians who are struggling to meet their mortgage repayments or who are locked out of home ownership and have either to live with their parents or pay exorbitant rent. The legacy of this Government to young Australian families after its seven years in office is a choice of living with parents, living in flats or in caravans. It is an indictment of the Labor Government's housing policy.

There has been no improvement in the amount being lent for housing. It has been steadily dropping for the last 12 months. In September last year almost $2,000m was lent for housing. This September, the last month for which I could find figures, only $1,300m was lent. There is no improvement in sight for either the private sector or the public sector. We are going backwards, despite the fact that $1.01 billion will be allocated in this Bill. In June last year 195,370 applicants were on the waiting list for public housing, and only 23 per cent of applicants are allocated accommodation each year. So last June 195,000 people were waiting to get into the public housing sector. So not only is the private housing industry in disarray; the public sector, too, is unable to cope with the huge demand that the high interest rates are causing. Many people who could normally afford private housing at realistic rates of interest are being forced into public housing, swelling the queues waiting for public housing.

I do not believe that we can debate the Government's policy on housing without debating Australia's homeless youth. That situation is even worse. It gives me no pleasure to bring up that subject. In the 1987 campaign, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) said that by 1990 there would be no child living in poverty. That is a noble aspiration for anyone to have, but the Prime Minister has not delivered on that promise. In fact, his promise has been a huge disaster. The facts, as estimated in the Burdekin report-the report of the National Inquiry into Homeless children-are that at least 8,500 children aged 12 to 15 years, and 17,000 aged 15 to 17 years, are homeless in any one year. The Burdekin report goes on to say that they are conservative figures and that there is more likely to be between 50,000 and 70,000 children who are homeless. The Human Rights Equal Opportunity Commission report of February 1989 entitled Our Homeless Children said that at least 20,000 to 25,000 young Australians were homeless, with the real figure being as high as 70,000. The Burdekin report and the Human Rights Commission report both confirm that figure. That gives some indication that those figures are on line. Both reports went on to say that, because those children were so young and lacked the basic resources, they were often driven to crime and prostitution. I do not believe anyone, whether they be in opposition, government or, the Australian Democrats who sit on the crossbenches, can take any comfort from those statistics.

The children on our streets are getting younger, yet the Government's policies are not reaching the majority of those who are suffering. The Government's policies are not reaching the people that are seeking private housing and those seeking public housing, or homeless children. So everywhere one looks, the Government's housing policies have been a failure. In every sector the Government has not fulfilled its commitment. I do not believe that there is any area of government policy in which the Government has failed so badly, so miserably, as in the area of housing. With record interest rates of 17 per cent to 18 per cent, on average, people need to earn $64,000 a year in order to service the repayments on a first home. How many people earn $64,000 a year? A very slim proportion. The public sector waiting lists are growing; only 23 per cent of people are having their needs met. The Opposition will support this legislation, but is forced to move an amendment which criticises and condemns the Government for its failed policies on all sectors of the housing industry. I therefore move:
At end of motion, add ``, but the Senate condemns the Government for its:
(a) undue emphasis on public housing stock at the expense of rental assistance to the private rental market;
(b) confrontationist approach to the States in the preparation of this new Commonwealth/State Housing Agreement;
(c) deliberate and ruthless high interest rate policy which is:
(i) pushing house ownership beyond the reach of many families; and
(ii) making it more difficult for those who are now receiving housing assistance to bridge the gap to housing self-sufficiency.''.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not wish to delay the Senate unduly, but given the parlous state of the housing situation and the lack of opportunity for so many Australian families, I believe it is important that I make some remarks on behalf of those hundreds of thousands young and not so young Australians rendered homeless by the policies of the Hawke Labor Government.

SPEECH.PARA: The simple facts are that by the turn of the century in 10 years time more than 500,000 Australian families will be sharing their homes with at least two other families. That means that 9 per cent of the population will be living in shared accommodation. In real terms nearly 86,000 people were on public housing rental lists in New South Wales alone this time last year, and the situation has only improved marginally. Home loan repayments have jumped, on average, by $250 per month. The goal of every Australian to own their own home is nothing more than an illusory, impossible dream-and we all know how that song goes. A Sydney Morning Herald poll earlier this year revealed that nearly 68 per cent of those people polled believed that the dream of a house on a quarter-acre block of land was no longer a reasonable expectation. Is it any wonder? One has only to take a drive through the new housing estates or look at the land and house packages being offered and one's head spins. I suggest that if any honourable senators in this chamber were trying to buy their first home, they would have difficulty affording anything at all reasonable.

While this Government can hold housing summits that do little more than massage enormous and ever-growing egos, the reality is that average working couples are condemned to living in rental accommodation for the majority of their working lives, and it has been established by statistics that couples delay starting families, as Senator Boswell said, because they simply cannot afford to lose one income. That is not a very good position for this lucky country of Australia to be in. This country is obviously not so lucky for those people who want to buy their first homes. We cannot really criticise the Government's housing policy because this Government really does not have a decent housing policy to criticise. An interesting paper was recently put out, in October, by the Real Estate Institute of Australia Ltd entitled Australia's Declining Housing Affordability. I quote from one part of the paper-and I think this is really where the problem with housing lies-which says:
Causes of decline in housing affordability
1. Government macro-economic policy.

Australia's taxation system serves to lower national savings, affordability and the efficiency with which the existing stock of houses is used. The greater an individual's savings, the greater the tax liability. The ability to save is an important factor in housing affordability. Savings which contribute to a housing deposit are generally made from after-tax income. This ability to save is affected by the fact that average income earners today pay a higher marginal rate of tax than did average income earners 10 years ago. This is compounded further by the government's unfavourable treatment of interest earned on savings deposits. Therefore those struggling to raise a deposit are faced with double taxation on the income contributing to this deposit.

In essence Australia's taxation system taxes savings and encourages individuals to spend. As a result a critical balance of payments problem has developed through the nation borrowing at a far greater rate to compensate for the lack of national savings needed to finance consumer expenditure. The government's response has been to tighten the supply of money and thus force up its cost.

Inefficiency in the housing sector, manifested in cyclical ups and downs in the industry, is a direct result of this policy. Typically when interest rates increase, the borrowing capacity of potential first home buyers is lowered, which limits their access to the sales market. This has a ripple effect through the industry as home owners wanting to upgrade are unable to sell their homes. The result is decreased sales and a downturn in the housing and construction industry, as has been the case in 1989.

The lack of continuity in activity leads to periods of under-utilisation followed by periods of high demand and related cost increases. During periods of under-utilisation there is difficulty in providing a stable environment for the training of workers and the formation of skills. As a result, apprentices are retrenched which causes a lack of skilled workers. This becomes critical when housing demand is again released on the relaxing of monetary policy. As there is a lack of supply of skilled workers, rising labour costs and shortage of new housing stock results. These forces act to bring about another boom in house prices, leading to affordability problems for the potential first home buyer.
That quotation shows what the big problem is in the housing industry.

This Government is just lurching from one crisis to another, trying to convince the Australian public that high interest rates are good for them. Senator Richardson was quoted the other day as saying that he believed the Government had not sold its message on high interest rates too well. I would be very interested to know how he or anyone else in the Government can possibly put any positive light on high interest rates. If Senator Richardson can convince the Australian public that high interest rates are good for them, I suggest he is wasting his time in this chamber; he could be making a fortune selling holes out of doughnuts and ice to Eskimos if he could sell that to the Australian public.

The Liberal and National parties, on the other hand, have a very workable housing policy, based on an acknowledgment that secure, appropriate and affordable housing is a basic need of all. We believe that a home provides a stable family environment, a share in the nation's wealth and a source of personal security. But all this Government has done is push more people into State-owned housing. We are going to reverse this policy by giving priority to home ownership assistance. We will assist with mortgage repayments, thus enhancing the affordability of houses for qualifying first home buyers. We will improve and better target the home deposit scheme and the first home owners scheme. We are going to encourage public housing tenants to buy their homes. Despite what the Prime Minister has said about homeless and poor youth, we believe that they do exist and they do need help. To that end we will continue to enhance programs for transitional, crisis accommodation.

Above all, the Liberal and National parties coalition will provide a stable, healthy economic climate which will encourage greater investment in housing and make achievable once again the great Australian dream for all Australians: the dream of owning their own home. This Government has robbed its citizens of one of their basic rights: to own their own home easily and affordably. The Opposition has pledged to restore the right to affordable home ownership.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Housing Assistance Bill 1989 provides an opportunity to canvass many of the issues surrounding housing policy and its implementation. At this stage of the session, to canvass all of those questions does not seem to be a very responsible approach, but I take this opportunity to make some general and specific remarks about this legislation, which implements the Commonwealth-State housing agreement. We have to look at this legislation in the framework of what is happening with housing. In this debate something has already been said about that, but I simply want to place on the record the Australian Democrats' concern at the state of housing and the impact that it is having on people in our community. It is getting increasingly difficult for people to become home owners, high interest rates and high home prices being factors involved in that.

SPEECH.PARA: We will not be supporting the second reading amendment from the Opposition because it is a major concern of the Democrats that more emphasis needs to be placed on the provision of public housing. In an environment where it is more difficult for people to get into home ownership and where private rentals are being pushed up, public housing becomes an even more critical factor in the overall housing picture. It is quite disturbing when one looks at what is happening in that area. In my own State of Victoria just last month a rental report, which is a quarterly review of the availability and cost of private rental property, demonstrated that tenants are paying up to 75 per cent of their weekly pay in rent. When that is put against a benchmark of 25 per cent, the sort of benchmark which is at an acceptable level of household income to be paid on housing, we see that that is an unacceptably high level.

An example was given on the release of this report by the Victorian Minister for Housing of a single pensioner parent with one child renting a two-bedroom property at a medium rental of $145 per week. When the length of the queues for public housing and the length of time people are waiting for public housing are considered, one realises that that single pensioner parent with one child is not an isolated case. It ought to be a matter of deep regret to all of us that those sorts of situations are occurring in our community.

For those people who are attempting to get into home ownership, the survey of the Real Estate Institute of Australia reported in September in the Australian Financial Review showed that average repayments on new housing loans had reached 35.8 per cent of average family income in the three months leading up to 30 June of this year. That affordability ratio was up from 33.6 per cent in the March quarter and 28.4 per cent in June last year. So it is not just people in private rental who are above that acceptable level of 25 per cent.

The figures from the Australian Bureau of Statistics 1988-89 household expenditure survey showed that the proportion of family income devoted to housing had risen in the past five years at the expense of other basics such as food. That survey showed that the proportion of total household expenditure devoted to housing costs had risen from 12.8 per cent in 1984 to 14.2 per cent; the proportion spent on food fell from 19.7 per cent to 18.7 per cent as those higher housing costs absorbed more income; and other items, such as clothing, recreation, and so on, also showed falls.

It is this trend of increasing pressure of housing costs on the lives of families in all kinds of housing that is of enormous concern to the Democrats. The causes are complex, of course, but the pressures of interest rates and of the Government reducing consistently over the years its own outlays of expenditure on public services, such as public housing, are major factors in the problem.

We are dealing with legislation on the Commonwealth-State housing agreement. The States have been hard hit by the Government's economic rationalist approach, and its reduction in spending in order to provide Budget surpluses. Let us not forget that the picture that I have drawn has to be seen against an economy whose surplus is over $9 billion.

When one looks at the pressure in the public housing area, reflected largely at State level, because the responsibility for provision is at State level, one sees other problems which are arising. My own State of Victoria is faced with a very high level of arrears among its public housing tenants. Just this week a report has suggested that there ought to be a system of direct debiting of pensions in order to make sure that public housing rents are paid. I join with those organisations which, in this morning's newspapers in Victoria, have expressed concern about such an approach. The director of the Victorian Council of Social Service, Rob Hudson, has referred to such direct debiting as `a dangerous option' which would `compromise tenants' flexibility to cope with financial emergencies'. Clearly becoming indebted for rent is an indication of a financial crises. While such a system might be deemed to be voluntary, Rob Hudson points out that in the context of rental arrears, where people have no effective choice, it is not so voluntary. Glenn Foard of the Public Tenants Union has said:
. . . direct debiting of pensions to pay public housing rents was not the answer, because it did not deal with the problem of low incomes.

We cannot talk about housing and the people who are hardest hit without looking at income support issues. Whilst the Government has made some moves in the direction of income support for low income people-and families in particular-while we have single pensioners paying 75 per cent of their weekly income in rent it is clear that those measures have not been adequate and that much more needs to be done.

The Australian Council of Social Service (ACOSS) in its pre-Budget submission this year devoted a great deal of attention to housing. It pointed out that high prices and high interest rates drive up rents, adding to the overall housing crisis, along with high interest rates for people who are purchasing homes. Nearly one in four private tenants have incomes below the poverty line after paying for housing. Rents and mortgage repayments have pushed hundreds of thousands of Australians into poverty. I draw this fact to the attention of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), the Premiers and the relevant Ministers who will be meeting next month in what the Prime Minister insists is not a summit on poverty but which is certainly a meeting to address the questions of poverty at State and National level. Without addressing this issue, they would not be addressing one of the key factors that is driving people into poverty.

Much can be said about the causes of the housing crisis-high interest rates; pent-up demand; the skewing into speculation largely created by the reintroduction of negative gearing, which was opposed only by the Australian Democrats in this place and which led to overinvestment; as well as heavy investment in owner-occupied housing; scarcity of land for new housing, scarcity of skilled labour and materials; and under-investment in public and community housing by governments.

I turn to the legislation. The Minister for Housing and Aged Care (Mr Staples) has been quoted as saying that the new Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement is a key part of the Government's housing and social justice commitments and would help alleviate poverty among low income earners. Would that that were the case. When one looks at funding under the new agreement the picture is not nearly as rosy as that. It does not meet the need outlined by ACOSS for increased government funding for public housing and therefore cannot meet the problems of housing-induced poverty.

When one looks at the actual amount being spent on public housing in relative terms and in real terms across the period of this agreement and the life of this Government, the picture is not particularly encouraging. Total government funds for housing to the States in 1989-90 have been reduced in real terms by 39 per cent since 1986-87. This year sees the third consecutive real reduction in total funds. The forward commitment by the Government each year for four years, commencing in 1989-90, will mean a reduction in real terms of 18.2 per cent over that period. By 1992-93, on the basis of the current forward commitment, Commonwealth funds to the States will have decreased in real terms by 50 per cent since 1986-87. The real level of funds in 1989-90 is 11 per cent less than the real level of funds in the first full year of the Fraser Liberal Government in 1976-77. In 1992-93, on the basis of the current forward commitment, Commonwealth funds to the States will have decreased in real terms to the average level of funds provided by the Fraser Liberal Government from 1976-77 to 1982-83.

That is a regrettable situation in the view of the Australian Democrats. That is a minimal commitment, one that barely matches that of the Fraser Liberal Government and represents a decrease over a long period of time. We are faced with a government which says, as the Minister has said, that housing is a major part of its social justice strategy and which, as Senator Boswell has said, is led by a Prime Minister who has made a commendable commitment to eliminating child poverty. But we know that housing is pushing hundreds of thousands of Australians below the poverty line.

The picture that we see before us in this new Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement is far from rosy. The Democrats and people concerned with public housing and its tenants have other concerns about this legislation. One is the treatment of rental rebates. The agreement resolves in a particular way the increasing rental rebate bills of State housing authorities and establishes a financial viability of public housing but does not incorporate the principle of Commonwealth responsibility for rental rebates, which has been up until now a feature of Commonwealth-State housing agreements. I say that is a principle because the Commonwealth responsibility has not always been met. But in this case the principle has actually been removed-not incorporated-in this 1989 Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement.

The rental rebates are the difference between what the tenants pay and the costs of public housing-such as rates, maintenance and other service charges, administration, loan repayments, depreciation, bad debts and so on. The rebate issue is resolved in this Bill by shared responsibility between the Commonwealth and the States. In essence, the Commonwealth is meeting only part of its income responsibilities. In this way the legislation will make it far more difficult for the State housing authorities and community organisations to insist that the Commonwealth meet its income responsibilities to pay for the full cost of rental rebates.

We are also concerned about the question of assistance plans in this package. I have a series of amendments to move in the committee stage which we believe are necessary to ensure that the Commonwealth-State plans are made public and that the States and the Commonwealth consult community organisations in the process of developing Commonwealth-State plans. The amendments are designed to bring in the consumers of public housing and to make sure that consultation with community organisations is a part of the process of the development of the Commonwealth-State housing assistance plans. We also have some concerns about rentals. We are concerned that the legislation requires the States to charge the minimum amount of market rental. We really believe that charging rentals above market rentals is contrary to the detailed provisions of the Commonwealth-State housing agreement. That remains a concern for us in this legislation. We would prefer to see the rent on each dwelling determined by a set of principles which would mean that rentals would not exceed the market rental on the dwelling. We do not believe that that is covered in this legislation.

I have alluded to our concerns about the funds available in this new Commonwealth-State housing agreement. The new 1989 Commonwealth-State housing agreement represents a major philosophical shift within the Government and, therefore, within the Australian Labor Party. The 1984 agreement was based on promoting public housing as an alternative to home ownership. This agreement seems to be based on the welfare model of public housing. It is concerned with tightening the reins and ensuring that public housing is targeted to low income households. This is consistent with the Government's very strong targeting approach in its welfare system. Other social and economic forces which I have mentioned have `welfarised' public housing. This is now endorsed by the underlying philosophic and policy change.

We are concerned that a feature of this legislation is that a larger proportion of the funding than was previously available is to be made available for assistance for home purchase. That does not mean that we do not believe that the purchase of a home is not a desirable goal. As I have outlined, over the whole period which is dealt with by this agreement we are looking at a 50 per cent funding cut for what is an agreement on public housing. We are very disturbed that the pressure which has come from the States to free up more of these funds for home ownership has been at least to a degree successful. We are concerned because that is a further erosion of funding which is specifically and directly targeted to public housing.

Until we get a genuine approach to public housing we cannot accept the welfare model totally because it fails to recognise that housing has a number of functions in our community. It is part of the transition between the various stages of peoples' lives. It also fails to recognise that we have an increasing need in our community for single persons or couples with no children to have a type of accommodation which can be very adequately and efficiently provided through a public housing sector, if we have a genuine public housing sector and one which is not `welfarised'. We regret the lack of a strong commitment to a genuine public housing development. We regret the cutbacks over time in funding in this area. We have to ensure that there is community consultation in the process of the continuation and development of this Commonwealth-State housing agreement and we will move amendments to that effect in the committee stage.

As I have said, we are not supporting the Opposition's second reading amendment because it complains about too much emphasis on public housing, which is quite the reverse of our view of this legislation. It does refer to a confrontationist approach with the States. I have already said that in some ways at least the States have had an undue influence in respect to aspects of this matter. I am aware that the responsible South Australian Minister, and the South Australian Council of Social Services, has pointed to some particular deficiencies for that State in the new agreement. They are very concerned that a reduction over five years will reduce the availability of housing for the most disadvantaged in that State. I do not believe it is the case that there has been a confrontationist approach.

While we have some sympathy with the third aspect of the Opposition's second reading amendment which complains about the high interest rate regime imposed on the community, having sat in this chamber hour after hour and having heard Senator Stone, the finance spokesperson for the Opposition, insist that the interest rate regime will be the same upon a change of Government, it will be very difficult for us to endorse even that part of the motion on the basis that it does not have any particular foundation as far as the Opposition is concerned. While we do not oppose this legislation we put on record those particular concerns that we have with it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the Housing Assistance Bill 1989 which gives force to the Commonwealth-State housing agreement. As is not obvious from the remarks of many honourable senators who have participated in the second reading debate, this Bill is supported by all parties and is expected to have a smooth passage. Nonetheless, a number of speakers have chosen to use the second reading debate to make what they regard as condemnatory remarks of the Government and to beat their chests about what they might do were they in Government to improve the lot of people who rely on public housing in Australia. So much so has that been the case that none other than Senator Boswell has been moved to put down a motion of condemnation in those terms in the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: I would normally retire from the podium after thanking honourable senators for their contributions to the debate and commend what is consensual legislation to the chamber. Senator Boswell's move requires me to say at least some things on behalf of the Government to set the record straight and to make it clear that this has been a Government of reform and improvement in terms of the public housing sector. The first comment I make is that the historic and fundamental thing that distinguishes the Australian Labor Party from the conservative parties in this country, or indeed in other countries of the world where that parliamentary representation appears, is that the Labor Party has pioneered the concept of public housing. The Labor Party did that, given its basic commitment to equality of opportunity, its commitment to the fact that people who are poor, who are low paid and who are in straitened circumstances should have access to good quality housing and not be discriminated against because of that. It is a legitimate charge to the public purse to see that the taxation dollar is recycled to meet their needs. That commitment fundamentally and philosophically draws a line of distinction between us and the conservative parties who, in their open honesty on this philosophical difference, have pointed to the need to encourage private initiative and to encourage people to find the wherewithal themselves.

True it is that in the third version of the Opposition's housing policy, brought down by the third or fourth Opposition housing spokesperson since the 1987 election, the Opposition paid lip service to public housing and rental assistance but, consistent with its philosophical mould, put together a proposal which is uncosted and vague but which aims at moving people out of public housing and into owner occupied housing without explaining how low income earners can afford to pay the types of mortgages that would be attendant on that move. If they could not pay it, they would be left God knows where.

Let me make it clear that the Government rejects Senator Boswell's motion. Our commitment to meeting the housing needs of the Australian population has been clearly demonstrated during our period of office. Our policies have been effectively targeted during the last 6 1/2 years of our period in government. Our policies have provided housing assistance which is distributed equitably between the public and the private rental assistance sectors, the home ownership area and crisis accommodation. Commonwealth assistance for public housing has more than doubled in real terms under this Government with over $1 billion being provided to the States this financial year. Over the last six years an estimated 260,000 households have been accommodated in public housing compared with 194,000 over the previous six years of the Opposition's period in government.

During our period in office an estimated additional 82,000 rental dwellings have been provided compared with 47,000 over the previous six years of the Opposition period of government. Approximately $480m will be provided for rent assistance this year compared with $160m provided in the last year of the previous Liberal Government. An estimated 92,000 home loans to low income households have been provided through the Commonwealth-State housing agreement over the last six years compared with a mere 59,000 over the previous six years. I can go on and make a starkly contrasting analysis of what we have done compared with what the Opposition did in its last period in office.

I conclude by saying that over 340,000 households have been assisted into home ownership under the first home owners scheme since its inception in 1983 at a total obligation of over $1.45 billion. In 1985 we established the supported accommodation assistance program to provide short term accommodation and support for those who were homeless and in crisis. In short, if one compares the indicators-not the words, not the brave promises but, indeed, the performances; what in fact happens and whether ordinary people get an opportunity-one sees that we have outstripped and doubled or trebled the performance of the Opposition in almost every area. It is not what people say but what people do which is the real indication of their priorities. On this set of statistics, there is no doubt that this Government's priority has been to meet our philosophical objective-the one I spoke of earlier-and provide for low income earners and people in need public housing stock which can meet that demand.

Predictably, the Opposition has taken this opportunity to berate us about home mortgages and the level of interest rates. I think it was Senator Powell who drew attention to the fact that the Opposition in this chamber over several debates has indicated that if it gains office it is unlikely that there will be any change in interest rates. That is not Andrew Peacock's view; I know that he has promised the Australian people that he will bring interest rates down. But it seems to be Senator Stone's view. It is certainly Dr Hewson's view and I heard John Howard say something about it the other day. So the question is whether one believes the Leader or the hard economic rationalists within the Opposition. What is true is that the Opposition has no panacea because of the overheating of the Australian economy and the need to keep restraints on money supply. Therefore, while I understand that this occasion would present those opposite with an opportunist possibility of exploiting the high level of home interest rates-something that we do not enjoy and do not like, but have to endure-their criticisms are made simply from an exploitative point of view and not from a point of view of delivering anything real or important.

I note that Senator Powell has foreshadowed that she will move an amendment at the committee stage. Unfortunately the Government will not accept her amendment. But when she brings it forward I will give a clear statement of the Government's view, which is in sympathy with the sentiments of her amendment although we cannot in practice reach the detail she proposes to insert into the Housing Assistance Bill. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

That the amendment (Senator Boswell's) be agreed to.

These amendments, in substance, are designed to provide for community consultation regarding Commonwealth-State plans. The amendments are designed to ensure that Commonwealth-State plans are made public and that the States and the Commonwealth consult community organisations in the process of developing Commonwealth-State plans. The Australian Democrats believe that the consumers of public housing-public tenants and their advocates-applicants for tenancy, consumers of housing generally and community agencies have a right to be involved in plans affecting their lives or the lives of their clients. That general principle is one to which I adhere and I am adhering to it more and more strongly the longer I stay in this place.

I find that many political and bureaucratic decisions that are made are far distant from, and show a lack of understanding of, the genuine needs of recipients of welfare services and public services generally. I think this is one of the major negatives in our Commonwealth system. Maybe it is because Canberra is where it is. But I think that wherever the national capital was located we would get a centralisation of thought and experience. Perhaps it would be better if our national capital were situated in an area with slums, with inadequate basic public housing, with high-rise concrete jungles, or whatever. Canberra is a very attractive place in which to live. The more time we spend here-and, goodness knows, we are spending too much time here now!-the more distant we can get from the real needs and concerns of people, particularly people in some of our heavily populated inner urban areas.

In addition, there are public housing needs in all sorts of communities, not least isolated rural communities. Before I came to this place I had experience of a town in a dairying area where the butter factory had been closed down and the factory houses had been sold off. All the sole parents were moved there. The mums and the kids slowly went mad and, in some cases, became violent, each against the other. That is another example of how distant decision makers can be from the client group. Here I am speaking about consumers, but many bodies in the community who are advocates for the consumers and assist people to become public housing tenants have a clear understanding of the needs of those people and put quite considerable pressure on governments in making those decisions. Quite overtly, I am attempting to put those sorts of people in a better position to put more pressure on governments to get their priorities right.

I am not saying, by way of this amendment, that there has been no consultation; I certainly understand that there has been. I am simply saying that I, and the Australian Democrats, would like to see-as would the people I have spoken of-the need for consultation entrenched in the legislation. It seems only a very few hours since I made this same comment when speaking to another piece of legislation. I said then that the major motivation for that legislation was the prospect of an upcoming election. I think I said to the same Minister-the Minister for resources (Senator Cook)-that it is all right to have him sitting here making commitments, which I have no doubt that he will, and representing a government which has consulted, I have no doubt that it will with some considerable justification. But we are faced with a democratic system and this Government, whether at this election or at another, will not always be in government and the attitude of an alternative government just may be different. We did hear Senator Boswell saying a lot about housing, so perhaps an alternative government might not be as bad as we think it would be. But I think it is important that these sorts of rights, this sort of access and this sort of consultation is entrenched in legislation; hence I commend these amendments to the Committee.

The last time we were dealing with the Electoral and Referendum Amendment Bill 1988 I moved the Australian Democrats amendment No. 2, to insert a new proposed section 53a. I have now moved our amendments relating to clause 68 and clause 109, which were circulated together with amendment No. 2. They relate to how to vote cards. As they all refer to the same item, it would seem to me to make more sense in terms of time that we deal with them together. These amendments deal with how to vote cards. As I said in the committee stage last time, we have been compelled to raise this yet again and, fortuitously, there have been two State elections since then. In each of those elections I and other members of my Party found-and I think Senator Haines could verify this in terms of the South Australian election, for which she handed out how to vote cards as well-that pressure is now coming from people attending the booths asking why we are continuing to waste so much paper on these cards.

As I said last time, in a Federal election probably no fewer than 80 million pieces of paper are handed out-an extraordinary amount-on one day. There is a simple and straightforward device to deal with this which in no way takes away the rights of political parties, or the rights of members of the public to see how the parties would wish them to vote, and that is having the how to vote cards under perspex in the polling booths.

The attempt to stop the how to vote card is nothing new in the Australian context. As I said before, section 246 of the Tasmanian Electoral Act specifies that the distribution of voting material, such as how to vote cards, is banned on polling day. I worked out the wastage involved and found that 150 hectares of forests and 300 tonnes of paper are used-something we could avoid by using other methods.

It is interesting that during the last Queensland election campaign the now Premier, Mr Goss, pledged on a radio program that I was on to prevent the future distribution of how to vote cards and opted for the identical method that I have been suggesting-that is, that how to vote cards be put in the polling booths under perspex. We will see Queensland follow the example of Tasmania on this issue. It is a pity that the Australian Labor Party in Canberra could not have got the jump on its Queensland colleagues and moved before them to do exactly the same thing.

What I am suggesting would satisfy all the demands for information that are made. This Parliament has led the way in providing additional information for voters on polling day. This is the Parliament which moved to place the names of political parties next to the names on the ballot paper, so that an individual voter could not be misled by how to vote cards or other literature that was handed out, and could easily see for himself which particular candidate had which particular affiliation. Within Australia we have other innovations such as that in the Northern Territory of having photographs on the ballot paper to assist the voters-particularly Aboriginal voters-in the identification of candidates.

What we have been about is certainly pursued here, and the proposition I am putting is not a new one. As I say, it has already been followed in the hard form in Tasmania, and in the softer version in South Australia, where how to vote cards may be displayed in the polling booth although the State has not yet moved to the point of banning how to vote cards. Undoubtedly, this issue will become much more of a concern to people on an election day, when the heightened environmental awareness of the public is such that they will want to make sure that not only do politicians preach about these types of things but, in an area in which political parties have some influence-probably about the only one-they take a major step for conservation.

The other point that should be raised is the somewhat extraordinary exercise that we now put electors through in most polling booths of running the gauntlet. It occurs in most cities around Australia. People need four hands to be able to grasp all the papers that are thrust at them. That does not encourage the type of thing that people have spoken about in this place, but the complete opposite. We are not encouraging the voter to make a decision prior to going to the polls based on information but, rather, we are encouraging impulse buying at the gate itself. As long as one political party does this, the dictates of the electoral system are such that everybody feels obliged to do it. Hence, we need a legislative base to deal with this. I appeal to the Labor Party and the Opposition parties to consider this and take a step which, I think, would be extremely well received-certainly by the conservationists around Australia and also by the average voter who is sick and tired of gauntlet running on election day.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition will not support these amendments. I have never heard such a feeble attempt to do two things at the one time. Firstly, the amendments seek to deny the elementary freedom of speech for people who want to be out on polling day, giving potential electors pieces of paper advising them how to vote. Secondly, they are a masquerade of being concerned about trees, paper and the electorate, when the truth is that this is a plea from a party which has no chance of manning every gate on every polling booth, and which is going to make sure that, once again, the public picks up the cost of the shortfall that the Australian Democrats have in attempting to get their how to vote literature into the hands of the maximum number of electors.

SPEECH.PARA: The specific regime put forward by Senator Macklin is as follows. Proposed clause 206a (1) states that a poster is to be formed from the how to vote cards. Who is to form the poster? Presumably, it will be the Australian Electoral Commission, the divisional returning office or an officer in the electoral system. Senator Macklin knows as well as anybody else the advantages and disadvantages that will flow, depending on where one's how to vote card happens to appear on the poster. Everybody knows that, unless we have the sort of revolving system which has been used in places like Tasmania, for example, in terms of the position of candidates on a ballot paper, there is a marginal advantage if one's how to vote card is the how to vote card which is displayed in the top left-hand corner of that poster. Everybody knows that.

We then come to the question of how the poster is to be formed, what the size of the poster is to be. Let me tell the Committee that in the Senate campaign in New South Wales it is undoubtedly true that there will be some dozens of candidates in party groupings, all of whom will have in terms of the distributions of their preferences a how to vote card which will be quite substantial in its actual physical size. If there are 20 or 30 of those groups on a ballot paper, each of whom is putting out a how to vote card which advises people how to vote for 40 or 50 candidates, and we are going to make a poster of that and display that inside each separate voting compartment, that is to say, those narrow cubicles formed out of the recycled cardboard which is used by the Electoral Commission or, indeed, the older ones which have the timber construction, I will tell the Committee what some of them are going to look like: they will start in one corner and they will run down the side of the booth, across the booth in front and back up the other side of the booth. Either that, or they will be so microscopically small that the Electoral Commission will have to order a couple of hundred thousand magnifying glasses to hand to electors so they can actually see what the wretched thing is all about.

It is not only that. The how to vote card is to be submitted in the prescribed form. In other words, the Electoral Commission will tell us how to put out, how to design and how to print our how to vote cards. They will be in the prescribed form and in the quantity determined by the Divisional Returning Officer. The poor old Divisional Returning Officer now has the responsibility cast upon him, under this amendment, to make sure that the how to vote card is submitted in the form which has been prescribed, presumably by some sort of regulation or schedule to the Electoral Act. The Divisional Returning Officer in each of the Commonwealth Divisions is to determine how many how to vote cards he wants supplied for that particular purpose, presumably for the purposes of forming these posters. One would have thought that the answer to that in some respects should have been only one. They have to be received within seven days before polling day. And so it goes on.

The sheer physical and logistical questions that are raised-let me leave to one side for a moment the question of the principle-by this amendment about each separate voting compartment having a poster, the nature of the poster, the responsibility for the preparation of the poster, the way in which the how to vote cards are to be displayed on the poster, and all the rest of it, just seems to me to be in its own way an absolute nonsense.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are entitled to register more than one how to vote card.

—Indeed, as my colleague Senator Reid says, one in fact is entitled to register more than one how to vote card. One has the opportunity to have all of these parties, multiplied by three. We have this wonderful system where the ones left over at the end are determined by lots, in terms of the distribution of the preferences. Imagine in New South Wales 15 or 20 electoral groups which may or may not register one, two or three how to vote cards for a potential Senate ticket which might have 40 candidates on it-and they will be combined into a poster and there will be one of those posters inside each voting compartment, for heaven's sake! I think simply to describe what is being proposed is to show what a nonsense it is.

SPEECH.PARA: More significant is the question of the proposed new section 109a to insert a new section 328a in the Act under the heading `No How to Vote Cards on Polling Day'. I have some difficulty recalling the exact nature of the debate that took place some months ago on this, but I do seem to recall that one of those pieces of paper that the Minister read out, which I think came from the Electoral Commission, was that wonderful statement that there is nothing that party workers enjoy more in the course of their life than standing around on polling day handing out how to vote cards and that it would be a shame to deprive them of the joy and the privilege that they get--

TALK.START.PARA: —Tongue in cheek, I said it.

—I thought it could only have been written by somebody who had never actually been through the process of standing at a polling booth all day doing that particular job. There is a very significant principle; that is, the principle that on polling day the political parties' candidates are entitled to approach electors in a particular fashion. There are in the Electoral Act prohibitions on canvassing and on the direct participation of candidates on polling day, and nobody has sought to upset those. There has been a quite distinct view that canvassing on polling day and participation by certain individuals on polling day should be ruled out, and it has been consistently ruled out under the Electoral Act.

SPEECH.PARA: It has always been a feature of Australian electoral practice that when we go to the polling booth there is an attempt by the various political parties to get a how to vote card into our hand. We all know the old techniques about who is at the furthest end of the queue, who is closest to the door, whether it matters whether they have our ticket on top when they go through the door, whether we go scrounging round the bins to get the used tickets out, or put them in the bins so that they do not look as though they are littering all over the street--

TALK.START.PARA: —Or knocking off the opposition's one when they are not looking.

—Well, indeed. In those places where somebody comes along and leaves a bunch of how to vote cards under a rock and the expectation is that we will direct other people to take those cards in case they miss them on the way, or whether in fact there is a friendly political group or party that says, `Look, do you mind handing these out, as well as handing out your own?-they are the common features of polling day activity that those of us who do not mind being described as party hacks have lived with for the period of our political existence in terms of the parties.

SPEECH.PARA: The fundamental principle of saying, as Senator Macklin's amendment does, `You shall be prohibited by Commonwealth electoral law from handing out how to vote cards on polling day' seems to me to be an absolute nonsense. The Committee will note, of course, that it is is not a prohibition on how to vote cards per se; it is simply a prohibition handing them out on polling day. All that in fact would be achieved in this circumstance would be to make sure that in the weeks prior to polling day exactly the same number of pieces of paper were handed out in the shopping centres, on the streets, in the letter boxes-wherever it happens to be. There is no magic that all of a sudden we will wipe out this terrible business of cutting down trees and turning them into how to vote cards. It is a prohibition on a particular day.

The other thing about it is that not only is it offensive, I believe in terms of in the rights of people participating in the handing out of the how to vote cards; it is grossly offensive to those electors who in fact want to go there on polling day and receive a how to vote card, who made up their minds 15 years ago that this was how they are going to vote, and who are never going to vote any other way. They are what the Americans call yellow dog democrats-it does not matter what the circumstances, they are going to vote for their political party, and God bless them. They do not want to be bothered during the course of the election campaign, they do not want rubbish in their letter boxes, and they do not want to be assaulted in the streets prior to polling day. They want to be left alone in the shopping centres because they know full well that on polling day they can go up to the polling booth and get the how to vote card of the party they want to vote for and they can follow it and fill in the numbers. They do not have to go looking around for some great poster inside as to what the advice is, or take those sorts of actions in order to establish the facts that they want.

Indeed, the Democrat amendment goes on to deal with newspapers, journals, magazines, circulars, pamphlets, `dodgers' or other documents, the essential purpose of which is other than to communicate directions or instructions as to how an elector should vote or as to the method of voting. It says, therefore, that those things are not included, it is only the specific how to vote card. As I say, there are those of us who find that part of the discipline of running a political party is whether in fact we are able to get people out to the polling booths to work. I think that is an indication of the success or otherwise of a political organisation. I appreciate the problem that the Democrats obviously face. They do not have enough people to get out and man every polling booth. It is not unusual for any of the political parties to be in that sort of circumstance. The Liberal Party in New South Wales has difficulty manning polling booths in certain areas. I have no doubt that the Labor Party in New South Wales has difficulty manning certain areas in, for instance, strong National Party territory in country electorates. There is no magic in that one way or the other.

These three amendments constitute in the first instance an absolute nonsense in terms of the proposed poster inside the voting compartment and a very considerable restriction upon the freedom and liberty of individual subjects in Australia and certainly will not be supported by the Opposition.
