As I say, this particular proposition put forward is wrong in principle, it is impractical and does not serve the self-interest of the two major parties, and that is that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: -I will respond to the points that have been raised by both Senator Puplick and the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Robert Ray). Firstly, the amendments that are set out here have been adopted from the South Australian Electoral Act where they have already been tested in practice. The types of wild assumptions and mythologies that Senator Puplick was trying to run have not occurred there. The method has proceeded to such an extent that there has not been any need to amend those particular provisions, although other parts of the Electoral Act since that time have been amended.

SPEECH.PARA: The proposition that Senator Robert Ray relied on was very similar except he added the quite extraneous comment that the Labor Party and the Opposition parties make promises which they keep, whereas the Australian Democrats do not. Let us look at the promises that were made during the Fraser years. I happen to remember Senator Ray talking rather volubly about what Fraser had promised and never done; in fact, I have heard the Opposition do exactly the same with regard to promises made by the Hawke Labor Government. Once in government there is no pressure whatsoever to fulfil the promises that were made. Indeed, one reason for the cynicism in the electorate is that the major political parties, having put up a whole raft of promises, never keep them. Therefore there is not the pressure on the major political parties to fulfil their promises that Senator Ray indicated.

Interestingly enough, I would be happy to go through the policies that we raised in the last election and compare them with the Government's policies to see how many of the policies were enacted in legislation in comparison to the Government's policies. I think that we do fairly well. Quite consistently in the last four parliaments day in and day out we have pushed a set of policies that have been clear and unambiguous. A week or so ago Senator Haines got into a lot of trouble by spelling out what our policies would be on a number of items if after the next election a Liberal Government were elected. We were told that we were not allowed to do that. We are not supposed to tell the electorate what we would do and would not do. Senator Ray might remember that in the last election campaign only the Democrats campaigned for a capital gains tax. It was introduced by the Labor Party and people then said to us, `The Labor Party has no mandate to do this'. I cannot be responsible for the fact that people do not bother to read the policies that we campaign on. That is their problem, not ours. We will continue to push very strongly to implement those policies.

The last point I wish to raise relates to Senator Ray's reference to some notion that the environment is now the last refuge of the scoundrel. This, it seems to me, is not where the electorate is at. The electorate very clearly is interested in procedures and methods by which we can conserve the environment. He suggests that the use of more paper, with the introduction of three Sunday papers in Melbourne, somehow exempts political parties, where they have some influence, from doing anything. I do not think it does. We have a responsibility, along with everybody else, to engage in conservation methods where it is possible.

What I have set out in my amendments is a practical method of conservation. It in no way deprives anybody, even the dyed in the wool voters whom Senator Puplick referred to by an American term that my learned colleague Senator Sanders had never heard of although he is a native American and had operated in politics in the United States for a long time. The dyed in the wool voters, who wish to have a direction on those issues, would not be deprived of that direction; it will be there for them. It will not deprive anybody of any information they wish to have. In fact, it is in the engaging in of a fairly massive conservation effort that we propose, yet again, these amendments as we have in the past, long before conservation became a popular electoral exercise.

Clause 58 (Provisions relating to scrutineers).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition opposes clause 58, which just seems to me to be a bit of additional nonsense. Clause 58 provides that a person who is in a polling booth in the capacity of a scrutineer shall wear a badge, supplied by the Electoral Commission, that identifies the person as a scrutineer. The very last thing one wants is a situation in which a person who wants to be a scrutineer goes into the booth at five minutes to six in order to be a scrutineer and the Electoral Commissioner says to him, `I am sorry, we have run out of badges. TALK.START.PARA: —This stretches my memory a long way back to the hearings of the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform. I think the clause was suggested more by the presiding officers than anyone else because, at times, in keeping an eye on the activities in a booth, they face some confusion as to who is a scrutineer and who is an ordinary elector. A badge also identifies scrutineers in case an ordinary elector wishes to ask that person for help, and that was the reason that it was brought in. It is not something to die in a ditch over, obviously, but it was brought in for those two particular reasons-not just out of a desire to create an extra bureaucracy or an extra expense.

SPEECH.PARA: As for running out of badges, I do not think that is a likely proposition. It is rare these days for scrutineers to sit inside the booth all day. It occurs occasionally, but not very often. Mostly scrutineers are there on the basis of looking at the formality of votes and the flow of preferences and at the recheck stages, and that was the reason why the amending Bill contains this provision.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I make another point about this, which seems to me to be perhaps equally, if not more, serious. At the moment, in order to be a scrutineer, one signs a declaration. In that declaration one undertakes to do or not to do certain things. The potential scrutineer identifies himself by name, puts his address and the details of the electorate where he is on the roll, and signs it.
—The candidate countersigns it.

—Indeed, and the candidate countersigns it. As candidates, we know the business that we go through about signing forms, having the necessary rubber stamps made, and ensuring they are acceptable to divisional returning officers or whoever it happens to be. But an individual scrutineer undertakes certain things and is bound by the terms of the conditions of the declaration form which he or she has signed. If we are to have this system where a scrutineer shall wear a badge, if anybody actually wanted to rort the system, somebody could go in and sign that they were a scrutineer, complete a scrutineer's declaration form, get a badge, leave the polling booth, hand the badge to somebody else, and that other person would then have access in and out of the polling booths, unless the presiding officer were particularly vigilant. If he or she did anything that they were not supposed to do, they would simply say, `I did not sign any form. I did not undertake to behave in a certain fashion. I never completed a declaration. I am just here wearing this badge'.

SPEECH.PARA: Unless we are now to have a whole regime where we have to sign for a badge and make a statutory declaration that we will not give the badge to anybody else-and, indeed, that these badges are not going to be simply swapped around for the sake of convenience-it really does not seem to me that, if the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs thinks that it is not worth dying in the ditch over, perhaps he could yield on it. There just does not seem to be a compelling case made out for moving away from a system which has a security element built into it in terms of the scrutineer's declaration to this business of badges and all the nonsense that may well go on with badges.

Badges can be numbered. If someone has completed a declaration at one polling booth, has got a scrutineer's badge and then goes off and presents himself at some other polling booth-because, after all, he has got a badge-the badges can be swapped around. I think that this system is open to considerably more misuse and abuse than the system of a controlled series of declarations. The candidate has a role in terms of signing the declaration and the presiding officer has a role in terms of accepting the declaration and maintaining a proper record of who has been authorised to act as a scrutineer and who has not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support Senator Puplick's remarks, both in terms of the principle and its practicalities. I think that the points he has made as to whether it provides a more secure system than we have now are very real points. The other thing that worries me about this-and I guess it is something that worries me about a lot of the legislation we debate in this place-is that all parties often make proposals for changes and additions to legislation without a real need for it. Particularly in areas like this, which are very technical and detailed areas, unless there is a good reason for making proposals of this nature, I think we are better to leave things as is.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs stretched his memory back to the reports of the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform and why this proposal came forward. In stretching my memory, too, although I was not directly involved, I cannot think of the strong reasons that were presented to that Committee. I think that the practical considerations that Senator Puplick has raised suggest that the Minister should have another look at this clause. Obviously no-one from either side is going to die in a ditch on it, but it does require further thought before we proceed with it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: -There seems to have been a lot of discussion over something that nobody is going to die in a ditch for. My memory is that a suggestion was made by the people in charge of the polling booths that some form of identification worn by scrutineers would be of great assistance to them, particularly in the counting of the ballots after the close of the polls, and this clause is in fact a follow-through on that suggestion. I fail to see Senator Puplick's problems because, since this is an addition to rather than a subtraction from the security which is currently offered, this will enhance the protection and not detract from it. That is how the people with practical experience in the booths saw it, and I think that their suggestion is a perfectly reasonable one and should be accepted.

That the clause stand as printed.

SPEECH.PARA: Clauses 59 to 61-by leave-taken together.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for advice. In clause 59 the following is to be inserted in the Act by proposed section 219:

SPEECH.PARA: A candidate shall not in any way take part in the conduct of an election.

Will the Minister indicate where under this section the `conduct' of an election is specifically defined, if anywhere? Does the definition reflect the old rule of thumb, which I think it was, rather than a specific part of the Act? For example, is a candidate still prohibited by this proposed section from handing out how to vote cards? Is a candidate who is a candidate for a House of Representatives seat, for example, prohibited from acting as a scrutineer for a Senate election taking place on the same day? Is that prohibition encompassed by that? After all, he is a candidate, and the conduct of an election includes the scrutiny of it. If a person is a candidate in, say, the electorate of Banks and he is subsequently asked to act as a party scrutineer for the count of the Senate ballot some time later, is he prohibited from doing so? Similarly, is a Senate candidate prohibited from acting as a scrutineer for one of his party colleagues in the House of Representatives?

The latter actually raises some quite interesting points. I do not know whether Senator Ray's and other honourable senators' experiences in any way have been akin to mine, but there have been many occasions when Senator Graham Richardson and I have sat eyeball to eyeball across a table during the scrutiny of the count in a marginal seat. Therefore, the question is: Am I, at the next Federal election as a candidate in that election, hereby absolved from the pressures of my political party to spend the three weeks following the election campaign acting as a scrutineer in those marginal seats in New South Wales where we tend to put in people who have the required combination of electoral experience and sheer gall?

TALK.START.PARA: —This amendment comes about simply because we are transferring one part of the old section into a new section and retaining the rest of it. My interpretation of it-and it is not based on a terribly learned view-is that `conduct' does refer to scrutineering or acting as an electoral official, which obviously is out. As I have always understood it, a Senate candidate cannot scrutineer until the declaration of the poll and one cannot scrutineer in marginal seats, and cannot scrutineer especially in the electoral office because people there are separating Senate ballot papers which may be relevant to oneself.
—Not if they have all been taken into head office.

—Senator Puplick says they have all been taken into head office but postal votes and absentee votes are still arriving. The only votes taken into head office, by the way, are below the line votes. Above the line votes are retained in each electoral office. The more touchy area is what happens with a House of Representatives candidate? The general rule of thumb is that one cannot scrutineer in one's own electorate but can in another. At some stage that may be put in doubt if absentee votes are being passed on but I think that is a very remote possibility.

SPEECH.PARA: The rule of thumb is that Senate candidates are absolved and House of Representatives candidates can scrutineer only outside their own electorate. State members of Parliament may be scrutineers in Federal elections, and vice versa. It would probably give pleasure to honourable senators to know that they should not scrutineer. Those in the off year who do not come up for election at the time are not only quite free but probably compelled to scrutineer at great length. I would not mind a provision that one cannot scrutinise a Senate election at all, because I do not think it helps one iota these days. The system is almost impossible to follow and when one is knocking out minor party votes one could be signing one's own death warrant, not knowing in advance what is happening. Very few people are skilled enough to know that. I take the term `conduct' to deal mostly with scrutineering. It also rules out members or candidates being polling officials, presiding officers or any other member of staff in the employ of the Electoral Commission for the period of the campaign.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about handing out how to vote cards?

—I would not think it covers that. If it does, and has traditionally done so, I suppose we would all have been convicted in one sense or another. One would be pretty lucky to find a candidate who does not hand out how to vote cards to get rid of his or her nerves. However, there is an exception. In 1974 we won a seat precisely by sending the candidate bushwalking for the two weeks before the election and on election day. But in general I think we can take whatever interpretation is necessary. The clause does not prohibit handing out how to vote cards, which is not an official part of the conduct of a poll. But scrutineering is recognised specifically in the Act for that purpose and therefore I think that what I said before applies to that.

Clause 62 (Provisions related to sections 224 and 225).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (3) Page 40, after paragraph 62 (c) insert the following new paragraph:
``(ca) by omitting paragraph (a) from subsection (5);''

On the face of it, this amendment makes absolutely no sense whatsoever, so perhaps I might explain it. Proposed section 62 of the Electoral and Referendum Amendment Act makes amendments to section 226 of the principal Act, the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918. Section 226 of the principal Act relates to the way in which votes are taken and dealt with in hospitals that are polling places and where mobile booths are in use. Section 226 deals with provisions which are covered in sections 224 and 225 of the principal Act. As I say, they both deal with mobile booths and hospitals that are polling places. The current regime provides that candidates are precluded from entering hospitals, special hospitals, nursing homes or similar institutions for canvassing once the writs for an election have been issued. Indeed, subsection 5 (a) of section 226 of the principal Act says:

. . . the reference in that sub-section to polling day and to all days to which the polling is adjourned were a reference to the period commencing on the day of the issue of the writ and ending at the expiration of polling day or, if the polling is adjourned, the expiration of the last day to which the polling is adjourned . . .

The Opposition amendment proposes that subsection 5 (a) of section 226 should be deleted. It is our view that this is a fair and reasonable provision, given the expanded nature of activities taking place within hospitals and designated institutions for the purposes of polling, and the extended nature of the activities that are to take place related to both mobile booths and hospitals that are polling places and other hospitals. Clauses 60 and 61, which we have just passed, make some amendments to the way in which mobile booths are to operate or be operated in hospitals that are polling places and other hospitals.

We say that the period from the issue of the writ up until polling day is too long a period for candidates to be precluded from canvassing, particularly because increasing numbers of persons are likely to be voting in hospitals, special hospitals, nursing homes and similar institutions. We believe that people in those areas are just as entitled to visits by candidates and that, provided candidates obtain the permission of the hospital authorities, they should not be precluded by the Electoral Act from entering hospitals for the purposes of promoting their candidacy.

I have moved the amendment for that reason. I believe that it would be fair and proper to extend both to candidates and to the people who are residents of these nursing homes, hospitals, special hospitals or similar institutions the right to be contacted by a candidate during the course of the period from the issue of the writ until polling day. As I understand it, legislation in most of the States provides that the executive officer, matron or responsible senior officer at these institutions is perfectly capable of denying access, and that denial is quite absolute in these regards. We do not believe that this part of the Act should continue in the form in which it is at the moment.

TALK.START.PARA: —These sections of the Act have a long history. When the original Bill was passed in 1983 there was a great deal of dissatisfaction in the coalition as to its provisions. It was discussed at great length in an atmosphere of some compromise in a joint select committee. Certain other concessions were made, such as the availability of postal votes, but on this subject the Government strongly disagrees with the amendment. The amendment takes us back to the potential for corruption that existed before. It is not an area where we have ever had equal access; it has been a very one-sided thing over the years and we believe that the sort of compromise we came to on the electoral reform committee should obtain. Clauses 63 to 65-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 66 (Questions to be put to voter)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition opposes clause 66. Clause 66 is the regime put in place for the questions which are to be put to a voter by the presiding officer at the polling booth on polling day. The existing section 229 (1) of the principal Act provides:

SPEECH.PARA: The presiding officer shall put the following questions to each person attending before him and claiming to vote in an election or elections:
(a) What is your full name?
(b) Where do you live?
(c) Have you voted in this election? or Have you voted before in these elections? (as the case requires).
It is now intended to replace that with a section of the Act which will delete subsection (1) from section 229 and insert the following:
Questions to be put to voter.
(1) The presiding officer shall put to each person claiming to vote such questions as the presiding officer thinks necessary to enable the person's identity and place of living to be established.

It then goes to seek to omit subsections (4) and (5). These distinguished between the person claiming the right to vote and another person on the certified list. It also inserts a new section which states:
If a person claiming to vote refuses to answer fully a question put to him or her under this section, the person's claim to vote shall be rejected.

A number of points arise here. The first is that for the first time this omits the requirement for a polling officer to ask an elector whether he has voted before in the election. I do not see any justification for that. The answer may be, `If somebody is going to lie and try to vote more than once, then they will not respond yes to the question ``Have you voted before in this election?'' '. Nevertheless, I believe it is simply an additional safeguard for those who might, for example, in their minds quite legitimately, turn up to cast a second vote. In the case of a person who has cast a vote by post or by pre-poll voting the roll may not have been appropriately amended in a way which demonstrates that that person's name has already been crossed off. There is no justification for having deleted that requirement.

Secondly, the obligation which the current Commonwealth Electoral Act casts upon presiding officers is that they must ask, `What is your full name?' and `Where do you live?'. That is very different from the presiding officers simply asking such questions that they think necessary to establish a person's identity and place of living. For example, a person may turn up and the presiding officer may say to him, `Is your name Robert Ray? Do you live at such and such an address?', if he happens to recognise him. Or the presiding officer may ask, `What is your name?'. The person may say, `My name is Michael Tate'. The presiding officer may look down his list and say, `Do you live at such and such an address? Have you been back there in the course of the last six months?'. He presumably gets the correct answer. It is then left entirely in the hands of the presiding officer to establish what he or she thinks are questions appropriate to establish the person's identity and place of living.

Whereas, at the moment, the Act actually enjoins that officer to ask three specific questions. It does not give him any discretion as to what they should be; it says precisely what they are-`What is your full name? Where do you live?'. It then goes on to add the qualification, `Have you voted before in this election?'. I do not believe that that change is justified in any sense. Clause 66 (b) (3) states:
If a person claiming a vote refuses to answer fully a question put to him or her under this section, the person's claim shall be rejected.

The clause does not state that the claim shall be put to one side-this is a very important point-and subsequently determined by reference to the master roll or whatever it happens to be for inclusion, as is the case at the moment when there are disputes about votes. It states that it shall be rejected because a person has refused to answer fully a question put to him under this section. If the presiding officer asks me, `What is your name?' and I say, `My name is Chris Puplick' and the officer then asks, `Do you reside at Murdoch Street, Cremorne?' and I say, `Yes' and the presiding officer, for the purpose of satisfying himself, asks, `Who else resides at that address?' and I say to the presiding officer, `None of your damn business', it is perfectly competent for the presiding officer under the amending legislation to say, `Right. You have not answered fully the question which I believe it is necessary to ask in order to establish your proper identity and place of living. Therefore your vote is rejected'.

He may well believe that in order to establish my identity and place of living he should ask me other questions to satisfy himself. As I said, one such question may well be, `Who else resides at that address?'. If I refuse to answer fully that question he can then reject my vote. The legislation does not provide that he shall put it aside or have it cast as a section vote or that it shall be looked at subsequently by the divisional returning officer; it states that it shall be rejected on the say-so of the presiding officer that I failed to answer fully the question which he wished to put to me to satisfy himself as to my identity and place of residence.

At the moment the Act states quite specifically the questions to be asked. It can be said that they are not adequately answered only if I decline to give my full name and the place in which I live; it does not put a discretion in the hands of the presiding officer to determine what questions he thinks are appropriate and indeed to determine what he thinks are full, proper and adequate answers to those questions. This is a discretion put into the hands of the presiding officer for which no justification has been made. The words to be added state:
If a person claiming to vote refuses to answer fully a question put to him or her under this section, the person's claim to vote shall be rejected.

Since when have we given presiding officers the right to reject an elector's vote because the elector fails to answer a question, which is not a question in a statutory form but a question which, according to this, is a question such that the presiding officer thinks necessary?

Senator Ray previously talked about party self-interest. This may be an invitation to presiding officers to exclude from the count votes from people who do not have English as their primary language and Aboriginal voters. The discretion provided here is far greater than has ever been provided in electoral law. That in particular will cause considerable problems when presiding officers try to establish facts from people who are not particularly competent in English. To establish which one of the Nguyen family is from Capital Street, Mount Druitt, the presiding officer may need to ask four, five or six questions other than, `What is your full name? Where do you live?' He may say to himself, `Look, I have a dozen of these people listed on my electoral roll at this address and they all have names that look pretty much the same to me. They are all Nguyen something-or-other and I will therefore ask additional questions. This poor joker cannot give me answers that satisfy me. I will not have the vote set aside, make him fill in a declaration or a scrutiny or put it in an absentee envelope or whatever; his vote shall be rejected'.

The presiding officer may not be satisfied with the answers given by somebody in an Aboriginal community because the presiding officer will be going outside what is provided by way of the statute, which, at the moment, is perfectly clear. It provides for the questions, `What is your full name? Where do you live?' For the point of this argument, I leave aside the additional question, `Have you voted before in this election?'. The Opposition does not believe that putting in the hands of the presiding officers the discretion, first, to determine without the precise backing of the statute what questions are necessary in order to establish a person's full name and place of living and, secondly, to say, `That is not in my judgment an adequate answer', is an acceptable variation to this part of the Electoral Act. The consequence of that will be that a person's vote will be rejected. After all, this part of the Electoral Act goes absolutely to the heart of the electoral process-the method by which an elector is given a ballot paper, is allowed to complete that ballot paper, and is allowed to participate as an elector. I could choke up the courts of disputed returns with allegations that my vote was rejected because when the presiding officer said to me, `Who else resides at that address?', I told him to nick off and he said, `Right, buddy, your vote has just gone out the window'. Under this system in marginal electorates we will invite that type of dispute in courts of disputed returns.

The current Act is perfectly clear: it requires three questions to be asked. The first question is: what is your full name? A person can answer that without any difficulty at all. The second question is: where do you live? The third question is: have you voted before? This question requires a yes or no answer. Provided the first two answers tally with the electoral roll and provided the answer to the third question is, `No, I have not voted before', a vote is admitted. This new system puts a discretion in the hands of the presiding officer to make up his own questions and then to make a judgment as to whether they have been adequately answered. I do not believe that that is a satisfactory way for our Electoral Act to be recast.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Women in Sport-Pharmaceutical Benefits Regulations-Secondary School Leavers-Radio Australia-Romania-Lesueur Community

PROCTEXT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to draw attention to some very interesting reading that can be found if one turns to the back of the newspaper and moves from the back to the front. I am advised by any number of colleagues that most Australian readers start on the back page of the newspaper and move in. Of recent times I must say I have been rather puzzled by what one can find moving from the back to the front. I referred in this place a few days ago to an article by one Jeff Wells in the Australian on 11 December 1989. Jeff Wells seemed to be very confused about a report from the Western Australian Women in Sport Advisory Council on a $24,000 study to look at why women drop out of sport, particularly in their adolescent years. While I do not necessarily start at the back pages I invariably repair to them, and Jeff Wells usually entertains me with his commentary on things sporting in Australia, but I have no idea what happened to Jeff Wells's brain on this day. He seemed to go completely off the deep end. Comparing his article on this research project in Western Australia with an article in the Age the day after analysing the same report, one would have to think we were talking about two different reports altogether. Anybody who is concerned about the report of the Western Australian Women in Sport Advisory Council I suggest should look at the Age summary of that research on 12 December 1989. It is vastly different from Jeff Wells getting carried away about words such as `lesbian', which drove him to some six columns about four inches long, going into the problems of a young man in sport. Mostly, the article was excessive in the extreme, but it finished up with the following paragraph:

SPEECH.PARA: So let us have some serious research here, you big researchers you. Is that a barbell in your pocket or are you just happy to see me?

That sort of question seems entirely appropriate to Mae West but it does make me wonder a whole lot about Jeff Wells. It seems also to suggest that, no matter what we have done for women in sport, the media does not take it seriously. This Government has done a considerable amount, starting, I am pleased to say, with the report of the inquiry that I chaired back in 1984-85 into the importance of women in sport. Subsequent to that inquiry, funding for the Women's Sports Promotion Unit was provided, which was pleasing to the thousands of Australians who take women's sport seriously. That seriousness is not yet reflected in our media coverage, in particular our print media coverage. The Age article tells us that research shows that column inches in the print media devoted to women's sport have increased slightly and recent research in Tasmania points out that in the Tasmanian dailies the figure has gone from 2 per cent of column inches in 1984 to 5 per cent of column inches in 1989. I congratulate Tasmania. If Tasmanian newspapers are not at the forefront, at least they are level pegging with other newspapers.

That is about as far as we have got with women's sport in terms of print media coverage. That is quite a shame, particularly in view of the achievements of women in sport in this country. I think if we took out of the calculations the amount of newspaper space devoted to horse races we could probably modify those figures somewhat, but even excluding that, we would still have to say that the coverage of women's sport is insufficient. That is despite the extraordinary achievements of women at the elite level of sport in this country. I find it bizarre and somewhat disappointing that a journalist as reputable as Jeff Wells seems to be driven to this kind of nonsense.

Lest it should seem that I want to comment only on Jeff Wells, I was pulled up short when I turned to another back page in the Age on 2 November 1989, where there was an article headed `Hi-tech nobbler shocks racing'. This discussed an extraordinary new way of nobbling horses at Ascot with some kind of battery device in the ear of a horse. A person in the grandstand with a set of binoculars and the right kind of button to press could zap the battery and shock the horse to do bizarre things at the end of the straight and certainly not devote itself to winning the race. Referring to the Secretary of the Victoria Racing Club, Rod Johnson, the article said:
. . . it was an amazing story and his club would be closely monitoring any development on the matter.

`Australian racing prides itself on its strong control, but there are some things we are just unable to guard against, and with the new technologies now available it's frightening what might happen,' Johnson said.
He went on to say:
`It's a bit like when the suffragettes were throwing themselves in front of racehorses to get publicity for the women's movement.
`We will try to take whatever precautions are necessary . . .

I worry about the Secretary of the Victoria Racing Club, who is clearly hanging on to a 70-year-old anxiety. I have no evidence that suffragettes are flinging themselves in front of racehorses on any racetrack anywhere. Indeed, if Mr Johnson was concerned about the problems of suffragettes, all he had to do was give them the vote. I am interested to find that there is somebody in Australia who can actually postulate suffragettes flinging themselves in front of racehorses as one of the possible ways of upsetting the due process and proper management of racing in this country. No doubt, of course, he was appreciating that this appalling problem had happened at Ascot, where the suffragette did fling herself in front of the racehorse. As far as I remember, she was the only person who did it and, for her efforts to draw attention to the suffragette movement, she died. I really do worry, reading comments such as that in the sporting newspapers in 1989. I hope Mr Johnson is comforted to know that since women have had the vote and the suffragette movement has taken its place in the scheme of things, the world has not changed too much; so the Victorian Racing Club need not fret about issues like that causing problems with their horses. Indeed, it might be much more fun to examine what has been happening since the examination into the drugging of horses, which had a substantial impact on the racing scene in our country.

I turned further back in one of the newspapers. I decided that the sports pages were too exciting. With Jeff Wells postulating problems about barbells and the Secretary of the Victoria Racing Club worrying about suffragettes, it seemed to me that I should retire to the financial pages for something more serene. In the Australian on 15 December I found a splendid article in the financial pages headed `Only trifles can fulfil a certain need'. This article by Bryce Courtenay started off with an immutable rule of marketing that goes like this:
. . . where a need exists it is filled.
Like most rules in business, it does not take an MBA to work it out.

For some strange reason I read on, I am not quite sure why. You will be pleased to know, Madam Acting Deputy President, that the article was devoted to what happens when men go out to run and the sorts of things they talk about. It is a very interesting article indeed. The first column was devoted to who makes the preferred Christmas pudding and how this compares to a Christmas cake. People were claiming total authenticity for the definitive Christmas pudding according to their grandmothers or mothers. In column two of this article we were shocked to discover this:
`Have you noticed how no one has mentioned the cake or pudding made by their wife?' A stunned silence followed. All you could hear was the pitter-patter of Nike, Adidas and New Balance.
However, it was all right because somebody then added:
`Not just that . . . what about bread and butter pudding?'

So we forgot wives and hastened back to food and devoted the next couple of column inches to bread and butter puddings and the preferment of our childhood, until somebody mentioned trifle, when all the runners stopped. Trifle stories and trifle recipes were swapped. I can refer anybody to the Australian of 15 December for preferred recipes for trifle. There are a certain number of honourable senators here this evening for whom that is no novelty at all; we have been making them for years. Indeed, I believe some of the Hansard reporters and the Clerk at the table would also know how to make a good trifle. I am perfectly prepared to put on record that these people are women. Any men in the audience who are prepared to say that they can conjure up a good trifle I will hear. Is Senator Tate a good trifle maker or is he just devoted to eating a good trifle?

TALK.START.PARA: —I make it with sherry in the bottom over the sponge.

—Senator Tate makes it with sherry in the bottom. That is almost the perfect trifle. However, it seems to me odd to find in the financial pages an article devoted to the problems of runners and how to make the preferred trifle. Curiously enough, the thing that struck me about this article was that it seemed to be devoted to what things were like when I was a kid. The article finishes:

SPEECH.PARA: The first nanna who establishes the National Cooking School of Childhood Food will be filling a need both urgent and of great importance.
There is a generation of Australians growing up who have never even heard of a chip sandwich!
Happy Christmas everyone, may your puddings be pungent and your trifles terrific.

I am entirely with the sentiments of this article but I have to say that the poor old wives get an awful beating in it. Mothers are fine and presumably daughters are not too bad-they suck on puddings and look for sixpences. But, again, I am a bit concerned about the view that men in the Australian community have of women. I refer them to an article in the Adelaide Advertiser on Monday, 11 December which talked about the launch of a Tomato Bank in Japan where Japanese people clearly have a different understanding of the virtues of women. The article states:
The Tomato Bank opened its first branch in Tokyo last week and already is deluged with depositors who think it is just too cute for words.
On its first day of business, the new Tokyo branch took in deposits of 134 billion yen ($1.12 billion), a sum equal to 26 per cent of all its previous assets.

This bank, the Sanyo Sogo Bank, based in Okayama, decided to change its name and its logo in a particular and deliberate attempt to attract deposits from women. The bank is celebrating a massive increase in profits. I suggest that this could indicate a different understanding and appreciation of women by the Japanese. They are not too concerned, as it seems is Jeff Wells, let alone the Secretary of the Victorian Racing Club, about problems associated with women but are more concerned with women's attributes and the financial assistance they can offer women.

Finally, I think by way of no thesis at all, I conclude with some comments from The University of Melbourne Gazette which arrived on my table as I was happily pondering these things that one can find if one starts reading the papers from the back. In this magazine there is an article entitled `No angel . . .' by Peter Connor who traces the history of the familiar figure that is the heraldic symbol of the Melbourne University. As this is my alma mater I was very pleased to read about it. The figure for Melbourne University is that of Victory. The University of Melbourne took this as its heraldic figure because it was not too long after the State of Victoria separated from the State of New South Wales that the University of Melbourne was established. As the State of Victoria had been called after the then British Queen, the university also looked to Victory-Victoria in Latin-for some kind of heraldic symbol. The university chose the symbol of Victory.

For those who are not sure, Victory is the god of victory whose usual name is Nike-perhaps more often associated with running shoes and intercontinental ballistic missiles. In ancient times the Greeks understood women, their importance and the place they played in society. Indeed, the gods of ancient times were nearly always women. The Greeks indicated and symbolised women with the sorts of attributes that I would be very pleased if our sports journos-our male journos-could comfortably arrive at for our women-that is, women of achievement, women of virtue, women of talent and ability and women who were just quite normal and naturally marvellous in the scheme of things. I am delighted and appreciative of Peter Connor for bringing to my attention the heraldic symbol of Melbourne University because it interested and informed me further about a symbol of Victory, the god-or goddess if we prefer that sexist term-Nike who represented victory; not victory in war but as it is described in the article which I referred to:

The inspiration for the design of Victoria on our University coat of arms comes fittingly from the peaceable Nikes of the early Greek coins, soberly clad and posed calmly with wreath and palm-branch, indicating . . . victory as a characteristic, an aim and a fact.

That is the sort of womanhood that I would like to represent in this place; that is the sort of womanhood that I think Australia and the Australian Government stand for. I am sure that you, Madam Acting Deputy President, represent that kind of womanhood and speak for it. It is normal and natural in the scheme of things for women to achieve-to try, to succeed and not be regarded as freaks for doing so.

TALK.START.PARA: —In many walks of life people are assessed by their peers, by their superiors and by those over whom they may have some authority. This assessment does not necessarily occur in a formal way, but it is an ongoing process. We in this chamber should be aware that our performance is being continually assessed by our peers, by our party supporters and by the public. For some, the assessment process is more formal. Among these are the students in thousands of schools throughout the nation. The assessment of their attainments has long term consequences, especially for those who are about to leave school and join the work force or attempt further study at the post-secondary level. It is about this group-those who are about to leave secondary school-that I intend to make some remarks this evening.

SPEECH.PARA: If the assessment process for our secondary school leavers does have long term consequences-and I hold that it does-it is vitally important that the assessment or examination techniques which are used be as accurate as possible. Firstly, we have to be quite clear about what we are attempting to measure. Secondly, we have to ensure that our measures are both valid and reliable. I will not go into these matters in depth, suffice it to say that there is an abundance of educational theory about testing procedures which allow those charged with the responsibility of assessing student performance to do so with a reasonable degree of accuracy. I say `a reasonable degree of accuracy' because assessment is not an exact science. What we must attempt to do is strive for perfection, but we must also accept the fact that we will fall short of that goal. Because of the imperfect nature of testing procedures, some students will believe they have been harshly treated. So, too, will the parents of some students. Their claims may be correct, but until educational theory takes us further, all educators can do is say that they did strive for excellence.

About four years ago, as Chairman of the then Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts, I presented a report dealing with assessment in secondary colleges in the Australian Capital Territory (ACT). The members of the Committee at that time were myself, Senator Teague, who is in the chamber tonight and was the Deputy Chairman, and Senators Knowles, McKiernan, Parer and Reynolds. In our report, we noted that external examinations were abolished in the ACT in 1977 and, since then, a system of continuous assessment has been used to assess student performance in the final two years of secondary school.

The Committee noted that in Australia only the ACT and Queensland rely entirely on continuous school-based assessment to rank candidates for entry to tertiary education. Other States and the Northern Territory continue to rely mainly on external examinations, with an element of continuous assessment. The Committee stated that it had a preference for an assessment system which combines continuous assessment and external examinations, rather than the system which was used in the ACT at that time and, indeed, is still used. I shall not traverse the arguments proposed by the Committee. They are outlined in the report.

I shall mention, however, that the Committee's suggestion met with heated disagreement by the then head of the ACT Schools Authority. Opposition to the Committee's position was not unexpected, if for no other reason than that the Committee noted that it had found the Authority's 1983-84 annual report to be `deficient in several respects'.

In the not too distant future, for tertiary entrance, the Australian Capital Territory will have the only system in Australia relying solely on suitably scaled school-based assessment. One may ask: will the Australian Capital Territory then be the only educational system in Australia in step, or the only one out of step? The new Labor Government in Queensland has announced that the Tertiary entrance system in that State is to be changed. The exact nature of the new system will be developed next year, so that it may be introduced for students commencing year 11 in 1991.

It is not before time that the current tertiary entrance system in Queensland should be scrapped. The tertiary entrance score-or TE score, as it is known in Queensland-has been misused and abused. It has been misused by employers who have taken it as a measure of scholastic ability, but who have taken little or no notice of particular subjects the young people chose to study, and how well they acquitted themselves in those subjects. It has been abused by educators who have concentrated on beating the system to have their students gain spurious TE scores at the end of their final two years of secondary school.

The TE score is supposed to be a predictor of academic success at the tertiary level. It is a figure which is derived by complex but mathematically sound calculations, taking into account students' marks as obtained in continuous assessment, the relative difficulty of different subjects and the ability levels of the schools in which the students completed their final two years of secondary education. In Queensland the TE score is a scaled score, with a maximum of 990. Scores are awarded to students from 990 downwards in steps of five. A score of 990 places the student in the top one per cent of the 17-year-old Queensland cohort, whether in school or not. Each step of five represents a further one half of a per cent of that cohort. Thus, for example, a student who has a score of 985 is in the top 1 1/2 per cent. A score of 980 indicates that the student is in the top 2 per cent, and so on.

With a scarcity of tertiary places in Queensland, entry to various courses has been granted on the basis of the level of a student's TE score. In 1989, for example at the University of Queensland, only those with a TE score of 990 or 985 were admitted to medicine. A score of 975 was required for law-that is, a student had to be in the top 2 1/2 per cent of the 17-year-old age group. To study arts at the same institution, a student had to receive a TE score of 880 or above-that is, be in the top 12 per cent of the 17-years of age cohort. Some other institutions had lower entrance scores for their courses but, taking into account the examples I have given, it is not surprising that competition among students is high. The best way to free up the system is to make more tertiary places available-something the Hawke Government has been doing since it assumed office in 1983, and something the Goss Labor Government in Queensland has already done in its first few weeks of office.

As part of the process of obtaining a TE score, students have to sit for the Australian Scholastic Aptitude Test or ASAT, as it is generally known. The results obtained in this test are used in the mathematical calculations to which I referred earlier. Individual students are not assigned an ASAT score but, all other things being equal, the higher a school's average ASAT score, the higher the TE scores of students in that school. It is regrettable that there have been professionally questionable, if not downright dishonest, practices which have occurred in Queensland schools in relation to the Australian scholastic aptitude test. I digress for a moment to indicate that to use profesionally questionable standards is, by no means, a new phenomenon. I can remember that in my early educational studies I was being lectured on how, in a particular country, students were chosen for various courses by the use of general ability tests-often referred to as intelligence tests. The system broke down because groups of students were coached in how to score well on these tests. This practice made a nonsense of the tests' norms and made it impossible to differentiate between students when some were coached and some were not.

It is fairly well known that coaching on how to complete the ASAT is widespread in Queensland. Some schools had multiple practice sessions, the hypothesis being that practice would lead to higher ASAT scores and thus to higher TE scores for the school. No doubt, some teachers viewed such coaching with disfavour, but could they afford to place their students at a disadvantage by not following a similar course of action? It is probably a case of `When the world is foolish it is folly to be wise'. Students in some schools, however, had little or no practice and were thus at a real disadvantage compared with their peers in other schools. This makes an absolute nonsense of the distribution of TE scores. Some students are awarded higher scores than they should and the TE scores of others are lower than they should be.

The zealous competition which exists for high TE scores has, in the past, also led to criminal activity. I am not sure whether all of this activity has been detected, but in 1986, for example, an ASAT test paper was stolen when a break-in occurred at a Queensland government school. It appeared from police investigations that the sole purpose of the break-in was the theft of the soon to be used ASAT paper. Photocopies of the test paper were promptly circulating in the school.
I am by no means the first person to doubt the validity of the ASAT testing process in Queensland. Three years ago, a former State colleague said:
Allegations of schools successfully defrauding the system are so rife and so serious that nothing short of a full scale police investigation is required.

Indeed, if it were not for the fact that the TE score is on the way out in Queensland, I would mention some areas where inquiries could be made in relation to the recently issued TE scores in that state. I believe, however, that the time of senior executives in the Queensland Education Department, now under the excellent ministerial direction of Labor's Paul Braddy, would be far better directed towards the establishment of an alternative system of assessment in the upper secondary school.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chapman Sen H.G.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today, 20 December 1989, marks the fiftieth birthday of Radio Australia, the ABC's overseas service. While some would undoubtedly argue that to reach this age is a milestone in itself, one must seriously ask whether Australia's short-wave expert will see further years of effective operation. Any nation's overseas broadcasting service which cannot transmit, due to aged or inadequate range transmitters, goes the way of the dinosaur.

SPEECH.PARA: The Federal Government's inaction in failing to provide Radio Australia with adequate resources to ensure its broadcasts can be heard clearly, particularly in northern China, condemns Radio Australia to a bleak and unprofessional future, lacking both independence and viability. Its short-wave services are claimed to reach as far north as Mongolia and the north-west of Afghanistan but, due to unreliable transmissions into parts of northern China, its signal is not effectively received in Beijing.

Radio Australia broadcasts in nine languages and reaches an estimated 50 million regular listeners. It broadcasts 24 hours a day in English and at various other times in Chinese, Cantonese, Indonesian, Pidgin, French, Japanese, Thai and Vietnamese. Its annual budget is about $25m, of which half is dedicated to transmission. Telecom provides half of the funds while the Australian taxpayer provides the other half. This compares to the BBC's World Service budget of $228m-$25m compared with $228m. The World Service, however, has a number of other distinct advantages-it broadcasts in 36 languages, not nine; and although permanently strapped for funds, even with its $228m, it has continuing support from both the BBC and the British Government, whereas Radio Australia has been quite sadly neglected by this Hawke Labor Government and by its own parent, the ABC.

This is quite astonishing when its programs reach more of our neighbours than any other form of national undertaking, whether that be sport, commerce, diplomacy or the arts. It is a key element in Australia's projection of its image to our neighbours. It rivals the BBC and Voice of America as a premier source of information to short-wave listeners, and yet it has been left to languish in virtual penury, with inadequate transmitters and, hence, weakened viability. Its audience is vast, particularly in those countries near our shores-throughout Asia and the Pacific. Its role following the Tiananmen tragedy was to establish that the truth was being denied to Chinese citizens by their own media. Listeners also tuned in to Radio Australia following the democratic turmoil in Fiji and the disruption to its media.

Over six months have passed since the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) said that he had asked the responsible Ministers, which included Senator Evans, to urgently provide options for action on Radio Australia's inadequate transmission facilities. His request was for immediate, albeit temporary, measures to be adopted to improve Radio Australia's signal into northern China. However, on 7 December, Senator Evans' answer to my question concerning Radio Australia demonstrated his total ignorance on the subject and indicated nothing more than inaction on the part of this Government. That is despite the fact that Senator Evans was one of the responsible Ministers who had been asked to urgently provide options for action.

Following the June massacre in China, Radio Canada International, which had never previously broadcast there but had planned to do so from April 1990, took steps to provide an immediate service. Its efforts to provide regular services took less than four months, and on 1 October it was broadcasting strongly into China following arrangements with NHK in Japan. Meanwhile, Australia continues to drag the chain. Senator Evans's supplementary reply yesterday that `There are no immediate practical options for significantly improving Radio Australia's signal coverage to northern China from within Australia' could quite easily be applied to Canada. Yet lack of geographical proximity did not stop Canada from making alternative arrangements in the short term and in less than four months to ensure that broadcasts from Radio Canada International went into China.

Since commencing broadcasts to China in 1956, Radio Australia has built a substantial audience but, following the brutal oppression of human rights in June, it is imperative that the Federal Government provide Radio Australia with sufficient funding to enable it to transmit at sufficient power not to be jammed by the Chinese dictators. Six months is more than sufficient time for the Federal Government to take steps under these circumstances, but it appears that procrastination, unfortunately, is the order of the day.

Radio Australia has survived five major reviews in 14 years and recent recommendations that immediate attention be given to the development of cost effective proposals aimed at preventing the degradation of programs transmitted from Shepparton and Darwin have been proposed. The ABC has agreed and recommends that there be an immediate development of a site in northern Queensland to cover the Pacific and East Asia; that there be established an offshore facility to transmit to northern China: and that the provision of additional transmitters at Darwin should redress current levels of downtime into South East Asia. Of course, these and other necessary refurbishments will cost money-and lots of it. The current state of Radio Australia's transmitters have been a national and international embarrassment, requiring some $30m to upgrade them to the point of efficiency. But, despite placing Radio Australia regularly under the microscope with the same old transmission problems being exposed, the Government remains locked in its intractable position. This Labor Government lacks the conviction to provide increased funding for a very necessary facility.

Despite widely publicised and emotional protestations by both the Prime Minister and the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) following the Tiananmen incident, nothing has been done to ensure that Radio Australia's transmissions to the north are improved, so that the people of China can be assured of hearing the truth about their brutal regime. It is fairly evident that, due to the limited transmitter capacity which Radio Australia has at its disposal for broadcasts to the Asia Pacific region, a system of priorities operates. Under this system, the South and South West Pacific, with its limited population, enjoys first priority, followed by South East Asia, while north Asia-China and Japan-with its massive population, comes a poor third. In fact, Radio Australia risks losing an audience of some 25 million people simply because of inadequate transmission facilities into northern China. This is because the service's Chinese operations are broadcast from 15- and 21-year-old transmitters sited in Darwin and Carnarvon, which are now simply inadequate.

In order for Radio Australia to maintain parity with Voice of America and world service programs, it should be operating 365 days a year on up-to-date equipment. In comparison, the BBC has just spent some $15m to install a new relay station in Hong Kong and in the United States, the State Department's funded Voice of America, has invested $100m in upgrading its short wave transmitters. Radio France International has also increased its budget, up 45 per cent over the past three years and Radio Netherland and Deutsche Welle are also currently expending vast sums in the expansion of their world broadcasting facilities. Radio Australia continues to operate outside this mainstream using outmoded and inadequate equipment, locking itself into the role of a regional broadcaster with its targets firmly set. Can honourable senators imagine Channel 9 or any other of the Australian television stations using 20-year-old equipment?

Despite a seven-month ABC review, which was completed in October, finding out once again that the reliability of Radio Australia's transmissions was more than doubtful and that this impacted on its overall viability, Radio Australia continues to battle wearily on. Its successes are many and, despite being unceremoniously dragged into the bureaucratic bunfights which are regularly inflicted on it, it has managed to reach this well-respected and, some would say, wise age of 50. Set up in 1939, the original objective was to counter Nazi Germany's propaganda and to give the nation `an independent voice with which to present the allied cause and carry news of home to Australian servicemen stationed overseas'. When Prime Minister Menzies opened the then Australia Calling's inaugural broadcast, with the words `the time has come to speak for ourselves', he set in concrete a solid future for the projection of Australia's national image.

Unfortunately, Radio Australia, although celebrating a birthday today, has been chronically under-resourced for the most part of the past 20 years. Its 220 journalist, announcer and operator staff produce some 18,000 radio hours per year, of what is primarily a reliable news service and programs promoting Australia's culture and its public issues, for about $600 per hour-which non-one can deny is a very economical operation. Mail has tended to reflect the course of political events in the regions receiving broadcasts and during the 1950s and 1960s, most of Radio Australia's mail came from Indonesia, Malaysia and Singapore, but in the early 1970s, letters temporarily increased from Burma, only to wane and build up again later.

It should be noted that, following decisions taken by China in 1978 to modernise, some 70,000 letters a month awaited the resident ABC correspondent based there. Even today, Chinese listeners contribute by far the greatest number of letters-nearly 80,000 letters were received from China in 1988-which is about 44 per cent of all listener mail received by Radio Australia. It will be a great shame for Australia if the Hawke Government does not display the courage, conviction and tenacity and put its money where its mouth is. Radio Australia may be continually praised for being a terrific asset, but it will continue to be a national disgrace unless positive action is taken on its transmitters.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with enormous sadness that Australians today heard the continuing news of the massacre that occurred in Timisoara, Romania on the weekend. The first reports yesterday had hundreds of innocent Romanian citizens killed by the Army of Romania after protesting the inflexible and overbearing totalitarianism of the Ceausescu Government in that country. Today's report from Yugoslavian news agencies states:

SPEECH.PARA: Up to 2,000 people have been killed in Romania since security forces with tanks and helicopters crushed anti-government demonstrators at the weekend.

The Senate passed a motion today condemning this massacre and called upon the Romanian Government to adhere to the civil rights commitments, such as the Helsinki Accords, which that country has subscribed to. The motion moved by my colleague, the Opposition spokesman on foreign affairs, Senator Hill, states:
That the Senate-
1. condemns the slaughter by the Romanian Government of its own people who were demonstrating for democracy and increased freedom;

2. calls upon the Romanian Government to adhere to the internationally accepted standards of human rights and to comply with the Helsinki Accords and other international agreements to which Romania is a party;
3. urges the international community to join in protest to demonstrate that such gross abuses of human rights will not be tolerated by civilised societies.

I am conscious tonight not only that this motion was adopted unanimously by the Australian Senate, but also that it would have been supported by thousands of Australians and not least those who have immigrated to this country from Transylvania. This terrible tragedy is the worst news that has come from any country with regard to the suppression of the rights of a country's citizens since the dramatic and equally tragic news of the massacre in Tiananmen Square in Beijing by the Chinese Army on 4 June last. It also occurred on a weekend. We are still very conscious of that terrible event. We are also aware that the Government of Romania, without any kind of apology, publicly applauded the actions of the Chinese Army and Chinese Communist Party leaders who called for that action in Beijing in June. Here we see a similar brutal ruthlessness by the last Romanian Stalinist totalitarian dictatorship in Europe. It is a great contrast to the refreshing waves of new freedoms achieved by the peoples of eastern Europe, especially in Poland, Hungary, in the last fortnight in Czechoslavakia and, to some extent, in the Soviet Union. We have this barbaric, retrograde and totally abhorrent action by this totalitarian government in Romania. The city of Timisoara is the fourth largest city in Romania. It is situated towards the western extremity of that country, about 50 kilometres from the Hungarian border and about 50 kilometres from the Yugoslav border. It is quite distant from the capital, Bucharest.

Some 20 years ago as a post, graduate student in Europe, I visited this part of Romania. I remember with great affection the welcome given to me by the ordinary people of Romania. I travelled from Bucharest to Sighisoara where I stayed several days, to Cluj in the centre of a broad valley in Transylvania, and to the north of Timisoara I came to Hungary. Between 10 and 20 years ago I was all the more conscious of a refreshing realism and progressive acceptance of human rights that were expressed by some aspects of the government in that country. At that time it looked as though Romania was one of the progressive countries that would not only increase trade with other parts of the world and every kind of intercourse, but also would accord rights to its own people. But the last decade has been one of enormous tragedy to the people of that country. It has reversed any feelings of encouragement that we had felt 10 or 20 years ago.

The repression has been especially felt by those individuals, families, communities and institutions which have had a foundation to challenge the conforming nonsense of this totalitarian communist regime. I mention in particular the church and minority communities, especially the Hungarian minority of several millions which used to predominate in Transylvania. That province used to be an integral part of Hungary earlier this century-in fact it had been for many centuries. So the ethnic community whose language, naturally, is Hungarian, has been one of the groups seen to be challenging the power of the communist government in Bucharest which is led by President Ceausescu. The ageless affirmations of the Christian church in Romania have also been seen-and rightly so-as a challenge to the government of President Ceausescu. It is not surprising that when this ruthless, brutal regime chose its time to repress the people yet further it acted in Timisoara last weekend against a popular Christian priest who had gained the ear not only of the Romanian peoples, but also of the Hungarian minority within Romania. It is the case that when the police tried to arrest this popular priest and human rights campaigner, Laszlo Tokes, the crowds tried to defend him and to stand up for their spokesman, the one who had represented their views. Tragically, as is reported, government tanks and helicopters with automatic fire mowed down the people in that demonstration of support for a popular and honourable man.

I stand in the Senate tonight-together with those who spoke on the motion which we all adopted this afternoon and with all Australians, not least Transylvanian and other Hungarian emigres to this country-to protest yet again the suppression of the rights of this Christian spokesman and of the peoples of Transylvania and Romania.

In the time that is available to me in this adjournment debate, I wish to refer briefly to a speech I made in the first week of November a year ago. I delivered to the Senate one of the largest petitions brought to the Senate last year. It bore 5,247 signatures and was from the Hungarian Association in my State of South Australia. It was protesting the decision by the Government of Romania to obliterate 7,000 villages in Romania. There are only 13,000 villages in that country. The Government of Romania had ruthlessly decided that, in order to bring the Hungarian minority into line, it would destroy their culture and their villages; it would rip the soul out of the community in Transylvania. Accordingly, it was without surprise to me that there was such an enormous response by those who understood this matter. Being conscious of the fact that I had visited Romania, they brought their petition to me to present to the Senate. At that time I noted that a few months earlier I had greatly protested the visit to this country of President Ceausescu.

In the 12 years I have been a senator, I have attended very happily all of the state occasions when we have had dinners, lunches, or occasions to recognise the visit of a president or a prime minister to this country. The only occasion that I have felt it was just and right not to attend was when in April 1988 President Ceausescu of Romania, this dictator, so wrongly was the guest of the Government of this country. Senator Button this afternoon in his speech supporting the motion that we have all agreed to, gave the excuse that a general invitation had been extended to President Ceausescu some decade earlier and that the government of the day, led by Mr Hawke, had felt some obligation to live up to that invitation in the year of our Bicentenary. But I see that as an excuse. I see Senator Button and the Government members wanting to draw away from anything to do with that disgraceful week in the history of this Parliament in terms of those we have accepted here. It was well known last year that this regime was brutalising and denying its own people their rights and that Ceausescu was villainous and was using Stalinist methods to suppress the people of his own country.

I will not detail all of my speech made on 4 November 1988, but I note that just today one of the most famous intellectual Romanians, Eugene Ionesco-a playwright, born in Bucharest who, as a child, went to live in Paris, France, with his parents, then went back as a student to Bucharest and taught in the university there for some years-today said:
Ceausescu is a madman, his wife-
I interpolate that she is in fact in control of Romania while the President is visiting Iran-
thirsty for power, is also mad and his son is an idiot and it's these three people who are being allowed to freely torture 23 million people.

I am sure that he did not say this lightly. It is a great tragedy that, when even the Communist Party alleges that it is supporting a democratic process, Romania has a father, a wife and a son acting against anything that could be interpreted as democratic principle and applying their own personal views and whims on the people of their own country, to their great harm.

Ceausescu is visiting Iran at the moment. He had the temerity today to give a speech at a banquet in Iran in which he said that his country's social and economic position was `good, stable and balanced'. That is a lie, a lie and a lie. There is no soundness either in this man or in his government. The enormous tragedy of this repression of the ordinary people of Timisoara and of Romania will take its toll upon that man, his government and the police state that he operates.

It was with obscenity that Australians see the central committee of the Communist Party of Romania standing and clapping its President in a recently televised excerpt of support for the policies which were to stand against all that is happening in Hungary, Poland, Czechoslovakia and East Germany. I believe that it is impossible eventually to restrain truth, justice and the rights of the people, and it will not be long before the people of Romania win justice and freedom.

Only a matter of weeks ago Mr Honecker, the former President of East Germany, was also praising the actions of the Communist Party Government in China for its actions in Tiananmen Square. He and Ceausescu were alone in the whole world in doing that. Already, Honecker has been expelled from his own Communist Party. He is in disgrace; he is accused of corruption. Even his successor is no longer in office, such is the rapidity of the effects of the disgust of the people of East Germany for the Government that so mismanaged their affairs. I look to the day, which will not be far off, when the people of Romania see the same kind of just and sound outcome for their own country.

In speaking tonight, I am aware of the thousands of Australians, especially those who lived in Transylvania-indeed, in all of Romania-who, I am confident, share the views that have been expressed by so many senators in the Senate today. I can only urge, as I did both a year ago and two years ago, the Government of this country to act together with other countries in taking international action to apply pressure to the Government of Romania to ensure that the human rights of its people are safeguarded and that we will not see this kind of barbarity and uncivilised and terrible tragedy ever occur again in that country.
