SPEECH.PARA: I wish to talk tonight about the Lesueur community in Western Australia. In September of this year members of the Lesueur community-a rural community north-east of Jurien Bay, a small town some 200 kilometres north of Perth-guided me on an excursion through what I can only describe as a botanical wonderland, otherwise known as Mount Lesueur. This area is considered by scientists and botanists as a botanical treasure which equals those that we have in the Stirling Range and the FitzGerald River National Park. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard two passages from Swans, Volume 123, No. 3 1983, which is the journal of the now defunct Western Australian Fisheries and Wildlife Department.

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order: Senator Jenkins might think that we in the Opposition sit here every night for the good of our health listening to her. I hasten to add that we do not, and it would be nice if on occasions she had the courtesy to show either the front bench or the Whip on duty that which she seeks to incorporate before she seeks leave to incorporate it; and we shall not grant leave until she has done so.
—I show the document to the honourable senator.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
(SWANS Passage No. 1, Vol 123, No. 3 1983)

``The Mt. Lesueur-Cockleshell Gully area proposed for reservation includes one of the more interesting and spectacular parts of the landscape in the northern kwongan (the Irwin Botanical District). It is an area where the ancient sedimentary rocks have been broken up and distorted by a series of major faults with their surfaces partially lateritized.''
and further on

``The vegetation of the area is mainly kwongan or shrublands as is typical of much of the Northern sandplain region. These shrub communities are very rich in plant species having up to 80 different species in a 100m2 quadrat.
and again

``The rich flora of the proposed reserve includes many species which are of special conservation interest. It is estimated that the total flora exceeds 600 species and of these 7 are gazetted rare and over 50 additional species have very restricted distributions being generally confined to the Jurien-Eneabba area.''

. . . . ``Twenty three of the Mt. Lesueur species are rare or restricted and a further 20 unde- scribed species are likely to be categorised similarly when the appropriate taxonomic research is undertaken.''
(SWANS Passage No. 2, Vol 123, No. 3 1983)
ARTICLE by Dr Stephen Hopper

``The aggregation of rare species, geographical outliers of widespread species, and a remarkably rich assemblage of plants in the small area surrounding Mt. Lesueur makes the region exceptionally valuable for flora conservation.''
``Once created, the proposed Mt. Lesueur Nature Reserve will rectify what has been an important deficiency in the State's network of nature reserves and national parks.''

TALK.START.PARA: —Interestingly, in 1989 the Mount Lesueur proposed conservation reserve faces a similar struggle for survival as that which the Fitzgerald River area faced some 20 years ago. Fortunately for the world and for all Australians, the proposed mining of the Fitzgerald River area, which was vigorously opposed by conservationists and others, did not proceed. Today, the Fitzgerald River National Park is considered to be one of Western Australia's great national parks and is an internationally acclaimed biosphere reserve.

SPEECH.PARA: Unfortunately, Western Australian governments seem to have learned little from that episode when nature conservation values were pitted against short term dollar gains. If they had, farmers, fishermen, conservationists, scientists and unionists would not now find it necessary to campaign to prevent Mount Lesueur being mined for coal with the prospect also of a coal-fired power station being built there. The justification of this proposal, which apparently has the support of the mining industry and the Western Australian Government, is weak indeed, given the abundance of other sources of energy which exist in Western Australia, sources which can be developed without destroying unique and rare flora. We only have to consider the natural gas pipeline which passes virtually through the area and also wind power and solar power, all of which are evident in Western Australia, as well as other forms of sustainable power.

The value of the Mount Lesueur area as a national park together with its adjacent sustainable agriculture and fishing industries is the type of regional planning and development that any responsible government would be proud of and should be promoting as a showpiece not only for our State, Western Australia, but for Australia as a whole. Instead, we have all these values being threatened by a possible coalmine and power station. Not only is the coal low grade, but the huge draw on the underground water required for a power station could well adversely affect established and sustainable agriculture, which is well-established in that region.

The botanical values of Mount Lesueur have been known since the early settlement of Western Australia. As far back as 1950, James Drummond, the first botanical collector to visit the area, is said to have called it his El Dorado. Since then, successive scientists have reiterated the praise as each survey adds to their knowledge of the area. While no Western Australian government has been able to resist the pressure of the mining industry, which has lobbied so successfully to prevent gazettal of Mount Lesueur as an A class conservation reserve, at least the Court Government in 1976 accepted the recommendations of the Environmental Protection Authority (EPA) for the area to become a nature reserve. Despite this, and despite opposition to the granting of mining tenements by the conservation movement, exploration tenements were granted at Mount Lesueur. The existence of substantial coal deposits has been known for many years.

Under the Burke Government, a review of mining activity in respect of conservation reserves and reserve proposals was undertaken and a report was provided to the Minister for the Environment. With regard to Mount Lesueur it stated that the State Conservation and Land Management (CALM) Department places the highest conservation value on the area, particularly for locations that have significant coal reserves. A number of alternatives have been discussed but the situation remains virtually at an impasse.

Conzinc Riotinto of Australia Ltd (CRA) in 1989 officially notified the EPA that it wished to proceed with a coalmine and power station at Mount Lesueur. The Department of Resources Development came to the assistance of CRA in a report in favour of the proposed development on the basis that the privatisation of power supply would help restructure the industry and improve productivity and thus achieve lower electricity tariffs for Western Australia. A further report by CALM scientists dated July 1989 documenting the international significance of Mount Lesueur and the need for A class conservation protection of the whole area-approximately 28,000 hectares-has been suppressed. All attempts by myself and several others to obtain copies of the report have failed. The fear in the community is that the report will be doctored to suit the needs of CRA and the Western Australian Government should the Government ever allow its release. This fear is reinforced by the hip-pocket reaction of the Chairman of the EPA to a statement by Dr Christine Sharp on 22 November reported in the West Australian. Dr Sharp was appointed to the Western Australian Environment Protection Authority in October 1989, the first woman ever appointed. Dr Sharp has a long history of conservation activity as well as of being a farmer and tree planter. But Dr Sharp made one mistake: she dared to state publicly what scientists and public servants alike have said behind closed doors. The West Australian article of 25 November stated:
In the interview, on the morning of her first EPA meeting, Dr Sharp said she believed the power station-plans for which include mining coal at nearby Mt Lesueur-should not go ahead.

Dr Sharp believes that the Mount Lesueur power station should not go ahead and that, instead, the Government should strongly encourage renewable power generation. The Chairman of the EPA, Mr Barry Carbon, just three days later responded to such honesty by disqualifying Dr Sharp from assessment of the CRA mining proposal. I quote again from the same West Australian article. Mr Carbon said:
I have determined that Dr Sharp will take no part in any discussions, deliberations, or decisions relating to the forthcoming review of the Hill River power station.

Dr Sharp's comments caused uproar in the mining industry. As yet, no public servant has spoken out publicly in defence of freedom of speech for Dr Sharp. Members of the voluntary conservation movement have, thankfully, expressed their abhorrence of the intimidatory tactics used.

I believe, bearing in mind that a Labor government is in power in Western Australia, that the situation is an extraordinary demonstration of just how politicised government agencies have become. We know a lot in Western Australia about WA Inc. It is extraordinary that scientists are muzzled and their careers and jobs are in jeopardy should they speak out, or, in fact, even whisper the truth. It is extraordinary that a person appointed to enhance the environment is disqualified from speaking the truth. Dr Christine Sharp was merely restating the EPA conservation assessment of 1974, restating what eminent scientists such as the Government Botanist, Charles Gardner, said in the 1950s, and the Academy of Science in 1962. The context has changed, but not the facts.

Both the Western Australian Government and the EPA stand condemned for not prioritising implementation of the recommendation that Mount Lesueur be an A class conservation reserve and they stand condemned for allowing the mining proposal to proceed to the stage it is now at. Exploration has already damaged the area, but, from what I have seen with my own eyes, I believe that the situation is not irretrievable. Not only will a mine and/or power station destroy this botanical wonderland, but it will also threaten one of the most stable mixed agricultural regions in the State, an area where the farmers show practical day to day concern for the land which provides their living. The coalmine and power station could also jeopardise the fishing industry which is based at nearby Jurien. Indeed, the fishermen of the area have expressed very vocally their concern on this score. I am appalled that local farmers like Don and Joy Williams, who have worked tirelessly to protect seven rare eucalypts on their Badgingarra farm at their own expense, and who this year won the John Tonkin Greening Australian Gold Tree Award-people with an abiding commitment to land care-have to devote time, energy and funds to opposing the mine and power station proposal, a proposal which any government committed to sustainable development would by now have rejected.

I cannot believe that the commitment of Senator Cook, Senator Richardson and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) to `Our Country Our Future' will dissipate into smooth words and lame excuses when it comes to the future of Mount Lesueur. Mount Lesueur undoubtedly qualifies as a biosphere reserve. Senator Cooks' public commitment to the use of constitutional powers where co-operation with the States to uphold environmental protection fails may well be put to the test at Mount Lesueur. I urge Senators Cook and Richardson to avail themselves of all the scientific reports on Mount Lesueur and to view the video produced by the Lesueur Community Group. Western Australian is not quite so bankrupt that it needs, or should be allowed, to destroy one of the world's treasures in order that electricity costs might be marginally reduced. It is far too high a price to pay.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Senate adjourned at 8.51 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The following requirements were included in the August 1986 request for proposals for the replacement Antarctic vessel:
The operator should have proven, well established ice experience in ship design operation and upkeep; and
The vessel should be crewed by officers and complement with sound ice expectations.
(2) The response by P & O Polar to the 1987 request substantially met the ice experience specified in the 1986 request.
(3) P & O Australia was not included on the first short list of bidders, prepared in 1986.
(4) The charter is signed by Mr R. J. Hein for P & O Polar Australia Pty Ltd.
(5) The Commonwealth is satisfied that at the relevant time the contractor had available to it the experience specified in the request for proposals.
(6) The Charter for the Aurora Australis includes the following provision relating to the experience of the Navigation Officers:

``For any Navigation Officer joining the Vessel the resume required under clause 40 hereof is to specifically include the proposed officer's age, certificates held by him, position to be held by him and his previous ice experience (particularly Antarctic) including the number of voyages undertaken by him (including the areas and the time of year). The Charterer shall within seven (7) days of the receipt of such resume advise the Owner in writing as to whether it approves of the proposed appointment and whether the ice experience of the proposed Officer is acceptable to the Charterer.''
The following Antarctic experience was required of the key members of the crew in the invitation to submit final bids in September 1987:
Captain: Ice strategy experience for at least four years in Antarctica in a similar sized vessel.
First Mate: At least two years in Antarctica in a similar sized vessel and a good understanding of ice strategy.
Two Deck Officers: At least one year's Antarctic experience.
(7) The current officers nominated by P & O will have the following experience by the time of the first voyage of Aurora Australia;
Captain: Two seasons Antarctic ice experience on Icebird plus training on a Canadian Arctic icebreaker.
First mate: Three seasons Antarctic ice experience on Icebird plus special training on an Arctic icebreaker.
One Deck Officer: Extensive trawling experience for the operations to be conducted in the research mode. Will undertake two Antarctic voyages this season.
Second Deck Officer: Trawling experience. Will undertake one voyage in Antarctica this season.

P & O (Aust.) has recently put forward a proposal for the First Mate to be replaced by an officer with four seasons Antarctic experience and extensive trawling experience. This proposal is currently being considered.
(8) The Commonwealth will pay the costs if an ice pilot is found to be necessary to provide the required ice experience for particular voyages until the Australian crew has adequate experience.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism, and Territories, upon notice, on 14 November 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Was a `Letter of Intent' given to P&O Polar shortly after the Government announced, on 16 December 1987, that contract negotiations could be commenced with P&O Polar; if so: who drafted the letter; was the advice of the Australian Government Solicitor sought; if so, what was his advice; who signed the Letter of Intent; who approved the letter; and what were the terms of the letter.
(2) What would have been the cost to the Commonwealth if a contract had not been signed in October 1988 due to the inability of the parties to the negotiations to agree on the terms.
(3) Does the charter contract for the Icebird provide for a reduction in the charter rate if the ship is beset in ice during the Antarctic season.
(4) Does the charter contract for the Aurora Australis provide for a reduction in the charter rate if the ship is beset in ice during the Antarctic season.

(5) Does the charter contract provide for payment by the Commonwealth of the off-season lay-up costs for the Aurora Australis; if so, has this ever been a condition of previous time charter contracts for Antarctic ships.
(6) Does the contract specify where the Aurora Australis will be laid up.
(7) What was P&O Polar's offer for the first full season.
(8) Do the specifications of the ship, as built, fail in any areas to meet the Antarctic Division's specification on which the successful bid was submitted.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) A Letter of Intent was provided to P&O Polar on 18 December 1987. The Australian Government Solicitor's Office redrafted a letter proposed by the successful tenderer and it was the version drafted by the Australian Government Solicitor's Office which was provided. The Australian Government Solicitor's Office provided advice on 22 December 1987 on the question of the issue of a Letter of Intent. The Letter of Intent was signed by the then Deputy Director of the Antarctic Division, Mr Rex Moncur. The letter was referred to my office for approval prior to it being signed. The letter read as follows:

Federal cabinet has approved the Commonwealth Government entering a charter for a research vessel to be deployed in the Antarctic and pursuant to this approval it is the intention of the Commonwealth Government to award P&O Polar a firm ten year charter for such a vessel for use in the Antarctic subject to the negotiation of a charter acceptable to the Commonwealth which is based on:
(a) the P&O Polar proposals to the Commonwealth dated 30 October 1987; and

(b) the understandings set out in the letter dated 18 December 1987 which was sent to Mr J. Bleasel of the Antarctic Division of the Department of Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories by Mr R. J. Hein of P&O Polar.

This letter is provided to enable P&O Polar to act immediately, prior to the completion of the negotiation of the charter, to place an order for the construction of a vessel appropriate for the charter with an Australian shipyard so that construction of the vessel can commence before 31 December, 1987.
(2) This is a hypothetical question as the Charter party was signed.

(5) The charter does provide for payment by the Commonwealth of the off-season lay-up costs for the Aurora Australis should it be laid up. However, this provision only applies if the vessel is actually laid up and not being used for other purposes. As far as can be established, through the checking of recent ship charters, this has not been a provision of previous time charters for ships for the Antarctic Division.
(6) The Charter does not specify where the Aurora Australis will be laid up.
(7) The basic price for vessel hire, crew costs and scientific instrumentation was estimated at $10.1 million for the 1989/90 season.

(8) The successful contractor along with most other bidders submitted their own specification as part of their bid. This was assessed as meeting the functional requirements of the Commonwealth. Following further negotiations the specification was refined and enhanced to provide additional functional requirements (eg ice breaking increased from 80 cm to 123 cm and passenger capacity increased from 70 to 109) and the inclusion of retractable axial thrusters to support slow speed research operations, increase manoeuvrability and provide a back up in case of damage to the main propeller. These enhancements were included in the final specifications which were agreed between the Commonwealth and the contractor on 13 October 1988.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs: Corporate Plan

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 28 November 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What were the reasons for the publications of the corporate plan of the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs in a form resembling a trade promotion booklet on high-quality paper and with colour photographs and colour charts.
(2) Did the Department, in view of expenditure restraints, consider publishing the corporate plan in a simpler, more modest form; if so, what was the price differential.
(3) How many copies were printed, and who has received and who is entitled to receive a copy.
(4) What was the total cost of publishing the plan.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) There is great public interest in immigration. Most people have a point of view. Many are directly affected by immigration decisions. Relatively few people are well informed. The Government is committed to encouraging more informed debate and to increasing community involvement in policy formulation. The Department's Corporate Plan was chosen as a major vehicle for promoting this debate and involvement, through widespread dissemination of facts. A brief, attractive and revealing, presentational style was considered appropriate for this purpose, and to encourage interest and commitment in staff of the Department.
(2) No, for the reasons set out in (1).
(3) Twelve thousand copies have been printed. Anyone who is interested in obtaining a copy can do so. People and organisations who have currently received a copy are set out below:
All members and senators of the Federal Parliament
Federal and ACT Government Departments and Authorities
A number of State Government Departments
Members of the National Population Council
Members of the Committee to Advise on Australia's Immigration Policies
A number of economic and social academics
Individuals whose photographs appeared in the Plan.

(4) The process of developing the plan involved most staff in the Department at some stage. Excluding staff costs, the direct printing and publication costs were $25,354.17, or about $2.10 production costs per copy.
